reviewText:
RAGE seems like a strange lovechild if Fallout made love to Quake in the backseat of a racing car. It is a furiously fast-paced FPS with visceral and brutal combat, while at the same time mixing things up with off-road racing, RPG elements, mini-games and crafting.

Sounds an awful lot like Fallout, doesn't it? Well, it's not. Despite many striking similarities, RAGE is entirely its own game. It does all the things Fallout does, but in its own way. If you leave your expectations and comparisons at the door and just play the game for what it is, you will find a competent and diverse FPS that may keep you entertained for a good 10-12 hours.

RAGE is a linar post-apocalyptic action game with a twist. It has towns with NPCs, quests, exploration, hidden loot and collectibles, mini-games and even racing tracks.

But most of all it is a hectic First Person Shooter, and this is where the game shines. The shooter element is the bread-and-butter of RAGE. It's fast, powerful, intense and it feels good! There are a wide range of weapons to use, each of which has numerous different ammunition types to spice things up even more. Take for example the crossbow; it fires regular steel bolts as one would expect - but swap them out with Dynamite sticks and watch your enemies panic as they realize they have only 3 seconds left to live. Swap in the Mindcontrol bolts and the crossbow turns your enemies into deadly walking bombs under your control!

The variety of weapons and ammo has you swapping back and forth between them with glee as you leave wasteland mutants in exploded gibs, charred corpses and decapitated slumps. What is even more striking is how the enemies move. They will pounce at you, climb railings to reach you and leap off of walls. They deftly dodge and weave in zig-zag patterns to make your life as miserable as possible. Their movement is fast, sporadic and unpredictable - and it just looks awesome.

When you're not dropping mutants by the dozen, the town offers a nice breather away from the gunfights and gives you the opportunity to pick up side-quests for extra challenges. Race for glory at the local racing track or shop and listening to NPC banter. The mini-games range from strumming banjos, throwing dice or even pitting your deck of special playing cards against NPCs. You can also craft your own specialized ammo, grenades and other useful gadgets with ingredients scavenged on missions or bought from merchants.

RAGE also has a few downsides, the most glaring perhaps being the poor and sudden ending. The plot is likewise lack-luster, uninteresting and just overall trivial. More often than not I found myself skipping story conversation because it was so bland I just wanted to go back to shooting stuff.

The graphics are a mixed blessing. Generally the sky and landscapes are mindlbowingly beautiful, but many of the up-close scenery looks washed out and blurry, sometimes to the point where you can't even make out what you are even looking at.

The sound effects and music is very good. The guns sound punchy and futuristic, and the voice acting is excellent from start to finish. The vehicle sounds are, however, quite bland.

Overall I feel that RAGE is a worthwhile game that offers a very solid shooter experience and a fairly mediocre everything else." Definitely worthwhile if you enjoy FPS games and/or wasteland style games.


+ Excellent FPS-style gameplay

reviewText:
People can compare Rage to many other games, however it reminds me most of Borderlands with a touch of Fallout and a pinch of Mad Max. However Rage has something new to offer. Yes, it is similar to other games, however what game is not? Rage has a style all its own and really pulls off what they were going for. This is a very grungy game, yet it has times of bright sunny skies and colorful scenes.

The story is not heavily detailed but that's alright for the type of game Rage is. It's a FPS that gets to the point and you never feel bored while playing. I thought the story was enough for me to have an idea of what's going on and get me into the action very smoothly. The first few missions give you a better idea of what's going on and flow of the story feels balanced.

The gameplay mechanics are very easy to use and to adapt to. Driving is fluid as is walking. The pace of walking is a bit quick, but I like it that way. Be that as it may, I often slowed down my pace to really take note to the detailed environments of the caves, tunnels and dilapidated buildings I scrounged through. The enemies are a joy to fight and have a mind of their own. From scaling the walls to jumping at the last second to dodge your attack, it quickly reminded me of the splicers who walked the ceilings of rapture in Bioshock. This makes it all the more challenging and enjoyable. Lastly, RAGE incorporates some RPG elements to help sooth that part of my gaming palate in the forms of customization, upgrades and side missions. All of that and a vehicle only multi-player tacked on? I believe that's a pretty good package.

All in all, I am happy with this purchase and would recommend this to anyone who enjoys shooters with creative atmospheres. I have read mixed reviews about it's length not being what people had hoped (about 10-12 hours) but then again, many of the shooters I have completed were only about 8 hours. With the existence of towns throughout, this will allow me to pace my gameplay and savor the experience without blowing through it a la any other mindless shooter.

reviewText: A real gem in the rough, While this game has a lot of rough edges and if you do buy it you might want to look up some config or visual modification tools in order to make it work for you the game is well done for the most part. While it may not be as open as some other FPS/RPG games out there it does bring a few good things to the table that others do not have. The enemy models, animations and reaction are very well done, fluid and depending on which faction you're fighting against it might play out differently. NPC interactions are good, and facial animations are very well done making them feel organic at times. The story is a bit rough in places and if you've read anything about this game you will already know that the ending is well not great to say the least. While I do wish there was more to the game then what is offered it was mostly fun while it lasted. The tech in the game world is very nice and refreshing; the in game crafting is rather well done and very quick allowing you to use different items against different enemy types.\n\nthe big picture" of each scene is mind-blowingly beautiful. This game's canyon vistas are the most intensely gorgeous I've ever seen

reviewText:
Rage, a post apocalyptic game developed by Id software (the makers of the Doom series) and running on there tech 5 game engine.

I played this game for both Xbox 360 and PC on Steam. I pre-ordered this game when it was available on Steam so I paid $59.99 for it, its now (as of this re-review) $19.99 and the one DLC is $4.99.

The game is your traditional FPS shooter game. Its heavily action packed and has lots some cool weapons. I personally found that the shotgun was the best one to use and favored that over all other weapons. There is crafting in the game as well but I find it very simplistic and only of use when you need to make items to break open locked doors, med packs or throwing blades.

I did play both the solo campaign the coop and the multiplayer side of the game. I am amazed at how well this game looks and plays and the voice actors used for voicing the game characters. The graphics are also superb and very detailed and amazing to look at both scenery and attacking enemies.

The game includes an addon that wasn't originally available unless it was pre-ordered and that's the sewers to explore.

When it was released the game wasn't what gamers were hoping it would be, an open world post apocalyptic game as the media coverage lead you to believe. Once you started playing you quickly found it to be a closed world and once you go through a mission area you can't go back and do it over to get any secrets you left behind or want to find. I didn't find this game to offer any replay value in the solo campaign at all. Don't get me wrong the first play through it increasingly good and very enjoyable.

The multiplayer side of the game is just a dune buggy race doing lap after lap and shooting at one another with mini guns and rockets. Its like deathmatch but with cars. Nothing new provided here by Id Software in this regard.

The says there is Coop play however this can be misleading because you would expect that you can play the campaign with a friend but this isn't the kind of Coop play that Rage offers. Its basically playing objective based missions with a friend.

Rage play's very good with the Xbox 360 controller and that is what I use for all my game play and its what I prefer over the traditional keyboard and mouse.

Overall the game is totally amazing for my first impression and first play through but severely lacks for replay value. However the multiplayer and Coop play looks as if it was an after thought.

In my opinion Id Software dropped the ball on this game or turned a tech demo into a game. Not sure which. This game made Id Software look dated and relying on its old game play style hopping for success.

Had the game been an open world type game with the ability to play it cooperatively then it would have been ground breaking.

Pro's
Amazing Graphics
Voiced Characters
Bladed throwing weapon
Con's
Closed world
No replay value
Coop play is not campaign based
Multiplay is just deathmatch play

reviewText: I love RAGE up until the point where it suddenly railroads you into a final mission and then ends abruptly. The first half is great - made even better by the Scorchers DLC. The shooting and AI are first class, the environments and character models look incredible even in 2014 and until you get near the end of it you'll be wondering why everyone gets so down on it. But up until then, RAGE ♥♥♥♥in' rules. Also the racing and co-op are surprisingly well made and fun. Find someone to play them with. Also, wingsticks.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: RAGE
Original Release: 2011
Genre Tags: FPS; Action; RPG; Post-Apocalyptic
My Overall Grade: A
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 20-45 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWRAGE is an extremely underrated game, and is definitely worth your consideration. It's another game where you find yourself exploring a post-apocalyptic wasteland performing missions for money and trying to survive— then wind up saving the world. In that sense, it feels a bit like a Borderlands game, but with a serious undertone and with realistic-style graphics. When you start to play it, though, you will find it definitely has the FPS experience of an ID game.

It isn't an open-world game really in the true sense of the meaning. But it isn't exactly forcing you from one level to the next, either. I personally found the world immersive and the story engaging. The narrative is well written, even if it relies heavily on established clichés. And I thought the graphics were quite nice; very, very nice actually— there was several times I found myself taking a moment to look around at the scenery and grab screenshots. The gorgeous visuals and interesting narrative establish an undeniably captivating presentation.

As far as gameplay is concerned: the mechanics and controls were solid, and the combat is exciting.  There is a decent amount of gun and enemy variety, but there definitely could be more. It’s enough to keep you interested, but it is certainly somewhat limited. The desire to explore more beautiful landscapes and to finish the interesting story will keep you intrigued, though, if you find yourself growing bored with the combat in the later stages of the campaign. It is certainly a decently sized game. And there are sidequests and minigames that are pretty fun if you are into achievements and extras.

Besides the campaign, there is a coop multiplayer mode where you can clear dungeons with a friend. There are a good number of missions to beat and they tie into the main campaign as little background stories of NPCs and locations. It is quite fun, actually, and adds a very welcome bonus layer of content.

Also, there is a racing multiplayer mode (for which I had trouble finding games, to be honest). I was able to find a few games with a low amount of people— but it wasn't living up to its full potential. It matters little in the long run, as the rest of the game is well worth it.

And so: if you are looking for a story-driven, atmospheric, and action-packed FPS game with a high standard of quality, you would be wise to give RAGE some consideration.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
I've read so many things about RAGE, how it was a huge disappointment, what kind of a lacklustre game it was. I needed to give it a try and all I can say is that while the game is a lot better than its counterparts in many areas, it lacks some vital things to make the world more vivid.

Pros:
- Enemy AI is great, they are responding to how you play. If you're going head on with a shotgun in your hands, they try to stay far and shoot you down with AR's or surround you with their greater numbers. If you're playing one shot one kill, they act swiftly and try to mow you down with their athletic skills.
- Enemy variety is good. You never find yourself killing the same type of enemy all the time. Even in missions and bandit clans, variety is good.
- Town designs are good and based on real world architecture. For example Subway Town is based on Chinese style, Jackal Territory resembles Brazilian Favelas, Dead City is the classic metropolis.
- Different accent and characteristics for every bandit clan feels great, a lot better than any other generic bandits in games.
- If you play stealthy, there are a lot of times where you can see how bandit clans work, how they are small military dictatorships, ruled by benevolent and paternal figures. Great insight.
- Missions are great, especially Dead City is one of the most memorable FPS missions for me.
- Caricature NPCs, like J.K Stiles and Dietrich are great.
- References in the story, things that are hidden shows that this game was made with passion and the goal was to lead the player to experience the game fully.
- Boss fights.
- Ammo and weapon variety can make any FPS player wet, but an oldschool LMG could add a lot to the gameplay.

Cons:
- Sİlent protagonist is a huge no for this kind of game. I've been asleep for years, I should speak, eat, drink, love, hate etc. I need to do things that makes me feel what it's like to be a human again. For example, one of the first missions could be getting in shape something like (Run 20 miles, do some push ups (like in GTA:SA)). The protagonist feels like a mindless robot.
- Alienation of the protagonist continues with no personal story. Finding devices that contained data about him should have told who he was, all you get for motivation to play is this is this

reviewText:
RAGE is a great game at first. Everything feels unique . The graphics are incredible and the atmosphere stunning. The weapons feel satisfying and the enemy AI responsive. The enemies are not too tough , but not too easy either. The story seems interesting in the beginning too. The driving can be fun and there are options to modify your weapons and vehicles. The world seems big enough for you to explore , which is also pretty nice. The crafting system is simple and useful. Additionally , the mechanics in total feel useful .There are also plenty of mini-games you can play in order to earn some extra cash which are pretty fun. The combat system is similar to most of the shooters today, nothing special , but was made better and more engaging by specific mechanics , like the wingsticks . Overall, the first few hours spent in the game were enjoyable and the game just felt great.

After the first few hours of gameplay,however,  the game starts going downhill. The weapons  stop feeling that great and the game starts to repeat itself just to make you feel that it's longer. The missions feel incredibly repetitive and I just felt that the only thing I was doing was to drive from point A to point B and then kill endless waves of enemies.  I also started getting really mad about my character , since I never got to even hear his voice. Even the driving started becoming extremely boring and the challenge had all been lost , since I was never pressed for ammo. There were infinite supplies of everything : grenades , bandages , ammo. The enemies stopped being interesting and handling them was just too easy. I didn't even get to finish the game , since the atmosphere and gameplay became so repetitive that drove me mad! It felt like an endless motive.. Last but not least ,the lack of cutscenes took away the immersion for me as well. It felt like the game lacked something basic , apart from the other. As a conclusion , every aspect of the game was simply ruined by the unneccesary extreme length of the storyline , which caused repetitiveness.

To sum up , RAGE is a fun shooter at first , but as you get used to the mechanics and the gameplay  , as well as the story and the mission patterns , it stops being  immersive and throws away the potential.

Thanks for reading and I hope that this review has been helpful!

reviewText:
I kept going hot & cold with Rage to start with, but my perserverence was rewarded when the story line kicked up a gear & suddenly, hours flew by. The whole linear story line holds no issues with me, there's nothing wrong with a single thread-story if it's an immerseive experience.

On the one hand, it has the same issue Farcry 2 has; it's side jobs that extend the game time are little repetative at times, popping you out of the experience & it has a typical id trait that means the character feels slightly ponderous in his movement. Not a major thing, but something I need a little game time to adapt to.

However, that said, the combat is excellent, the AI engages in tactics that vary from one group or tribe to the next; some use melee weapons, others keep their distance, the Authority uses armour & sheilds. They use grenades, they retreat when you over power a squad, they use cover... It really holds onto you as a player. The mutants, meanwhile, are aggressive, really fast moving & resistant to injury, so you have to be accurate & prepared to retreat yourself. They crawl on any surface so appear out of no where, giving some genuine tension when an NPC tells you to go into mutant-infested locations.

Secondly, the little mini-games; trump cards, gambling machines, holographic games to bet on, racing... all make it feel like there are actual communities looking for entertainment & diversions. You're not forced to engage with these, but they do add detail to the 'world'.

While the car segments aren't the worst in an FPS, OK at best, it's the FPS part that makes the game. All the weapons have different flaws & strengths, all have various ammo types to play with that give advantages but also have drawbacks. This means you have to use your loadout rather than just use one gun as everything is useful & necessary.

Remote control cars with bombs, sentry bots/turrets. emp grenades... all of these can be built using parts found laying around, plus to get a dead characters ammo, you have to 'use' them, all making the player get involved in the game, rather than just shooting anything that moves. As different groups & tribes favour different weapons, you're forced to consider what guns to use depending on who you're fighting.

The problem for Rage is that Doom 3 & id's reputation hangs around it's neck a bit, colouring what is a good story driven FPS. Give it a fair chance, put enough time in for the plot to shift up a gear, 5 hours plus at least, & it will reward you. For me, a fully filled-out world is more than just being a sandbox shooter & Rage is an example of that. It's not a top game, but it's pretty good & certainly worth spending time with.

reviewText:
This is a hell of a game. I remember it getting heavily critizied when it first came out for technical issues, but these have been fixed now, you will need a decent rig to be able to play RAGE on full graphics, understandably though, since it looks absolutely stunning.

The game play reminded me very much like Borderlands, lots of different types of weapons, and your vehicle that you can upgrade with different weapons and armour.

The there so much content here, just the right amount of side missions to go along with the main story, that makes the flow of the game feel good. There is a few dull moment where you find yourself running from point to point in the cities, but they come part in parcle with this sort of game.

Another interesting feature would be the racing, this is done very well, the controls are perfectly carried out, not difficult at all, and it is actually a really nice addition to the game, it gives a nice break between running and gunning.

I would really recommend RAGE, there is about thirty hours of content here and you can always get this really cheaply now days.

reviewText:
It was definitely fun. But there are a few things that really took away from it.

Positive:
- The graphics and environments are still amazing, even today.
- The AI is incredible. Enemies are dificult enough to keep you awake. Their death animations are realistic, and make you feel like you actually just killed a real human being... yay.
- The combat is fun and engaging, though you'll never be pressed for ammo.
- The racing is pretty good, even if it's almost impossible to lose.

Negative:
- Your character is boring. He's silent, and has basically no personality beyond people telling him that he's awesome.
- The main antagonists aren't even seen until the second half of the game.
- The main antagonists are basically just future Nazis.
- The textures take a while to pop in.
- The final mission is really really short, and there's no huge boss battle. Just a bunch of easy-♥♥♥ enemies that I breezed through with a shotgun.
- The ending isn't really explained, and makes no sense at all.

I give it a 7/10. Worth at least one playthrough.

reviewText:
First and foremost: RAGE is a strikingly beautiful game. Coming from iD, I would expect no less. Since the dawn of the shooter they've been at the forefront of cutting edge technology with a minimum of requirements. With new engine iD Tech 5, they've done it again - this is one of the most beautiful game worlds ever realised. It's staggering the amount of detail that can be seen in this title, from the cliffs and canyons to the exquisite characters. But for all it’s beauty, RAGE is a shooter very much stuck in the past, and while story and character have been beefed up a great deal from past iD products, they just can’t compare with shooters of today. RAGE is wonderful to play, but caring about the game world or having an emotional attachment to any character is a darn sight harder.

You awaken in the beginning from a cryo-chamber after many hundreds of years of slumber. The world has mostly been destroyed by an asteroid, and various mutants, bandits and factions now control various parts of this ‘wasteland’. Upon exiting the safe confines of this vault, noting that the other inhabitants have long since deceased, you’re attacked by a mutant and saved by a local. In short time you’re given a gun and you’re told to start shooting. As is the pedigree of this developer, RAGE is a shooter first and foremost.

It’s a very traditional shooter as well, corridors and small warehouses rule the day, and enemies jump out from the shadows and behind inaccessible doors. While the game world is at times large, this is more of a playground for vehicular destruction and transportation, getting from one location to another, and can be considered filler. While it has its moments it certainly feels like a part of the world to give it a greater ‘Mad Max’ vibe – there for the sake of being there, and it begins to lose its sheen the longer you play. However, it plays second fiddle to the shooting, and while no one could accuse RAGE of being revolutionary, it’s not held back by its lack of ambition.

In fact, because of this, RAGE’s old-school gameplay feels a little fresh, even if it’s playing to its out-dated strengths. The guns, for instance, genuinely feel powerful, and the ragdoll physics really show their strength. Shoot a guy with an arrow, and he’ll stick to a wall. Blast out their legs and they’ll flip over as they’re in full pelt. Shields crack and splatter from impacts, skulls crack open, and generally, the various guns, each with multiple ammo types, feel creative and meaty.

In addition, there are many single use items that can be crafted, found or purchased throughout the game world, such as bladed boomerang ‘wingsticks’, gun turrets, spider droids and RC bomb cars, to name a few. Occasionally you may need to be creative, with the enemy A.I being considerably good. They tend to work together, hide behind shield carrying allies, flush you out with bombs, call orders to each other, flank and generally do their best to kill you. Even suicidal mutants will jump back and forth, hop around corridor walls and ceilings, only to backstab you. The various enemies each have their own powers and weapons they favour as well, zig-zagging while they throw screen-darkening clutter at you, ducking and dodging as you’re blasting away. Thankfully, the pacing is spot on, you never feel over-whelmed, and there is always enough challenge.

Apart from the shooting, there are odd jobs around towns, such as blowing up bandits cars in certain areas, various race types, delivering timed mail, and even a circus like murder simulation television show where you are literally put into arenas of death. None of it is as compelling as the main quest, but it does help break up the monotony, and helps create the illusion of a living, breathing world. The detail to RAGE is exhaustive, in only the best and most obsessive point possible.

This obsession has been carried to some of the most detailed and amazing character models yet seen in any game. Sadly, they’re not all too interesting. Especially when the game attempts to shift gears and provide a sense of tension – I just wasn’t feeling it. The good guy archetype character is boring as hell, the corrupt characters as cliché’d and obvious from the start. Everyone plays their character, but there is no real personality, and there never feels like a compelling villain or even a compelling reason to your character. The world feels like it’s had far too much lavished upon it’s visuals that it’s characters have become secondary.

The faceless bandits and “Authority” you fight throughout the game might as well be very detailed stick figures with some great artificial intelligence. Fun to shoot at but why should I care? For all the amazing detail, and terrific character animations, especially by the town folk, they might as well all be playing parts in a stage play. Yet even as I played away, hoping to find a payoff, I was quite disappointed. There is no real satisfying conclusion or encounter, and it felt like I was really only fighting for my own personal entertainment rather than any emotional connection.

As of this writing, RAGE has been available for just over two years and it’s more interesting modes have been all but abandoned by gamers. The online multiplayer, once iD’s main claim to fame, is not supported, and the co-op mode, while fun, with a friend I was able to rope in, never felt like a compelling addition, just a very good one.

And that really sums up how I feel about RAGE. It’s a game that feels rooted in the developer’s past while having the vision, the visuals, and the environment, to look towards the future. RAGE proves that iD knows how to craft a fun shooter, yet struggles to create compelling characters or even a memorable narrative. Why should I care about the town of Wellspring when I only just entered it? Despite the context, RAGE is still a blast to play. It may not be revolutionary, but its still a finely crafted shooter that is a whole heaping of fun and comes recommended as something a little old-school.

8.0/10.

reviewText:
+ Beautifully realised game world. When the textures are at their peak they're gorgeous, and this game is a prime example of Post-Processing done right. There is an unbelievable amount of visual fidelity & attention to detail in the game that makes the environments feel seamless, believable and immersive.
+ Fantastic animations and voice acting make for lively, genuine characters.
+ Great enemy AI - though their banter gets repetitive, they'll duck & weave and take cover to make combat more difficult for you.
+ Satisfying gunplay, with weapons that feel like they have some kick on account of good audio mixed with realistic enemy reactions.
+ Linear, but with PLENTY of exploration. Don't go in expecting Fallout's expanse or Call of Duty's hand-holding; RAGE sits fairly solidly as a mid-ground between these two ends of the spectrum.
+ The driving is actually FUN. Vehicles handle nicely, and I found myself playing all the races out of enjoyment rather than necessity.

- Horrible texture pop-in, which detracts greatly from the experience in some areas where flat, mushy Play-Doh surfaces are rampant. No, your eyes aren't blurry... that's just the game's major gaping technical flaw.
- Easier difficulty than you'd expect from some of the godfathers of First Person Shooters. I'm usually a normal difficulty kinda guy, but if you have ANY experience with FPS games then Normal" is a vacation and "Easy" is just insulting. "Hard" feels like the definitive experience
date: where it's difficult enough that you'll want to experiment with everything in your arsenal
recommended: but not SO difficult that you can't rely on the basic pistol to carry you through most situations. Seasoned shooter fans will want to skip right to "Nightmare" or "Ultra-Nightmare"
hoursPlayed: but even then the veterans and masochists will probably leave unsatisfied.\n- Boring soundtrack that really doesn't live up to the standard of the sound effects & ambience. It's uninspired

reviewText:
For all the artistic and technical talent that Id has at its disposal, you'd think that after all these years they'd pick up someone who could write an interesting story. But Rage, like every property Id had created, has a shallow and generic setting, a mere framework for the gameplay it supports. And sadly, the gameplay equally lacks in innovation.

That's not to say I didn't have fun; for an action-shooter FPS, the combat could be remarkably tense, thanks to some good AI and an impressive moveset for all the enemies. The NPCs advance, take cover, throw grenades, retreat, and even try to drag their wounded carcasses out of the firefight. The fights were probably the best part of the game, which is all the more odd since the weapons you fight with are so dismayingly underpowered (in fact, the bulk of my kills were with the pistol with which you start the game). I have equally little to say in favor of the mission-based gameplay and even less about the abysmal driving segments, both of which seemed tacked on to show off the open world technology rather than for interesting gameplay.

And what about that technology? The graphics engine -IdTech5 - excels in creating large detailed levels with sharp textures; there's no low-res skybox in this game! But it rarely takes advantage of this technology; the outdoor levels are broken apart by narrow canyons so you rarely get a feel for the expansiveness of the world. Worse, this impressive long-range detail comes at a cost to the short; close up, the models are distinctly low-polygon in comparison to those used in other modern games. In many areas, Rage looks decidedly second-class.

Throw in a variety of other gaffes - serious technical issues (albeit none that effected me), uninteresting mini-games"
date: unskippable cinematics and a noticeable lack of content - and its not hard to understand why some are calling Rage just another Id tech-demo. It has its moments
recommended: but as a complete product it is significantly lacking."

reviewText:
A semi-open world semi-linear FPS game. You are a survivor of a post-apocalyptic world, battling bandits and mutants at first until you are dragged into a resistance in war with a corrupted army of battle armor soldiers.

This game have one linear main quest, and a number of side quests per main event. Each main quest involve you traversing an area like a city, a dungeon, or a tunnel to find something or kill everyone. Backtracking/sidetracking options are very limited, so there is no feeling of repetition at all.

Weapon options are padded very nicely. The variety are there and not too overwhelming. Your guns are upgraded progressively, and each have their own pro and cons. Your most basic guns are still very useful near the end of the game when you have access to upgraded ammos. The crafting system is there, but I find myself only crafting a few items and ignore all the rest. The sentry bots are kinda OP though, they are very useful in a fight and their ingredients are cheap and common.

There are plenty of mini-games to explore during your main-quest downtime. There's a racing game that is actually pretty good! And there's a collectible card game where the cards are part of the game's collectible items scattered throughout the world. There's an arena for you to kill mutants for money when you just want to kill stuff.

Although it is considered an old release now, you will still need a powerful rig to run this game. The graphics are very good even when compared to today's standard. The gameplay itself is good, but the menu controls feels like a bad console port, mouse sensitivity is very inconsistent.

For achievement huntersThe Scorchers DLC is needed for 100% completion. Minimum 2 playthroughs are recommended if you want to collect all the achievements. Single player achievements are all quite doable, and all of the missable achievements are no longer missable after years of patches. Except a few will require some luck and patience if you aren't very good in that mini-game. Multiplayer is dead, 3-player boosting is needed for 100% completion. Also, 2-player coop buddy will be needed for the coop campaign.

The ending is kinda disappointing.
Other than that, this is a very good game.

My score: 9/10

reviewText: If you don't expect what it can't deliver, it's an amazing game.  Stunningly beautiful environment art and great guns with good variety (and I find myself switching all the time).  Good level design.  It's quite a rigid and pretty heavily scripted world but it's beauty never ceases to amaze and the gameplay keeps being fun for a long while.  The driving/racing component is a bit harder to like, I find, but it's still enjoyable.  Story is nothing to rave about and the characters are forgettable, but the setting of the game is so well presented, it never really becomes too much of an issue.  Overall, if you like good old FPS action delivered with a level of fidelity raised by a good margin, Rage is a really solid pick.

reviewText:
I just finished my third play through of Rage not because it’s such an awesome game but because it’s a 20 gb installation and I’m going to get my headache’s worth before I finally uninstall it. I actually bought the physical DVD version (free after rebate!) and it was a pain getting it installed and registered with Steam. Those of you who buy the game through Steam shouldn’t have any problems though.

I heard that Rage got a lot of flak when it came out because it’s from Bethesda and people thought it would be an HD Fallout game with drivable cars. Instead it’s a mostly linear shooter with some crafting elements and side quests. The graphics really reminded me of Doom 3 (ID Software developed the game) right from the start except with the game taking place mostly in the sunny outdoors.  I suppose it’s technically “open world” but there’s no built in game map, so when you’re cruising in your car you really just follow waypoints. The world’s not that big anyways though. Rage is NOT an RPG, so there is no level up system or skill point system. Instead you rely on your array of weapons and different ammo types to blast your way through.

Non-spoiler story synopsis: An asteroid hits the Earth and a bunch of “arks” are seeded around the world to wake up after the catastrophe. You play one of the ark survivors waking up and exploring the post-apocalyptic world. This means mutants, bandits, and high tech “new world order” enemies. Really, the story isn’t very well explained through gameplay.

Kind of spoiler: There’s no final boss! You’re just playing along in the last area and after holding off a swarm of enemies the game’s over. I was surprised since I had been hording up ammo and didn’t get to use some of the special ammo I was saving up. In all I think the game took about 12 hours to finish but on this my third run I’m skipping some of the side missions. Like I mentioned earlier, there’s no level ups anyway so I won’t really be missing out on anything but story.

Overall I’d give the game a thumbs up. Good graphics, a decent challenge, and pretty cheap nowadays (I think it’s about $5 on sale sometimes). Multi-player is dead though, so factor that into your buying decision.

reviewText:
Having finished the game I'm conflicted to 100% recommend the game.

If we consider a game having a beginning, a middle and an end, then this game has a strong beginning, a heavily declining middle and a completely missing ending.

Without spoiling anything of the story:
You expect the final to be your last stand, having your strongest weapons at the ready only to find yourself finishing the game via cutscene.
Personally, the ending was a letdown and I would consider it a key event which should trigger the finalphase, but it was the end of the game and I doubt we will ever see a fullfilling ending.

All in all this game is a somewhat" in every category it represents.
An O.K. shooter with utility ammunition or gadgets which you will only ever use once to progress the story.
Acceptable graphics once you follow the guide posted on steam to improve the visuals of the game.
Weapon upgrading is shallow and only for the base weapons every other weapon stays unmodified and yet more effective than any of the upgraded weapons. (Excpect for the shotgun. Shotgun is god

slow while shooting with heavy ordnance and armor or hiding behind cover and shooting with their forehead exposed for a clean shot.

reviewText:
I am slightly conflicted when recommending this game. People may enjoy different things out of a game than I do.
As per usual with my reviews, I'll take my time to lay out why I recommend this game.
I bares noting that I finished the game on the ultimate hardest difficulty, only available to owners of the Scorchers DLC.

Rage has a combat system that I regard as fun. Especially in the beginning, assuming you went the hardest difficulty, the game quickly plays the resource game. I was challenged often to use my ammo sparingly, keeping my real good guns for emergencies.

Money is on short supply as well, so it becomes a balancing act of fighting and earning money to cover your costs.
The really strong weapons, like the shotgun (which remains a solid option throughout the game) will run out of ammo fast if you only use that. Sadly, this balance can be ruined by an exploit. It's a little convoluted, but workable. I tried it and felt I ruined the experience a little bit for myself, having large stocks of ammo now. There was no way I would waste 500 shotgun shells halfway through the story. If you feel honorable enough, you can avoid doing it.

The combat itself is enjoyable. The guns feel like they have weight, and rightfully so. Hitting something with the full blast of a shotgun will annihalate a small enemy, and stun normal ones with a second killing them. Using a grenade to stun the really big enemies is a valid tactic to then unload shotgun ammo into them.

But if you play on a hard difficulty, you'll not be running and gunning. In fact, much like the enemies, you'll be looking for cover often and peak out to exploit their unfortunate positioning, if any.
And if you get shot? Well, the revive mechanic is there to save you, zapping you back to life if it has a charge.
This is a good mechanic to balance the cheap lucky shots the enemies sometimes like to dole out.

Storywise, the game is solid. It's not the best, but it tries to be comprehensible and cohesive. It feels like a potential that wasn't fully tapped into. This is noticeable in two things. One is the missions, where they objective is little more than progress through area's through, well, shooting and reaching the end. Then make your way back, often using a shortcut.

But the worst part is, however, it's ending.
Now, I would not skip on buying this game because of it. It's literally the last mission that is completely ♥♥♥♥. You break in a facility, spend a few hallways killing and pushing buttons and then tough out a minor gauntlet. No final boss, nothing to really write home to.

Everything before that mission seems fine and as the same quality as the rest of the game. Which makes it even more mindboggling. I cannot fathom why something like this was ended in such a way.
It begs the question if it wasn't rushed or something.

The same devs made Wolfenstein: The New Order, and I can taste some of the influences. Taking cover, the guns feeling good... But while Wolfenstein was more like a hallway shooter, pushing you forward into levels constantly, Rage has a bit of an open world aspect. Not as vast as you'd hope, but big enough to rummage around and see the sights. However, mission handling and such always happen in cities and such. Even races.

Races are moderately enjoyable, and are required to upgrade your vehicle. But all in all, they're not something that ultimately stands out as extremely enjoyable, but a good enough time waster if you feel like trying. The races vary from time trials, racing combat to hunting random checkpoints that appear on the map. The enemy AI, especially in high difficulties, can be a real challenge though. So if you want those achievements, maybe do those on a different difficulty.

I found Rage a worthwhile experience. The combat and gameplay, which matters more to me, felt good. Most of the weapons fit archetypes that you should be familiar with, but most of their design fits the theme. Except the shotgun. Damn thing looks like a modern polished weapon in a world of rusty and dusted weapons. It doesn't look high tech either like the late game villain's weapons do. Odd one, that.

The exploration and story could have been better, but the atmosphere is very well done. There's lots to do, a few things to gamble in a few games, and tasks to do. The people in the cities don't repeat their lines, and often have interesting things to say. Not to mention that they seem to be all named. As if they were placed by hand.

If the positive aspects I've described call to you, then Rage may be a worthwhile experience for you as well. As a game of age, it'll now be more often on sale, so be sure to grab it at your convenience.
And if you want a game where the combat also feels just as good, Wolfenstein: The New Order will be the next game I may heartily recommend.

reviewText: Mr. Rebounding Health, I want to ask you something.  Are you ashamed at all of how badly you ruin tension, pacing, excitement, difficulty, level design and strategy in video game experiences?  I would have enjoyed RAGE immensely more had you not wiped your feet on the experience.  Okay, sure, the story, characters and ending were bland, but as a game, it's pretty good, and it's a beautifully optimized 10 - 16 hour experience.  The enemies are quite smart and evasive, I got to hold 10 weapons at once with varying ammo types and the baddies responded to where they were hit and were ultimately satisfying to kill.  Hell, even the driving portion of the game was phenomenal, so much so I actually couldn't wait to travel and participate in races.  Then you came in and took away what could have been intense, exciting combat and instead, gave me tunnel vision with how easy and ultimately dull you made the shooting.  Now, thanks to you, I can only half-heartedly recommend RAGE.  Thanks a bunch.

reviewText:
This review is split in 2.

Vanilla Game....great game, although a little on the easy side, even with Ultra Nightmare.  The hardest part of the game were the last 2 DLC levels with the Scorchers.  All in all, very fun game, great graphics, solid performance, and amazing shooting mechanics, as expected from ID.  Minigames are worth spending the time to play, and even though money is abundant, the side quests are fun to accomplish.  Racing mechanics are well done IMO, and i do not use a controller.

8/10

Game with Rebalance mod 2.0......Oh my, this is what the game should have been.  It may not be fair to do a review of a game WITH a mod, but considering IMO this is how the game should have been i will include it.  ReMod2.0 makes items more expensive, ammo less powerful, and the regenerating health is GONE.  Engineering items is now essential to survival.  This mod + Ultra Nightmare is tough as nails and i loved every moment of it....

9.5/10

reviewText:
Rage is fun to play, it's not a GOTY but it's a good FPS with some RPG elements: crafting, inventory. AI is really great, it's fun to see enemies and your robot(s) follow you, climb, hide, etc.

You should totally play it, size can be problematic with slow or limited internet but it's a great experience ;)

Graphics
The graphics are good, but the texture caching is some time (most of time on dual monitor setup) a little ugly, if you see what I mean ... The Mega texture give good decors, but you can see that cars or rocks are paint on the texture (it's flat). Since it's Carmack, you can forget physics for objects: table, chair, some bottles are stick where they are.

Length
The game have a good length I've ~20 hours for the main story and side quest (the only things I haven't done are: little games (boring) and most of races). The last DLC add 2h30 of content, and you can still play after you've finish the main campaign. BTW it isn't a real open world, you can drive around, but you'll encounter many close doors and missions are in a close area each time: sewers, refineries, etc.

Size
The size on my hard drive is: 23814 Mo (with all the DLC: Authority pack, sewers and The Scorchers).

reviewText:
This game is problematic. It's great all-around, but some of the complaints about it are warranted. The design is brilliant, but the execution just isn't quite up to snuff. Blowing off mutant heads is better than ever, and id has really kept up with the times. The gameplay here is completely unique to id.

Some of the more blatant errors have to do with the balance of the weapons later on in the game. The machine gun/ironsight/cover play looks like it should work, even into the Gearheads lair, however this is not the case and suddenly you must change your strategy. Up until enemies get armor however, you can effectively just melee through the game if your aim is good enough. I was able to complete normal without purchasing bandages or saving mid-level, first time through the game. More subtle some of the maps don't make cover and terrain visually clear. Obstacles sometimes only come up to your knees, and you can jump over other stuff that's up to your thighs, it's a real pain to have to learn this in the middle of a firefight. Combat is not a place where you want to fool around with a player's ability to flow. Please only player clip for good, not evil.

But these problems are far and away the exception, and not the rule. id is the best, this game is really quite good, and visually stunning. The uniqueness of the game far outdoes the slight problems with it. 10/10 would buy again

ps: this is one of a few fpses released in the last 5 years where the campaign isn't simply a drawn-out multiplayer tutorial. buy now!

reviewText: Addition to the review: I notice that a lot of people are saying my review isn't helpful, I am not saying this isn't a good game, in fact I quite enjoyed it when I played it on my 8800GTX, but the game has serious technical issues that hinder many people from playing the game and I have not found a fix that works. I can recommend the game itself because it is a lot of fun, just not on PC due to myself and everyone I know having SERIOUS issues with the game.\n\nRAGE... while it is a well done game, it is hindered by game breaking technical issues that they have not fixed and the game came out quite some time ago. If you read through the forums, you will find that a big problem with the game is the way that it caches textures with higher end graphics cards. This causes extreme pop ins for textures that really ruins how good this game looks and destroys your frame rate. This only seems to be an issue with higher end graphics cards. I have experienced this issue on the following cards: Nvidia 280GTX (and two of these in SLI), Nvidia 560 GTX, Nvidia 560 Ti, and the Nvidia 660 Ti. Normally I wouldn't bash on a game for an issue like this but for it to be such a massive and common issue really ruins this game and I can't say I would recommend it to anyone with a higher end rig because of this. Now if you have a lower end rig (ran this without any issues on a Nvidia 8800 GTX), you may be able to run this game without any problems but unfortunately there are no guarantees. I cannot recommend anyone buy this unless they are willing to roll the dice with this broken game. I really hope id Software can step it up after losing John Carmack and fix this engine. Go play it on consoles if you are dying to play it, you can probably get the Anarchy Edition at your local Walmart or EB Games for $20 or less on PS3 or 360.

reviewText:
Difficulty: Easy
The Bottom Line: Just Plain Fun/Great
Score: 8.0

Note: This Game Been Tried Out And Reviewed In Offline Mode or On Another Steam Account And Or Consoles.

I remember hearing and waiting for this game back in '08,Yeah, that's how long I've been waiting for this game

The new engine is astounding. The textures are amazing,It is very nice to see a new engine and not some re-used or re-updated albeit old engine like Unreal 3.0

do not expect this game to be open-worlded in the same sense that Fallout 3 are, The world seems large but you are only confined to small and medium sized areas. As you play,but this game is mostly linear. Once you discover several towns, you can do fast travel

Overall: the game feels like playing a Mad Max movie with the elements of Borderlands, Fallout, and Some Metro 2033 elements. But that is not to say that any ideas were stolen or re-used for this game. Rage is its own kind of animal, it is unique and it's got plenty of peculiar style.The world is believable and immersive.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Gameplay wise I really enjoyed RAGE. Its a nice mix of solid shooter mechanics with racing thrown in. It mixes up the experience and keeps the game feeling interesting throughout. The gunplay really shines here. Standard fair weapons with some uniques, but each with unique ammo types and functions that feel very satisfying to use. The explosive shotgun shell rounds for instance, or the electric bolts for the crossbow to name a few. Gadgets like the wingstick are fun as well.

Combat is almost always in small corridors. Larger areas are mainly for travel or vehicle comat. Its not a bad thing but rarely will you ever do your fighting out in the wilds.

The racing aspect feels pretty decent. Its got some fun challenges and upgrading your car is fun as well. It mixes the pacing up which I enjoyed.

Graphics wise it has a uniuqe look. They use the mega texture technology to have no repeating tiling textures" and for a more unique look. It does look very good
date: but it it lacks in other areas such as dynamic lighting
hoursPlayed:
and high resolution textures. Still its got a very unique look compared to other games.

Now the game is not perfect at all. The story and characters are very poor. The story barely exists at all. Some HUD features are obviously from the console and the game could make much better use of PC options. Standard PC features like mouse smoothing and FOV have to be changed via console or autoexec.cfg files. Really sad in this day we still get this crap from devs.

Challenge is another problem. Im not an amazing gamer
voteText: but I played on hard and didnt have a hard time with anything except a couple encounters.\n\nStill in the end once you get your FOV and mouse set
helpfulPercent: and are playing the game its a great experience. Very fun simple good old fashion shooting with some racing to spice it up. Really recommend espicially now when its so cheap and is 5 bucks on sale every other month or so."

reviewText: You would think with such big names behind it as Bethesda, id Software, and Square Enix, this title would be well worth its playtime in cash; unfortunately this is not the case. While the game-play is about as fun as any other post apocalyptic sandbox and the art is certainly a drawing factor, it is simply not all that fun to play. It is surprising just how quickly I found myself getting annoyed at the go fetch this" quests and overall clunky mechanics behind some of the tasks. The challenge is not apparent on any difficulty and areas that are marked by NPCs warning of the dangers that lie ahead are little more than small scripted events where you fight a dozen enemies one at a time.\nThat is not to say this is a terribly made game though. It delivers a mad max kind of vibe that seems to be trying to pull off some off mix of Elder Scrolls: Oblivion mixed with Borderlands. Quests

reviewText:
Rage has some interesting parts, but the package as a whole is a mess. The color of the world is dreary but every NPC you meet is somewhat cheery and treats you like their best friend. While I love racing games and did not expect realistic vehicle behavior, Rage's MarioCart-like take is off the wall arcade. The power ups add more chaos to the racing that's already silly in comparison to the shooting. Even the shooting isn't all that good. The AI is interesting in that it seems to react to the situation, yet it's still dumb and easy to defeat. Bad missions, bad driving, and a setting that isn't coherent and reminds me that there are other similar games with much better story and tone.


There's probably a lot of games that have been and may be $5 on sale that I would take over Rage.

The Rocket Rally races are just random nonsense where there's no consequence for dying and bares no relation to the rest of the game.

I either end up playing whack-a-mole as enemies pop out from cover or just walk up to them with a shotgun when they are crouched. Mutants you just wait for them to run straight at you.

reviewText:
Do I recommend Rage?

Mother******* ninja wingstick's.
Grenades n' ****.
And for the Really Bad*** you have your firsts.
You can beat innocent psychopaths out in the desert to death with your fists.

11/10

reviewText:
I feel this game is very under-rated and under-appreciated. My first contact with this game was thanks to my local Game store where I picked this up second hand for only £4 (xbox 360) early last year. Within the first 5 minutes of playing I was completely absorbed and I fell in love hard. I've since had to re-purchase the game via Steam for another nostalgic playthrough and I don't regret it one bit.

The game is based in the future amongst a wasteland filled with survivors, mutants, monsters and patrol units, not to mention bandit cars. You play a character that has crashed down to the wasteland from an intelligent craft which pre-dates the war. The war that is, that turned the land into wasteland in the first place. With your andvanced Ark technology implants and a funky selection of arsenal, you play through to liberate the wasteland and help the survivors as best as you can. Shotgun, machine gun, cross bow, sniper rifle and grenade launcher are some of the weapons that the character can play with throughout the game. My personal favourite are 'boomsticks', a boomering shaped object with blades that can be thrown to cut through advancing enemy heads with the chance of the stick returning to you for another throw.

The story line and game start of very well but honestly I found the middle and ending not to live up to the first half. It was good, it was full of action but I just felt there should have been more, a bigger climax. Still I think it is well worth a play for any fps game fans. Plus it also has bonus games inside such as car racing (and fighting) plus gambling games ie cards, dice, roulette. Also has optional side missions.

reviewText:
This game left me a bit divided.

On the one hand there are :

- excellent graphics (game from 2011 gives my new pc plenty of work)
- cool apocalyptic world with bad gangs and good people trying to survive, kinda mad max
- big map with big levels
- diverse missions for main story but smaller side missions
- cool weapons, my favorite was the sniper rifle
- weapons have cool ammo, some make enemies explode :)
- vehicles which are upgradable by winning races
- car races
- mini games
- plenty of achievements
- sexy women
- much interaction with npc's

On the other hand:

- the finale was such a letdown, a cold shower, I was expecting a bit cutscene but got less than 1 minute ...
- some mini games are so hard that I just didn't end them, like the ones with the knife or banjo ...
- some achievements are very hard, getting all collector cards for one, I got 53 out of 54, thanks a lot now I have to restart this game ...

All considered I had 24 hours of full gameplay. I recommend it although probably everybody finished the game already cause it's from 2011 :)

reviewText:
I really, really wanted to love this game but instead I could only like it.

Post apocalyptic shooting with vehicles and open world elements from the people that made Quake, sounds fantastic right? That's until you actually start playing. You're dropping into the world with the barest amount of exposition and rescued by John Goodman who within five minutes of meeting you, gives you a gun and asks you to wipe out a gang. Vehicles don't exist beyond mini-games and the odd moments where you need to traverse relatively short distances to mission dungeons."

You ultimately join the rag tag group known as "The Resistance" who fights against the tyrannical "Authority" (honestly guys
date: hire a writer and come up with better names) in the most cliched manner possible. The game does have it's standouts. The gunplay feels good
recommended:
the animation is excellent and blowing up other cars is enjoyable. The characters are very well constructed and they make you want to just sit and talk with them but instead are used as one-shot interactions. John Goodman's character disappears after the first hour of the game.

The game was unfortunately not everything I wanted it to be but it was still an enjoyable experience.
Get it for $5 if you have a rainy weekend."

reviewText:
I Bought RAGE on it's release day because id Software. I'm still a fan of theirs after over 20 years. Don't know why exactly all the time, but yet I am.

I was somewhat disappointed with RAGE. Sure, it looks nice at times, but for all the hype and fervor preceding the launch, it was a rather big let down on the overall gaming experience.

If you are a fan of id Software's games, I do recommend RAGE. It's not a greatest game out there, but it has it's moments. If, on the other hand you are short of time and crave for some truly great entertainment, there are better options.

Pros:
- The action, at times
- The idea and potential for the story
- Pretty post apocalyptic scenery and semi-comic imagery

Cons:
- The, oh, so very static world. Not a cloud moves in the sky.
- Race grinding.
- Was there a main story? I can't remember. If there was, it was really unremarkable and bland. (Oh, wait, I am mistaken. I do remember the story. It really is unremarkable and bland.)
- The sounds and overall feeling of the weapons. Since the Doom 3 failure, why cannot they get those right? (This is a minor issue though.)

reviewText: A game with a bipolar mix of great ideas and some pretty heavy misses. I'll start off with the good, get into the mixed, then get into the bad. Overall, though, I think it's a great game.\n\nSo, the game starts off with a pretty epic cinematic of an asteroid hitting earth. You are one of the chosen few to be put into a life-sustaining pod of sorts to be released when it's safe to live again. How lucky! Everyone else in the pod died. Not lucky. In the meantime, civilization has adapted to a post-apocalyptic scenario by survivng in small pockets of the wasteland. Some people mutated, others formed gangs, and others complain about the authority" being a general pain in the ♥♥♥. Really

reviewText:
Now, i just want to start out by saying, the PC port in this game is awful, if you have a console, you should get it there, but if texture rippling doesn't bother you, than let's get started.

Rage is a very great breath of fresh air for FPS games, It blends in nice open levels inside the overall world design of the game. You can have up to 4 weapons equipped at times, and they all feel powerful and immensely satisfying, They have complex recoil movements and different weapons are used for different situation. It's FPS aspect is fun, frantic, and intense, though you will be finding yourself covering behind objects a bit too frequently.

The Graphics are very well done, the objects and everything looks good in the game, but you may need some help from mods to get rid of the texture rippling.

The story is the weakest point of this game, as you play the game, it is backed up by either way too generic characters, or promising ones that you barely get any dialogue from. Even though the world is somewhat decent in size and filled with crowds. It felt rushed and unfinished, and put together at the last second.

But, the game is good overall, i never usually put scores on games, but since this review is a bit crazy, i would give it a 7.75/10

reviewText: Surprisingly brief. It is a great shooter/racer with alot of little mini games you can have fun with from the battle card game you can play to the hand knife roulette type game all the way to the simple guitar memory game. I found crafting and the battle areas also to be quite fun. Ok now for the down side, The game was buggy as hell when I first picked it up but it got less buggy after some graphics card driver updates. I never once met the mysterious general running the bad guys, The last battle was also more of a gauntlet with no actual boss fight to speak of. Kinda left me surprised and disappointed. It actually felt like the game lost funding and so they just ended it with a happy ending cut scene. Do I recommend it? Yes but know what you are getting into and try to get it on sell. Right now it is 4.99 on the summer steam sale and that is a good price for it. Enjoy it while you can and make it drag out as much as you can but it will end. If you want a better game, get Borderlands (any of them), won;t be as visually impressive but will be more fun and complete and less buggy.

reviewText: Despite the hugely anti-climatic ending that WILL leave you disappointed, Rage is a very under appreciated game, that got a lot of hate due to its crappy PC port on release. Most of the problems it had were fixed, but it still feels like a console game. And playing on PC, that is unacceptable.\nIf you're able to get past the graphical issues, Rage is a very well made game. Think of Borderlands but without the RPG stuff: that is Rage. At first it may seem like an average game, but as you play it you'll discover that it's a lot of fun and it has a strange charm that will hook you up before you know it. I can't tell where that charm comes from, because thinking back, it's not better than similar games like the mentioned Borderlands, but it's still fun, which is what matters when playing a game.\nSure, it's rough around the edges, not for perfectionists, but if you play a game to enjoy it, trust me, you will like this game. Also, if you have the chance, get the Scorchers DLC, it makes the game better and adds content to the endgame, which the original was missing.

reviewText:
Having played 690 plus hours of this game (so far) confirms my total commitment to another brilliant production from the id people.

The fact that you can enjoy not only different difficulty levels but also vary your playing direction every time you start a new game is a bonus. Yes, you must follow the given format to complete tasks and levels but they also can be varied in actual excecution (You don't have to do what you are asked or told to do in the order given). Plus you can upgrade and vary upgrade choices as you go which is made much easier once you establish the best way to make money quickly to make purchases.

For 'Hints' and 'Bonus' material please refer to my guides section for this game to learn more. There is quite a deal of information there that will assist with gameplay and the acquisition of money required to purchase upgrades.

In short 'Rage' is a great game that can be left alone for a while and comfortably returned to at a later date and played again and again.

Great graphics, good story line and flexible playability. Extra DLC's would be great to expand this game as it lends itself to more missions.

First time through took some 30 - 40 Hrs and this will vary depending on how much or how little you feel you want to do. The game is extremely flexible and I would rate it 9/10.

I have uploaded many screenshots that will giva an indication of what to expect.

Have fun.

reviewText:
RAGE:
RAGE is a game in a post - apocalyptic world, or if you rather, the Wasteland.
This is a game that includes looting (Ammunition, collectives and such) and a big arsenal of weapons that allows you to choose how to kill your enemys in serval different ways.
One more cool thing this game have, is CARS, YES! On the campaign you get cars that you can ride in them trough the Wasteland and use them to crash\shot\explode your enemys, or just use them for racing and such.
Beside the main missions, which are awesome by the way.... There are also alot of cool side missions that can either give you money or either grow your arsenal if you complete them. The gameplay is so fun, I have to say. Its very smooth and easy to control. And now about the soundtrack, its also OK... They really fitted in the music to the location and the environment you're playing on, the characters, the weapons and the cars soundtrack.. This game is really fun and its awesome!!
Highly recommended!

reviewText:
Solid FPS with some nice Open-world and RPG elements.

Don't expect too much from the story. Even though the whole post-apocalyptic universe this game is set in seems very authentic and well done, there could've been done so much more in order to make the story more compelling. There are a great amount of interesting characters, both enemies and allies, which add to the atmosphere.

The gunplay overall is not on the level of Killing Floor 2 for example but above average nontheless. The guns handle well, the sounds are realistic and shooting feels satisfying. Different types of ammunition help spice things up especially later on in the game.

Throughout the game, RAGE wants you to believe it's an open world shooter. Between quests, it does a relatively good job at it. During missions, however, there are a LOT of invisible walls which can get annoying at times. Most missions consist of going into a cave/dungeon/city/building and pick something up/deliver something etc. and then go back to the quest giver. The levels are generally linear but well designed. You don't have to run back the way you came which prevents the player from losing attention quickly. There are not a lot of areas that I felt like I want to get out of immediately.

If you're planning on playing RAGE on hard difficulty, I wouldn't bother. All they did was turn the enemies into bullet sponges. It doesn't necessarily make the game harder, but you just end up wasting a lot more ammo and it just doesn't feel right to see a bandit without any heavy armor take a couple dozen bullets before eventually dying.


Overall, I didn't feel like quitting the game at any point, the game kept me interested enough to play it for about 13 hours. If you're into games like Fallout or the Metro series this might just be something you should consider picking up.

reviewText:
-Description-
Story:
The asteroid called 99942 Apophis is on a collision course for Earth and it will hit the planet at August 23, 2029, destroying civilization as we know it. The only hope for humanity to survive this event is to burrow down to ground with these Arks and submerge when the Earth is habitable again.
You are one of those survivors who were selected to enter one of the Arks. You submerge from the ground in the year 2135, only to notice that all your fellow Ark colleagues to be dead from the Ark malfunction and that the Earth has become a savage place, filled with raiders, mutants and things that has a dendency to kill you.

The main story is somewhat average. It starts very strongly and keeps you in its grasp, but the ending was a little disappointment and anti-climatic for me. Not only that, but the ending also had a huge cliffhanger.

Gameplay:
The game is somewhat similar to the Borderline series, mixed with some Fallout's apocalyptic atmosphere. You can scavenge the world for items, which you can then use to build different items, depending what recipes you've discovered.
The game has main quest line which you can follow, but there are also several side quests, which offers you money that you can then spend at vendors for items and car parts.


Pros:
+ Apocalyptic world and locations
+ Infranty and vehicle mechanics
+ Vendor system
+ Crafting system
+ Interesting characters
+ Strong story, but...

Cons:
- ...Anti-climatic and gliffhanger ending
- Main story is kinda short
- Lack of character progression
- Stealth gameplay could have been better
- Not as challenging as I would have hoped

Do I recommend?
Yes. It has it's shortcomings, but if you enjoy playing apocalytic games, you'll probably enjoy this one too.

Verdict: 8 / 10 - Good game
( 1 = do-not-bother game
5 = average game
10 = must own game)

reviewText: Rage is the last FPS developed by id software, the mother of the genre. Combining few RPG elements with free roam and vehicle races, the gameplay is somehow unique. The FPS mechanics are well crafted and gun feel is really good, while races and short travels only represent a break from linear levels, adding some poliedricity wich never results boring. Enemies movements will test your shooting skills, like few games do, and crafting system will need your creativity to choose the right strategy for every fight. Even if the abientation is immersive, the plot is however poor, expecially in the end, making Rage a good game but definitely not a masterpiece.\n\n85/100

reviewText: id Software has written several pages of videogame history, creating the archetypal '90s shooter with Doom and bringing the third dimension to gaming with Quake. John Carmack and John Romero have created such legacy for themselves that their promises and opinions are to be taken seriously today, even after all the years that have passed since they went their separate ways. So when John Carmack lets it be known that he is about to deliver a shot heard round the world it is quite understandably taken as an accurate description of future events.\n\nRAGE is known to most gamers rather from the circumstances surrounding it than the actual game itself. To call the pre-release buzz a hype is a true understatement. Many believed the hype only to be disillusioned on release, with is this it?" being the collective response. And as history has shown
date: the reaction was justified since RAGE came and went without impacting much of anything
recommended: let alone becoming legend. Now that the circumstances have changed a quiet appreciation has grown around the game as it it taken for what it is and not what it's creators meant it to be.\n\nThe world has ended and the player character awakens to a wasteland
hoursPlayed: as is custom
voteText: and meets the people and the factions that have survived or emerged in the meanwhile. Unfortunately there is no imagination or surprise involved in any of this. There are The Raiders
helpfulPercent: The Authority (!) and The Resistance as well as The Mutants and finally the common folk. Everything is so generic and lifeless that the names in capital letters are also the only description required. Even more unsettling is listening to the NPCs talk. An abstract
votesHelpful: Lydia-like cheer has descended on the survivors and not a single line of dialogue sounds like actual speech. A vendor says "All my stuff is A-one premo" in an attempt to simulate humanity with literally everything else being poorly disguised information about the game mechanics involved. Fortunately the protagonist is just as wordless as Gordon Freeman or the Doom Marine before him so there are no attempts at drama. The main story is so straightforward I am hesitant to call it a story and all the characters are merely their occupations. There are no themes introduced or points made. And although many many women dress extremely impractically to say the least there is absolutely no romance or sex anywhere
votesTotal: not even married couples among the NPCs. All the writing involved in RAGE is words
votesFunny: nothing more
commentsCount: and my mood always soured when I had to stop playing the game and listen to the people in it.\n\nWhat makes the world of RAGE even more unwelcoming are the excruciatingly slow and dull opening hours. There are so few places to go
column16: weapons and tools to use and things to do that it takes some self-discipline to soldier on. This is undoubtedly where the synthetic if not downright artificial nature of the world shows its very worst. Fortunately the first day of gaming is misleading: as the world in which you can wander in gets bigger the game gets better as well. The farther away I proceeded from settled areas the more I enjoyed myself. The levels are highly linear but well-designed and even the typical ruins and bunkers are interesting to explore. I was most impressed by the ruins of a great city that felt like nothing had been spoken in them for decades. Exploring these streets was the equal of any other post-human gaming experience and conveyed more meaning than any amount of words could have done.\n\nWhile all the characters are just happy automatons they were at the least well-made automatons and much thought has clearly gone into them
column17: despite well-known influences showing here and there. The animations were exemplary in many cases
column18: especially those of the melee chargers found on many levels. Mutants charge forward in berserk parkour and should they get decapitated they keep running for a few more paces until realising that they have died not a moment before.\n\nThe gameplay in RAGE is the traditional first person shooting seen many times before and since. It is made enjoyable by the large variety of weapons and quick-use items as well as the enemy behaviour. Only those equipped for close combat will charge forward
column19: while those with firearms shoot from behind cover and finally retreat and regroup at the next defensive position with fresh troops coming in as well. Enemies will also get visibly injured and hobble around in pain or shoot from a sitting or lying position in their last moments. Doing this to the bad guys requires of course appropriate tools and RAGE delivers. There is a large arsenal and while it mostly consists of time-tested pistols
column20: assault rifles and shotguns they universally look
column21: sound and feel good in use. The basic ammunition types are nothing compared to the specialist ones you need to craft or buy at a high price. My personal favorite was the crossbow with four different types of bolts. One of these variants was a mind control crossbow bolt which lets an enemy to be walked to his comrades in remote control to be then exploded by a button press. This is one of the best But Of Course weapons in recent memory and there is undeniable glee in using it. The craftable quick-use items are even better and I was able to use most of them at a constant rate which is to say I appreciated the system very much. The first one accessed is the Wingstick
column22: a throwable weapon looking something like a cross between ceiling fan and huge shuriken. It has limited guidance in flight and will return to the source to be used again later. Decapitating a charging mutant with one and retrieving the implement gave me a self-esteem boost against my better judgement.\n\nControls felt natural and all the menu systems were ideally clear and informative. It is most unfortunate how blurred things can look on close inspection
column23: especially the clutter items. RAGE looks great in motion
column24: however
column25: and my game was a stable one as well. There is a command console and mod support for the technologically skilled. I used a keybind to hide my HUD and weapon to take screens as my only modification. A full third of my 300+ screens are from my RAGE playthrough which is certainly a testament to my gaming experience as a statistic alone.\n\nRAGE has one major DLC
column26: The Scorchers
column27: which merits a separate mention. It plays to the strenghts of the base game
column28: with spectacular level design and highly intense gunfights. The story is kept to the bare minimum
column29: thankfully
column30: and the missions are well integrated on the main campaign. The weapon added is also one of the very best available
column31: useful but well-balanced and with three distinct forms. The titular Scorchers also feature some of the most amusing battle chatter available and must be quoted here. Melee berserkers tell you that they love you during their charge and shooters remind themselves of their "Happy place!" when wounded. Should a comrade fall the survivors exclaim in sorrow "We lost what's-his-name!" and remark how the player needs more therapy. All in all The Scorchers is a highly polished addition to RAGE
column32: equaling the finer levels in the base game and even surpassing them in places.\n\nRAGE is one of those games that feel better out of context. It did not change the course of game design and will not give gamers reason to reinterpret the enjoyable hobby in question. But it is beyond any doubt a well-made shooter experience
column33: carrying on certain traditions and expanding on others
column34: all the while being an imaginary world well worth the visit if only for the places alone."

So the game is good, one of my favourites. It's pretty much a shooter with some very basic RPG elements like crafting and items, not to say this is an RPG in any way though.
