Overall I recommend it as I'm a sucker for post-apocalyptic and sci-fi worlds and this has it both.

reviewText:
RAGE sets you in a ravaged wasteland world that is home to mutants, bandits and the Authority which all want a piece of you or should I say, a nice chunk of you. The wasteland environment looks gorgeous both in the way it has been designed and the graphics itself which easily helps with emersion. There are perhaps a few iffy textures when it comes to some of the interior levels, but if you can look past that and enjoy the wasteland, it's easily cancelled out. The character models and weaponary also look fantastic.

Apart from the main story, the game offers some decent side missions, events and numerous amounts of things to collect. Schematics, recipies (these allow you to craft various things as long as you have parts), collectables, mini games, stunt jumps throughout the wasteland and of course, racing events where you can earn racing certificates to be used in upgrading your vehicles. There are also various ammo types you can use with your weapons.

There's a few co-op missions you can do with one friend or a random. They're fun, but unfortunately a little short. There's also multiplayer by way of racing, but as to be expected, the multiplayer portion has fizzled out.

The ending could be viewed as somewhat disappointing in the fact that it's left rather open and perhaps there could have been some stronger emphasis on the story, but all small negatives considered, the gameplay is solid, the graphics fantastic and there's plenty to keep you busy with for quite some hours. Having played three playthroughs of RAGE on Normal, Nightmare and Ultra Nightmare, I can say I thoroughly enjoyed the game each time.

reviewText:
I remember hearing and waiting for this game back in '08. I actually remember them announcing that Rage would be coming out sometime in April, 2009. Yeah, that's how long I've been waiting for this game. Long and behold, it's finally here.

For those who didn't know, this game occupies 3 DVDs. That's right, the game weights 21 GB. Well, at least Sony's Blu-Ray format doesn't have that problem. I am also extremely glad that the developers didn't trim down the game so it could fit on one DVD (you know, if it can fit on one DVD for the Xbox, then it can fit anywhere, kind of like what happened with the trimming down of the GTA 4 world map because of the DVD format.)

Anyways, the new engine is astounding. The textures are amazing, especially the faraway ones. I get a stable 60 FPS with my Fermi, 8 GB Ram and 2.93 icore. It is very nice to see a new engine and not some re-used or re-updated albeit old inherently engine like Unreal 3.0.

However, do not expect this game to be open-worlded in the same sense that Fallout 3 and New Vegas are. The world seems large but you are only confined to small and medium sized areas. As you play, more of these areas become available and you can go back if you want to, but this game is mostly linear when it comes to navigating the world itself.

There is not enough exploration to go around but I absolutely love the environments - none of the environments repeat. I love the abandoned buildings, hotels, sewers, back alleys and such. It is something that I always wanted to experience in the last two Fallout games but couldn't because of the lack of the said environments, because of the recycled areas with the same textures and objects and because of the outdated engine. This time however I can't stop taking snapshots via Fraps and Steam.

There are several types of enemies. Some of the punks however speak with a British accent and have British flag tattoos, but most of them look the same (a homage to Mad Max and Doomsday (2008) perhaps?). There are some other medium and large-sized mutants.

I like the fact that there are several vehicles and that you can customize them. There are also several ammo types for each weapon, however all I really ask for is for head shot to equal instant death, which is not the case in this game unless you use a shotgun up close.

You can also create some new items that will help you advance in the game as well as access some closed off areas so do not hurry to sell every junk you find because you might need it.

As far as the weapons are concerned, well I'd say that most of them get readily available within the first few quests, so you do not really have to work hard to get them. Plus the ammo is not that scarce for some reason, so do not expect any Metro 2033-kind lack of ammo. Also, half of the weapons look like they were taken from Crysis. I would also expect some weapons to be home-made.

There' s no way to skip the occasional cut scenes or hurry up the monologue, BUT if you take a few steps away from the person giving you the quest, then the quest becomes readily available without you having to hear the whole story.

The enemy AI is good. They dodge bullets, take cover, retreat, advance and throw grenades - everything that you really need. It is also satisfying to blast some of the melee-wielding enemies. They don't always rush at you either, they actually try to surround you.

This brings me to another point. The gameplay itself is what truly shines in this game. The fire fights and the shooting just do not get old. It is extremely satisfying to fight the hordes of mutants. You can craft sentry turrets and sentry bots(like in Doom 3) to help you out. You can also craft various types of special ammo, and since there's no weight limit, there's little reason to sell junk that can be used to construct the dozen or so different things.

When you die, the nanomachines that were implanted in you moments before the asteroid collision and the subsequent hypersleep serve as a defibrillator. Meaning if you die, you can revive yourself once or twice before the defibrillator recharges. There's a tiny minigame involved that determined how much health you get once you are revived. And by health I mean how red your screen is before it turns normal since the game has regenerative health.

The characters you encounter are all unique. They all have different clothes, voices and personalities. Some give you new quests, some just do small chit-chat. The secondary characters even have names.

There are some easter eggs scattered around including a few that pay respect to Fallout, like the bobble head and the water purifier chip.

The minuses:

Let's get this out of the way: You can't see your legs and you cast no shadow.

Oh, and you are also mute. All you can do is listen.

I like the fact that you do not have any maps or minimaps when you enter new unknown areas ( I don't like excessive HUD), but friendly towns could use some indicators because it causes some confusion when you enter a new friendly place and are trying to navigate between the newly introduced characters and quests.

When you drive a vehicle you get a third person view, however you cannot look around or behind you which really constricts your view.

The sky looks amazing although it is static. It's like a giant wall paper.

The dead bodies disappear quickly, but at least they won't do so unless you loot them. So if you want to increase realism, do not loot the bodies.

I don't think I've encountered a single checkpoint or an auto-save. That's right, your entire progress depends on your manual F5 saves, what's more is that every time you save, it takes 4 seconds for the screen to unfreeze. Annoying but necessary. So if you forget to save and die, you will have to repeat your last progress from your last save.

The game is also extremely easy. I'm playing on the hardest (Nightmare) mode and I steam roll over everyone and everything. The quick regenerating health is part of the issue.

The most important thing is the lack of a good and consistent story. This game nailed almost everything but the main story. You wake up from cryosleep and you get thrown into the semi-open world of fetch quests. For some reason people around you assume that you are a killing machine who is able to take out hordes of enemies and fetch supplies. No one ever explains why you should be doing the things you are doing. One might think that there is no need for one coherent story in the huge 21 GB single player post-apocalyptic world but I beg to differ since this is not an open-world game. You cannot bypass quests and go wherever you want, there ARE constrictions.

Overall, the game feels like playing a Mad Max movie with the elements of Borderlands, Fallout, and Some Metro 2033 elements. But that is not to say that any ideas were stolen or re-used for this game. Rage is its own kind of animal, it is unique and it's got plenty of peculiar style. The world is believable and immersive. And the game itself gets better and better as you play it.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Rage is a fantastic game with an interesting story line, the intro towards the game is brilliant and makes the game moving and interesting to play on to find what happens.

The game does have bad points but also bring good points, my bad points towards the game is, it’s too short, you will spend around 8 hours on the game and you’ll complete it, if you do the side quests and try for 100% completion, it may take up to 15 hours. When you get into your first town area, it’s hard to find your way around the area and can take up time, me personally I don’t want to get lost and waste time trying to find a place where I need to be. However in the towns, you have a lot of stuff to do, such as go to the merchants and buy ammo, items for building items and also you can play mini games to earn extra money in the game. They is also a race events that you can attend to which gives something extra to do in the game and something to complete.The ending of the game seems dull and could have been better and could tell more information on what happened.

The graphics towards the game is amazing with a lot of details towards the scenes with shooting and driving around in the care.

The mechanics of the game for me personally were hard to get used, but eventually I got used to them, they even easier with a controller. Driving is fluid, walking is fluid and both seem realistic.
The game reminds me of Borderlands and a slight hint of Fallout, with rage having it’s own elements towards the game.

I am happy with buying this product and would recommend this to anyone who enjoys shooters with a different atmosphere.

reviewText:
The game is pretty fun. The shooting is awesome, the variety in weapons is neat, and the enemies are apocalyptically crazy! For whatever reason, I had the profound thought when I first started this game that the shooting just felt really good. It felt comfortable and just great in general, beyond what other games have done.

The driving works well enough, and blowing up enemy cars is always awesome, but there's just a little something missing that keeps it from being great. It was neat to get to use my apocalyptic car to race others, it was a good change of pace sometimes from blasting psychos and mutants. I enjoyed that I could customize my car up a bit, adding upgrades and changing out weapons and such.

The world is kind of open, but not in the way The Elder Scrolls or Fallout or Far Cry are, it feels much more linear than that. The places where you can drive feel open but like there are only certain paths to take. Each area you explore on foot has some room for a little side exploration to discover hidden stuff, but it doesn't have the same sense of adventuring as other games do. You can do whatever you want, but there isn't much more to do than shoot up your enemies.

To make up for what I'm going to say next a bit, the game does have a unique storyline, interesting characters, and the graphics are really beautiful. It was interesting listening to the voices of all the variety of characters, they had neat dialogue and were voiced well. Unfortunately, even though the characters were neat, the game just couldn't make you care less about what was going on, why you were doing what you were doing, or make you want to care about any of the characters. The storyline is unique, but it wasn't done well enough that it gripped you.

Overall, it's a fun game and definitely worth your time, but there is definitely potential for so much more. I'd love to see another game in this franchise.

reviewText: The Scorchers DLC opens up a new series of missions that start in the Northern Wasteland, inside Hagar Territory, where you headed first in the original game. Don’t worry, if you’ve already finished the main story in Rage, this DLC also brings in a new feature that allows you to continue to explore the Wasteland after you’ve completed the main campaign.\n\nWhen you load up your game you’ll be given a mission that asks you to investigate a new gang of bandits called The Scorchers. As you investigate this new threat you’ll meet up with new allies, gain access to new weapons and visit new locations. The great thing about The Scorchers is that the missions integrate into the main game, and the new areas all branch off existing areas in the game. You’ll still be able to visit the same shops, and talk to the same people, in between each part of the Scorchers mission.

reviewText:
This game was...underwhelming, especially after hearing people compare it to Fallout. It feels like started out like a great game, but the developers got bored with it.  Rage plays alot like borderlands, but without the fun of co-op, building a skill tree through level progression, or finding better/interesting weapons.

-The vehicle combat in the game is pretty stagnant and just ends up feeling like a chore when driving from place to place.

+There's some content to explore outside the main story; a handful of sidequests/jobs and mini-games that might keep you busy for a little while, but have no real impact on the game.

+The combat can be chaotic fun, the game offers a variety of ways to kill baddies.  There are a handful of interesting boss fights.  Some environments can be used to your advantage to surprise enemies with fire, electricity, spinning blades, etc.  There's no way that's really significantly better than the others at dispatching enemies, however it can be fun to use these things in combination.  My personal favorite toy in the game was the sentry bot.  The only disappointing part to combat was that it was too easy.  I played through the game on normal and NEVER used a healing item because your health regenerates quite quickly.  And if you do die, your character has a built in defibrillator that will instantly revive you (as well as killing surrounding enemies).  So I would highly recommend playing on a harder difficulty setting.

-If you're looking for a good story, this is NOT the game for you.  Where the environments are interesting and varied; the story is very vague and un-engaging; it merely exists as a medium so the game can pit you against seemingly endless waves of enemies.  The ending of the game is by far the most disappointing aspect of the game. (Minor SPOILER ALERT:  there is no final boss, just a few waves of easy enemies.)  The game ends just as the story is getting started.  You have no real choices or impacts upon the world.  Your experience through the game will be the exact same as everyone else, which is why I'm not recommending the game.  I paid $5 for this game on a sale, and I wouldn't advise you to spend a penny more than that on it.

Overall, this game puts the player through a fun filled adventure with amazing graphics and awesome gunfights!

reviewText:
4 year later does Rage still holds up?

Well i am happy to say that it surprisingly aged well.
A mess up hybrid (that combine FPS Gameplay with 3rd Person Fast paced driving mechanics) from the minds of ID software.

Driving in rage work like you'd expect Fast Paced,Total Destruction Comparable to Twisted Metal.
The A.I. is challenging and at moments unpredictable especially the mutants are insane.

Were Rage fails it's at being a good Pc Port It's unoptimised.
It took me 4 year to Finish it (Because of the lack of support by AMD and there drivers) on Pc with a stable Frame Rate.
I had to do my first run on Ps3 (Console version are awesome)
And let's not talk about the Horrible multiplayer components of Rage

At the end of the day i should not recomend Rage on Pc but Rage is an Excellent Game that should not be missed

8.7/10 Verdict: Buy this classic Hybrid when it's 75% off on a Steam Sale.

Ps: If you can run it then great and if you cannot run it but you need to play it then ask for steam refund and buy the Xbox 360 or Ps3 version of Rage

reviewText:
Careful before buying: the game doesn't use steam cloud it only saves locally so back up your saves with Gamesavemanager.

This is unimpressive compared to masterpieces from id like Doom and Quake 1-3 mainly because those games redefined and changed everything, but it still has it's merits. To id's credit it is a creative game that has solid, smooth combat and great weapons and enemies, one of the smoothest running engines I've ever played, and also great sound effects. It has great graphics (besides the god awful mushed textures up close) and very nice presentation value and is a lot of fun to play. The combat is really very good, top notch. One big thing that makes combat so awesome is that all weapons sound very good. The weapons sound loud and hard hitting, especially when I blow a guy into outerspace with a point blank shotgun blast and it kabooms in my ears through my headphones.

id software worked with Bethesda so Bethesda had some say in it and probably nudged them towards making it a wasteland game like Fallout 3 since it was so wildly popular at the time. That's OK, but I miss the evil satanic neo-gothic stuff from Doom and Quake. It also has a horrible last boss and ending. You do many things and craft and quest and so on, then the game just ends. But id knew they ♥♥♥♥ed that up and there's an expansion that lets you play even after the final boss.
This game was an experiment for id to showcase their new engine which is incredible, as I said one of the smoothest game engines I've ever seen. It performs flawlessly. Although the graphics are beyond horrible in some areas, like ground and stationary surface textures. Just a blurry mess. Actually you know what, the graphics in this game just suck balls, period. Fantastic art direction, suck balls graphics quality. Oh and if there is one thing that id absolutely cannot do, it is racing. The racing parts in this game just ♥♥♥♥ing suck and are horribly sleep inducing. Also, the mouse pointer in game menu's, all of them, never feels right. It just doesn't move normally, but loose and crappy.
Despite the games numerous merits, it doesn't live up to id's standards when you compare it to Doom and Quake 1-3. It was like they said we are going to create a good game even if it kills us" and to their credit
recommended: but therein lies the argument that prevented this from being their next mega-hit. But RAGE holds it's own for what its worth: a wasteland FPS with very solid mechanics
hoursPlayed: a phenominal game engine besides the suck balls graphics
voteText: and not much else to complain about other than id's standardized approach to it's production quality.\nLets just hope that John Carmack didn't leave id software because this game and future projects are what their production mentality is starting to curve towards. Let's hope that we actually see them bring back the magic when they put out Doom 4.\n7.5/10"

reviewText:
Thanks to Steam's free-to-play weekend I gave RAGE a jam, what first drew me to download and play it was Snoop Dogg, RAGE is Snoops favourite game.
I was a little reluctant at first because as a gamer I can become easily addicted to chasing achievements and didn’t want to delve into yet another post apocalyptic FPS, but RAGE is seeming more like a diamond in the rough.

RAGE is a FPS developed by id Software. It uses the company's OpenGL-based id Tech 5 game engine and was released in October 2011.
The game is set in a post-apocalyptic near future, following the impact of the asteroid 99942 Apophis on Earth. The game has been described as similar to the movie Mad Max 2 and to video games such as  Borderlands.
The mixture of FPS shoot and loot based missions and demolition derby type racing is just enough to be entertaining, if you get board of the same go to point [A] and kill random bandits to recover some junk missions you can enter a race, zoom round a circuit and bash and crash your way across the finish line to earn more upgrades.

In RAGE's story, the asteroid 99942 Apophis impacts the Earth on August 23, 2029, leaving few survivors. Human survivors have come together to form settlements around oases and other practical or habitable locations, including race tracks. These fragile homes are diligently defended by the inhabitants against bandits and mutants, which are divided into various gangs and organizations of their own.

RAGE has two multiplayer modes: Road Rage" and "Wasteland Legends". In Road Rage
date: up to four players compete in a free-for-all match that takes place in an arena designed to make use of the vehicles. The objective is to collect rally points that appear around the arena while killing your opponents and stealing their points. Legends of the Wasteland is a series of two-player co-op missions based on stories that are heard throughout the single-player campaign.\n\nSo aside from the basic gameplay and plot overview my personal opinion on rage is to give it a go
recommended: even just a few casual missions and there are fun or get right into the game and get all those delicious achievements.\nIf you find yourself really getting into the RAGE universe
hoursPlayed: Bethesda and Dark Horse Comics announced a three-issue comic book series based on RAGE
voteText: also there is an entire novel based on RAGE game.\n\nEnjoy killing bandits and making the roads a safer place

reviewText: RAGE is one of the first open world games i've actually enjoyed, while all the others mainly consist of travelling miles to an area then killing a few enemies, RAGE keeps travelling to a minimum and puts most emphasis into its amazing combat. Every shot feels powerful, as every bullet sends your target stumbling and limping. The first person combat sections are usually set in corridored levels full of enemies to mow down, making it a blend of Borderlands 2 (the driving, setting and open world) and Quake 4 (the frantic action set in the fairly common linear area). I recommend this to anybody who likes FPS and open world games.

reviewText:
RAGE is an FPS made by the legendary ID software, responsible for Doom and Quake. This is their latest game, and while people say it's awful, it's only because ID made it, and the expectations were unreasonably high. This game feels like a watered down Borderlands, with the exploring and shooting fun. Not too much stuff to do, but the game is at a short, good length. I would say 10-15 hours should take care of it.

The game plays like an ordinary FPS, running through places, shooting things. the game takes place in two separate hub locations, which branch off into different areas. The shooting is great, but the exploration is lacking. There really isn't much stuff to look at, making any collectibles and stuff pointless. The base game is quite enjoyable. It's just a normal shooter in a semi open world, don't expect anything more. There is a lot of racing sequences and driving, so be prepared to do some races and car combat if you want to get anywhere in this game.

The multiplayer.....uhh.. The co-op missions are quite fun, but there's only a few of them to do. The road rage multiplayer is passable, and it's basically a ripoff of Twisted Metal.

This game is beautiful, but suffers pop-in textures. Luckily, no matter how good your computer is, it should run very well. I have a terrible computer and I was able to run it in 60 FPS. This game is excellent, but don't set your expectations too high, because RAGE can only jump so high.

reviewText:
This game have all the necessary potentials it needs to become a perfect game, but it fails to make a final touch to it.

RAGE is an open-world, rogue-like fighting game similar to BORDERLAND but with quality graphic. The game concept and art is well made, and the progression of the storyline is indeed very unique and interesting.

But what could have been a perfect game falls short when the plot of the game suddenly came to a sudden end that leaves all loose end... well, loose! It is a very anticlimactic, and it just leaves me blank when the game suddenly rolled to the ending credit.

As I mentioned before, this game already have all the necessary components ready, but failed to utilize the ultimate ending that would make this game into a perfect piece.

The gameplay time is significantly short.

Nevertheless, this is still a great game to play, and very enjoyable while it last until the plot ended.

I would rated it 8/10, where the -2 is deducted from the loose end plot

reviewText: One of the best FPS experiences I've had in the past decade. It's kind of shooter I was looking for since the original DOOM and Duke Nukem 3D. Relatively short shooting sections go after even shorter story scenes with questing and a bit of a post apocalyptic world exlploration. And the game benefits from that approach. Most redundant features were cut off. Guns look amazing, sound beautiful and interact with enemies and environment so well that after a few minutes I found myself switching weapons only to look at how another goon would die from my beloved 45 caliber compared to the shotgun. It's fun, it's oldschool and it's that rare sort of John Carmack-style games that he doesn't make anymore. So this game is definitely worth checking out.

reviewText:
It isn't a bad game perhaps I was expecting much!!

I have played through the whole game in 28.7 hours, completed each and every side quests (left a few), but after 28.7 hours of my life that I devoted to this game in hope of getting something, i was left with an empty stomache and with a bad taste in my mouth.

Rage is a fully open world game, which involves sweet elements like the old school arcade type racing & fast paced combat. At first when I started, the opening sequence blew me away, the graphics looked sharp, art design and every graphical fidelity was top notch. I could see vast landscapes, people, bandits running around in their buggeys and all sort of ♥♥♥♥ and It made me super hyped up that I want to explore every bit of it. However that soon came to an end.

Pros
The game looks stunning considering the fact that it came out 4 years ago. It does an awesome job of introducing new combat mechanics and enemy types. This isn't just an open world fps game, it also involves old school arcade style racing, something that reminded me of some of the classics I palyed back when I was small. This game might not have tonnes of guns but holy ♥♥♥♥!! it has tonnes of different bullets!! (Yup! you heard me......Bullets!!). Each enemy type requires you to switch ammunition type. Heavy bullets for heavily armored, insanely heavy bullets for insanely armored. This requires you to plan ahead before infiltrating a bandit camp, stocking up on ammo, best suited for that faction and resources. The game has a good variety and amount of enemy types that it will throw at you to keep things interesting. Weapons are awesome and every enemy reacts differently to different weapon, shoot their legs and they'll stumble and fall or shoot their faces and they'll try to reassure that their face isn't missing by touching it with their hands. The enemy ai is good, really good.

The game also has a decent crafting system which let's you craft items on the fly. You usewhatever parts scrap metal, junk you can salvage from the wasteland and dead bandits to create turrets, medkits, lock grinders, RC bbombs etc.

THE MULTIPLAYER
Since I am playing the game 4 years after it's release, I couldn't find any matches online,
Sorry!!

Cons
Rage creates an illusion of being an open world I say this because at first it will tempt you by showcasing these sewers that are scattered all around the wasteland, the bandits carrying on with their work, doing their business but then it hits the speed breaker. When you finally get to explore these things you realize that their aren't that many sewers in the whole god damn game, and one of them unlocks only for one mission. The game will have you infiltrating the same camps again and again and again and again........ and for some f***ing reason you encounter enemies exactly at the same location you encountered them before, so even before you can see them you can fire a rocket straight to the location you had your last encounter and it will work. The world is big and filled with detail but there is not much to it, it all ultimately feels so dull because it lacks the depth feels too much abandoned, there's not a whole lot of things to do in it and it always holds your hand, restricting you from exploring it. Some of the locations which look interesting are locked out even though you could see the enemies shooting at you from a distance. I mean to say why give the players access to a place, which isn't ready to be discovered for another 2 to 3 hrs, so early. The sidequest are probably the weakest part of the game, the game itself is like stuck on a replay button, you do things which you have already done over and over again until you say f*** this....I'm out". The end mission also feels a ♥♥♥♥♥slap to the players face

reviewText:
This game is great!  After purchasing, I immediately played through it 3 times, trying out the 3 different character classes,  increasing the difficulty and finding more hidden locations each time.

There's plenty of variety to the game and it's a lot of fun.

It delivers very well as a shooter.  The weapons are great - they look/sound good and have a good feel.  Combat is very satisfying.

Some (all?) of the guns have alternate ammo types (ie: armor piercing, explosive, electric) which you will learn to use strategically (or to completely steamroll the enemy).

It features a fairly unique open world which is fun to explore in your upgradable offroad vehicles which you also get to use to partake in violent races through the badlands.

I also think the game looks beautiful as far as settings, NPC's, weapons, vehicles, etc go.

reviewText:
Surprisingly, after hearing so much negative press, I find that RAGE is quite enjoyable. The gunplay could use some work at times (a magazine of 7.62x39 should be more than ample to take down a human, when all shots hit the head), but the driving is quite good for a game that's a mix of shooter/driver. I haven't completed the entirety of the campaign yet, as I'm playing through the DLCs at the moment (both of which follow the campaign instead of adding end-game content, though Sewers is part of the base game now) but the story is not nearly as hackneyed as many have accused it of being. It feels like Mad Max, Borderlands, and Car Wars had a disturbing little baby.

The weapons are nice, there is a good selection of generic staples (the assault rifle, machine gun, shotgun of course) in addition to some fun takes on things like the crossbow and pistol (which uses a removable cylinder and multiple caliber options--not possible but pretty fun in a video game), minigun toting spider drones, turrets, RC car bombs... it's taken a non-RPG shooter and given it some pretty entertaining, though not genre defining, upgrades.

All in all, though it is a Bethsoft published product... it's worth purchasing when on sale.

reviewText: The id 5 engine makes this game, the game is incredible looking and seems a shame more games haven't used this engine. Although the gameworld can be restrictive and some missions repetative the game flows well enough to keep you interested, there aren't too many side missions and the racing is pretty fun. The physics are good and the weapons have a weight feel to them, plus the AI is pretty good and provides lots of entertainment in torturing them with limb shots.

reviewText:
This game is fun :D

The gameplay is good and feels complex enough to immerse you but not so complex as to slow down the action.

The gun combat feels good to play and the kills are satisfying. The post-apocalyptic environment is immersive as well and looting enemies and their bases is fun.

It's not perfect - the open world" feels limited at times and the graphics can look a bit bland. Also the driving sections feel a bit tedious when you just want to get into the shooting action! But hey these things aren't a big deal.

The co-op seems pretty cool as well. Poor matchmaking but the gameplay is good.

So yeah

reviewText:
Oh Rage. You could, and should have been so much more.. First of all: the gun play in Rage is rock solid. ID knows how to make shooting fools in the face satisfying. But, and there is a huge but; the story is so badly put togheter and full of plot holes that by the end of the game i was really scratching my head at the fact that this was put togheter by a professional writer. The main plot really feels like it was cut short and the few subplots is just dead ends and is hardly worth you`re time. Then there is the mini games.. Personally i rarely engage in mini games unless there is some kind of story exposition to be had. Rage has so many pointless mini games that gives you absolutely nothing. They really feel like some slapped on filling since the side quest" part of the game is a joke.

The game also suffers greatly from constant "pop-in" that can be really annoying if you are sensitive to that kind of graphical glitches.
All in all i was very disapointed."

reviewText:
RAGE is a difficult game for me to recommend or even describe my thoughts on. On one hand, there is one main (and important aspect) to the game that the game nails in spades (imo). However, on every other hand the game fails to deliver with…just about everything else. For me: The most important aspect to a videogame is that of its gameplay. With that in my mind on games, RAGE, to me, is the biggest counterexample to that claim that I have ever seen and played.

The basic premise is an asteroid fell to Earth and ravaged the planet creating the homeland and setting to the main game, the Wasteland. You play as an Ark survivor who awakens to find the rest of your Ark members dead. Afterwards, you activate a panel that opens the door and step out into the desolate world. You enter the Wasteland and encounter some of the enemies that you will be fighting later on your journey and after being saved by Dan Hagar (played by John Goodman). You and him set off for town to begin your adventure and help in the ongoing battle against the bandits who rule the Wasteland.

Right off the bat, story wise, you can tell this isn't going to be any more than just a slapped on, Grade B, generic story that's sole purpose is a background for you and your rampant annihilation that you bring onto the enemies of the Wasteland. To be fair, id isn't really a company well known for their story telling, characters, or even their open worlds like say the Fallout series. However, in RAGE it feels like id was putting more emphasis on story and characters than their previous works; it felt as if id really wanted to break free from their simplistic shooter roots of just running and gunning with barely and reasoning behind except, Screw it! Why not?" That and the modern warfare market the FPS genre lives in now makes it difficult for future FPS games to not include it in the main game. Either way

reviewText:
There are so many amazing things about this game, it is entirely underrated. Unfortunately a lack of marketing combined with the overall lack of content are what ultimately made this game less successfull than its 2011 classmates such as Skyrim. With that said, to this day this is easily one of my favorite games that I have played. What the game lacks in content is makes up for a million times in character, beauty and overall fluid gameplay.

In comparison, RAGE vs. Bioshock (any of them) Rage wins in actual gameplay and mechanics while Bioshock would win with the strong storyline. They are  both incredible games, but put the stoy-type that Bioshock has into this game and honestly you have the perfect FPS game.

I'll start with Cons:
-The game is short, there is no way around it.
-There is more more that they could have done with the 'racing' aspect of this game. It really is more of a mini game within the game but it offered versatility in a fairly constricting game.
-This is a FPS with linear story progression, there is very minimal sandbox-type capabilities

The Pros:
-Gameplay is just delightful
-Weapons are varied and the bow with environment interavtivity and ammunition types is just increible.
-The various ways to approach every single fight whether it is through exploding remote cars, guns blazing, etc... The game boasts strong versatility in gameplay.
-TONS of mini-games within the game that are all pretty fun.
-The story is very entertaining
-The game is full of vibrant characters and monsters
-The art style is great
-The graphics are just beautiful considering a 2011 release date.
-The engine was truely a pioneer, boasting ZERO, I repeat, NO replicated areas or terrain types. (To explain, in most games, areas are replicated, reconfigured and reskinned. For example, in Fallout you may notice that a lot of areas are quite similar. This does not happen in RAGE as the engine was developed to be able to specifically alter each area, each rock, each spray painted wall.)

reviewText:
9/10 - no rage quitting here, you'll probably play this in one go

RAGE is the reason I like the STEAM free weekends, because otherwise I would have never played and eventually bought this underrated jewel of a game.

It's a mix of post-apocalyptic FPS, car wars and CCG (yeah thats right, RAGE includes an in-game collectible card game thats as fun as addictive). And on top you get to craft all kinds of useful stuff.

Took me 40 hours to finish but I'm a slow player and had both the Scorcher and Sewers DLCs. An average player will probably spend about 15-20 hours on the base game and 30 tops on the whole package.

++PROS++
+ World design, characters design, weapons design, everything is original and great looking
+ Engaging firefights in extremly varied locations where tactics count and cover is important(!)
+ An AI that lives up to its name, from mutants running on the ceiling to soldiers throwing grenades to get you out of cover
+ Original weapons like razor-boomerangs (that do return!) or RC bomb cars
+ An ingame trading card game where you have to find/buy/kill for cards you use to construct decks which you play against NPCs for cash
+ Car races&fights that are just complex enough to be fun but simple enough to enjoy even playing with mouse/kb
+ A crafting system that has you hunt for scraps and recipes to craftt everything from ammo to small robots.
+ Conversations are mostly voice acted and human(oid) enemies do a lot of trash talk during fights. VO quality is good and even the music is mostly enjoyable.

--CONS--
- Too less of everything. Places, npcs, quests, weapons, vehicles....had the game triple it's size, it could have become a contender for FO
- Not exactly railroaded but far from open world, regions have to be unlocked and the longer the game goes the more often you drive along the same routes over and over again
- The story starts out very good but somewhere in the last quarter it looses grip and logic and the end" feels rushed and unfinished
- Some boss fights can hardly be won by intuition
date:
you will have to google the tactics once or twice
- An autosave system you will have to get used to (it's not unfair though)

If you decide to give RAGE a try
recommended: get the DLCs from the start - imo the're not much fun to play after the base game's end."

reviewText:
As single-player FPS, it's quite good (if easy). Imagine Borderlands but with better characters and upgraded graphics. Controls are responsive, and there are very few cutscenes or slow character animations to interfere with gameplay.

Unfortunately, you'll spend almost as much time driving cars as you will shooting guns, and as a driving game, it's overly simple and not much fun. No multiplayer.

If you have a fast enough computer to run this at the higher graphics settings and if its on sale cheap enough, this is worth picking up for the eye candy... but don't expect to replay it.

reviewText:
It would be a competent but forgettable shooter, but as much as I wanted to like RAGE, the id Tech 5 engine is atrocious.  Wolfenstein had many of these problems, but MachineGames did their best to utilize its strengths and cover its weaknesses.  Here, we get to see just how terrible the engine really is.

As far as the game itself goes, it's your generic old-school/new-school mash-up game.  The gunplay is still satisfying, as you'd damn well expect from id, but there's just some clunkiness to it I can't put my finger on.  I suspect this also has to do with the engine, as when it isn't microstuttering and streaming 128x128 textures two feet away from me, I start enjoying it again.  I'm not even a graphics snob either, and it still gets to me with just how jarring and distracting the pop-in problems are.

The game puts you in a post-apocalyptic world, where bandits are everywhere and you go around doing quests for different people.  You can also get some vehicles along the way, and carry four weapons at a time.  Sound familiar?  Correct, this game hits pretty close to Borderlands in its gameplay.  Sadly, Borderlands takes what it does and does it well, while RAGE focuses more on its slightly-decent gunplay, so it's more of a Borderline" than anything.

Let me go out and say
date: I f@#king hate the car physics.  They're just awful.  You've got turbo and a single handbrake that's way too efficient.  Your car is pretty much glued to the floor
recommended: the smallest pebble can stop your car altogether
hoursPlayed: and moving fast with boost only exaggerates the problems I stated before with pop-in.  I dread any and all cars in this game.\n\nOn an Nvidia card

reviewText:
===Note: The Steam Review Police are trying to keep me down and limit my text, so like half of this review is in the comments===
4 years ago, I purchased RAGE. It was $30, and this was back when a game dropping to $30 within the year of its release was a deal of a lifetime and not an everyday occurrence on GMG, so I thought it was a great deal. I had heard the horror stories of its launch regarding things like ATI and general pop-in issues, but I figured enough time had passed that those bugs had been worked out. And they had, for the most part, but that wasn't why RAGE became one of my most regretted purchases on Steam. But instead of reviewing the game as I remember it, I decided to replay it just to articulate everything that I found wrong with RAGE.

First off, if you have two or more monitors and your primary isn't on the left, RAGE is going to default to try launching on your left monitor. It doesn't matter how big or small it is, or if it's set as your primary monitor (which is what most sensible games launch to); it's going to make it fit until you get in and tell it not to. The engine is also locked at 60 FPS, so if you're like me and have a nice 144 hz monitor and want to get the most of it then you should go somewhere else. But enough technical nitpicking - what about the game?

Well first off, I should mention the graphics, because it's obligatory that whenever someone mentions RAGE they have to talk about the graphics because that's the only memorable thing in this game. I could sit here and laugh at how bad the texture pop-in is, or how low resolution the textures are for hours, but I actually can't because I hit the text limit that I didn't know steam reviews had, so instead I'm just going to just leave you these videos I recorded throughout the last few days, and screenshots to accompany them, so you can laugh at them yourself. Just let me know when you're done so I can continue - they're compressed to 720p, but they still demonstrate the effects enough. These are all recorded and screenshotted on a GTX 970 with an i5 3570k overclocked to 4.4 GHz.

http://puu.sh/jvyNH/9ed9b1eb9f.mp4
http://puu.sh/jvOqm/6589f38244.mp4
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=497666089
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=497666199
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=499374619
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=499374777
http://imgur.com/a/Qmc3x

See, the thing about RAGE's graphics is that they look great when you're outside, but the game's interiors pretty much universally look like garbage from a game from 2004. Of particular note is that the game has no dynamic lighting that I could see, so instead of giving you a flashlight or something they just made all the darkness the color green, which just makes it look even uglier. Thankfully, this also has the unexpected side effect of making the pop-in not very noticeable, because even if the textures haven't popped in at all you won't be able to tell if it's using placeholders or if that's just how the game looks. What you will notice, however, is how barren the world feels. The items that can be picked up have a noticeable contrast in texture quality with the rest of the world, and since RAGE is a game where you're expected to search every nook and cranny to find said objects, there's no excuse for said nooks and crannies to look so completely awful. Nothing else in any given level can generally be interacted with - you can't break bottles, you can't push chairs, you get the idea; it feels like the entire map is just one big model that you're moving through, and combined with the total lack of any dynamic lighting it makes the interior environments feel extremely dull.

Oh, but what's that you say? You want to know about the wasteland itself? The one you've seen so many beautiful scenic screenshots about? Well, the problem is that those are just that - they're scenic wastelands that you drive through, take a screenshot of, and drive past. And that's a good thing, because even if you're outside and you get too close to a rock, or look down, the graphics just don't hold up. Now, regarding the pop-in demonstrated above there is a config that you can put in your launch options to remove it (supposedly, that is - I didn't try it, since I wanted the full RAGE experience"). The catch? It requires a GPU with at least 3 GB of VRAM. For a game in 2011
date: this is unacceptable. For a game that looks like it was made in 2004
recommended: this is laughable. But with all that
hoursPlayed: the graphics aren't even the real flaw of RAGE.\n\nAs I said before

reviewText:
I wasn't expecting too much from this game. I bought it for £3, at GAME. I quite liked it, really.

The Bad Stuff:
-The textures in game really look low detail. Unreal Tournament GOTY had better in 1990's
-The enemies repeat. The always look the same. No variation. 100 men the same, each level.
-Not enough vehicle customisations.
-John Goodman*
-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI*

The Good Stuff:
-RAGE delivers a great FPS Single Player Story.
-Interesting guns, vehicles and locations
-Doom and Quake fans will love it. Lots of moments that take you back.
-Despite the low detail textures, RAGE looks amazing in some areas.
-Regional AI damage. Shoot them in the foot, they limp. Shoot their knees - they fall. Kinda fun.
-Classic old school FPS


*denotes same thing.

If you like Dead Island style, talk to npcs and get quests for them and they'll pay you. You can not miss this game.

reviewText:
Beautiful graphics, good controls, ok storyline, ABSOLUTE ♥♥♥♥ ENDING.

Very good for a Kill Everything time waster, but don't go in expecting more than guns and guts.  Everything storywise falls apart in the end.

I still enjoyed the guns and the various ammo types, but was disappointed to see so few upgrades for your weapons, and a rather limited number of hidden secrets, or build schematics.

If you go in just wanting to see some pretty visuals and glorious gory deaths, this is visually worth the cost. Just be warned, the game will leave you wishing they had taken advantage of many of the introduced features.

I won't spoil any story, but I will say that the ending felt like a boat, sailing smoothly until it plummets off of the face of a flat flat Earth.

I had to verify that I had in-fact, beaten the game.  I literally just stared and said WTF?""

reviewText:
Very fun yet very basic shooter. That said, I'm enjoying it a lot. Is very classic, for example, you really don't need to use the aim button as in CoD to be accurate, since in normal view you already have almost perfect accuracy. Also is very old school in the sense that you can carry a bunch of weapons with you, and not just 2. The scenario is great I must say, incredibly beautiful and full of detail, so if you're looking for shooting in cool futuristic environments with lots of weapons and also do some fast speed driving, this game is definitely for you.

In the technical side, for me works almost perfectly maxed out. I still do see some texture pop up in my face, but is not that bad, and the delay is less than half a second. But if you have AMD beaware and read other reviews first.

My specs:
Laptop Samsung 7 Series NP700Z7C
Core i7 3615qm at 2.3 Ghz
8 Gb of Ram
1 TB of disk at 5400 rpm
GeForce GT 650m with 2 GBs of GDDR5

reviewText:
Amazing game! Great gameplay, stunning visuals and interesting characters. This game just has the full package!

The story sets in a post-war, apocalyptic world, and the visuals could not be better. From the landscapes to the tiny details, everything looks great with a unique art style that reminds borderlands.
The gameplay is probably the strongest point in Rage, and it was probably the main focus of the producers. And what a great job they did! I was actually searching for a FPS that suited my gameplay style, and Rage just hit the spot. It has loads of guns, some of them pretty creative, lots of different ammo for each weapon, turrets, RC bomb cars, you name it. It has diferent enemies too, which requires you to play a different style against each one, and has some fun bosses too. The roaming areas are open world, while the shooting areas are narrow spaces, clearly telling you where to go (despite sometimes I get lost for a moment, but that's becaus I like to search every bit of floor searching foor goods :P).
This game also has a car racing component, which is not bad at all. you can roam in the open world by car (or other ground vehicles) and you can race with them. The driving is quite arcade, keeping it simple, but is well balanced, nevertheless. The vehicles also have diferent weapons to shoot the other vehicles, so there's that.
The characters in this game are rich and well done, and despite of what they say to you won't be crucial information, you just want to listen to them, because of how interesting they are.

The only downside in my opinion is the story. While it promisses a good story at the start,  the story simply doesn't develop too much, wasting all the potential it had.
This game also has some few frequent minor bugs related to the image, like showing the desktop for a fraction of a second (nothing to worry about).

Overall, a really great game for people who just want to have a nice session of shooting, repeating their favorite missions on the highest difficulties (and they are challenging) and dont care that much about the story. Highly recomend it! :)

Is very classic, for example, you really don't need to use the aim button as in CoD to be accurate, since in normal view you already have almost perfect accuracy. Also is very old school in the sense that you can carry a bunch of weapons with you, and not just 2. The scenario is great I must say, incredibly beautiful and full of detail, so if you're looking for shooting in cool futuristic environments with lots of weapons and also do some fast speed driving, this game is definitely for you.

In the technical side, for me works almost perfectly maxed out. I still do see some texture pop up in my face, but is not that bad, and the delay is less than half a second. But if you have AMD beaware and read other reviews first.

My specs:
Laptop Samsung 7 Series NP700Z7C
Core i7 3615qm at 2.3 Ghz
8 Gb of Ram
1 TB of disk at 5400 rpm
GeForce GT 650m with 2 GBs of GDDR5

reviewText:
Amazing game! Great gameplay, stunning visuals and interesting characters. This game just has the full package!

The story sets in a post-war, apocalyptic world, and the visuals could not be better. From the landscapes to the tiny details, everything looks great with a unique art style that reminds borderlands.
The gameplay is probably the strongest point in Rage, and it was probably the main focus of the producers. And what a great job they did! I was actually searching for a FPS that suited my gameplay style, and Rage just hit the spot. It has loads of guns, some of them pretty creative, lots of different ammo for each weapon, turrets, RC bomb cars, you name it. It has diferent enemies too, which requires you to play a different style against each one, and has some fun bosses too. The roaming areas are open world, while the shooting areas are narrow spaces, clearly telling you where to go (despite sometimes I get lost for a moment, but that's becaus I like to search every bit of floor searching foor goods :P).
This game also has a car racing component, which is not bad at all. you can roam in the open world by car (or other ground vehicles) and you can race with them. The driving is quite arcade, keeping it simple, but is well balanced, nevertheless. The vehicles also have diferent weapons to shoot the other vehicles, so there's that.
The characters in this game are rich and well done, and despite of what they say to you won't be crucial information, you just want to listen to them, because of how interesting they are.

The only downside in my opinion is the story. While it promisses a good story at the start,  the story simply doesn't develop too much, wasting all the potential it had.
This game also has some few frequent minor bugs related to the image, like showing the desktop for a fraction of a second (nothing to worry about).

Overall, a really great game for people who just want to have a nice session of shooting, repeating their favorite missions on the highest difficulties (and they are challenging) and dont care that much about the story. Highly recomend it! :)

reviewText: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II is a truly amazing game. From the realistic breast physics to the immersive slap noises that occur during biker segments, it is truly a game worthy of praise. You begin as a Sonic looking for his parents who were killed by Batman during the Great Depression. As the game progresses, you learn more about Batman, coming to the conclusion that he is actually a carton of Mtn. Dew in disguise. It's a great message to send the new generation, informing them that caffinated drinks are the root of all evil.\nFollowing the events of Batman's unmasking, Sonic suddenly realizes what his true purpose is, and transforms into Mario because Nintendo is better than Sega. EA drops from the sky and challenges you to a fight before immediately decomposing into a pile of ♥♥♥♥-covered money. After wading through the ♥♥♥♥ and avoiding flying ♥♥♥♥-covered money, you finally find and confront Batman, killing him because Superman will always win.\nMario then re-transforms back into Sonic before succumbing to his wounds, stating the core message of the game - that I've never played it.

reviewText:
RAGE is one of those games that I love to hate. I frequently find myself wanting to punch my screen, and continue on at the same time.

I started this game on Ultra Nightmare difficulty because I am somewhat of a masochist. I held my own after learning the mutants attack patterns, and figured I could progess slowly through the game using a decent plan of attack and ammo conservation. I quickly realized that not only would I never finish a Bash TV episode without a hypochondriac's collection of bandages, but I also could not win a race that involved a time clock. I spent the entirety of my UN attempt broke and without ammo in my guns and my car. I was basically reloading the same pathetic attempts to luck out" without pulling my hair out of my scalp.

After 20 plus hours of this anxiety attack inducing frustration I dialed it down to Nightmare and have been progressing at a steady rate. I am totally addicted to the game when it comes to fps combat and enemy commentary. I find myself giggling as much the last time I heard "Hey he killed what's-his-name!" as I did the first. I have found most of the weapons have a direct purpose at least once
date: and the art style is somewhat of a favorite of mine.\n\nThe downsides I have noticed as a current player of at least mediocre knowledge of the game would definitely include the racing controls and overall uselessness of most weapons in the game. I am not using a gamepad so maybe that contributes to my problem
recommended: but it seems like the more I upgrade my cars the worse they perform. Every situation I use the car in (combat races
hoursPlayed: open world
voteText: time trial
helpfulPercent: etc) the car seems to perform differently. I assume there is some form of scaling invovled in different scenarios
votesHelpful: but I don't know if that's true. Either way it keeps me from grasping a familiarity with the vehicle I have invested in
votesTotal: and takes away from the overall level of enjoyment when it comes to racing. Once I have the story mode racing achievements finished I'll probably avoid it all together on future playthroughs.\n\nThe weapon selection is farily decent for a standard single player game of this kind. The problem for me is that even on Nightmare (and Ultra Nightmare for a short time) I find myself using four guns. Two of them for all average encounters and two of them for special ones. I used standard buckshot in the shotgun and steel tipped bolts in the crossbow in every fight I find myself in. Crossbow is for human combat
votesFunny: and the shotgun is for mutant combat. I never bother with anything else leaving most of my weapons forever ammo capped. In circumstances out of the norm I use the double barrel shotgun (Anarchy DLC ftw) armed with Pop Rockets
commentsCount: and the pistol armed with Fat Mamas or Killstrikes. The double barrel with Pop Rockets takes down any large scale boss or DLC related special mutants in seconds
column16: and the pistol with said custom ammo destroys armored humans in a similar fashion after I shoot off their helmet using the crossbow. Perhaps my experience will change once I reach the end of the story and battle the Authority
column17: but that has yet to be discovered. I find the automatic rifles to be ammo dumps that destroy my accuracy overall
column18: and even with armor piercing rounds just feel totally underwhelming. The nailgun fits into that category as well
column19: and I haven't used it since I finished the achievements related to it. I know its ammo is retrieveable (rebar only)
column20: but so are crossbow bolts that don't take 4 seconds to reload.\n\nThe crafting system is keeping me interested until I have all the schematics aquired. I mostly only use it for turrets (still trying to kill 5 enemies for the Steam achievement and will probably have to do this on normal difficulty) and lock grinders for obvious reasons. I only spend four more dollars on bandages if I just buy them compared to buying the pieces (Crimson Elite armor from Anarchy DLC ftw) and after earning $40
column21: 000 at the poker machine 4 bucks just isn't all that much compared to crafting time. So basically the best part of this system is crafting my pistol ammo. Kudos for putting a crafting system in
column22: but 90 percent of the time I'll just skip it.\n\nMultiplayer in RAGE seems like an afterthought. I generally don't get too invovled in fps multiplayer modes due to general lack of interest
column23: but in RAGE the coop was very fun for a few days. The voice chat feature worked great and saved me from needing to be on my Mumble client. My friend and I cleared everything on both difficulites except three missions. We never finished the Bash TV episodes on Nightmare (good God)
column24: and due to an end level glitch we could not finish Grab and Go on Nightmare.\n\nAlso
column25: where are all the people for the races? Even on the f2p weekend I saw no one on it. We sat for quite a while and I tried solo que a few times with no luck. Two Steam achievements I won't get unless I get two more people on my friends list who have the game and we just que up with four of us. C'mon now...so many in game badges based on the multiplayer races and no one is attempting it? Requiring four people before I can even launch the race keeps us forever alone. Seems like a waste to me
column26: but then again maybe I just missed the golden era for this games racing mode.\n\nAfter almost 40 hours in my playthrough (I take my time and try not to miss anything...the first playthrough is the most important to me) I already know I will at some point play this through again. Most likely on Ultra for the achievement and normal to clean up any missed achievements after that. This game offers much more than some folks would have you believe as long as you can get past the occasional pop in and fairly standard story line. I would definitely invest in future DLC or anytihng related to this game."

reviewText:
Paying $60 was a mistake, & I was one of the few who was unable to play for weeks after the game's launch, but I must say I still enjoyed RAGE quite a bit for what it was, for its blending of old & new.

The gunplay feels fantastic (esp. after DOOM 3's); the characters all feel very real & visually exhibit a great range of personality; the megatexture technology & art design is mindblowing; enemies-particularly mutants with their wild movement-react in uniquely 'realistic' ways to your firing, often stumbling past you as they come to grips with their death, or tripping over themselves to the side; easter eggs done right. Also: Wingsticks.

Some large gripes, however:
-Very slow intro.
-Mission structure is overly in-your-face about you being a gofer for absolutely everyone.
-Side missions felt pointless: Freq. boil down to repeating levels you've already completed. Too much padding.
-Pacing, story & writing seemed incoherent & incomplete.  Like they dropped a lot in development.

reviewText:
RAGE is one of the greatest flops that I have seen in video games, but it is still blows my mind every time I play it. RAGE is a first person shooter! A lot of people don’t seem to understand that, but it has been pretty clear from the start. This is NOT another Fallout or Borderlands! I don’t understand where everybody keeps getting this from. RAGE differs from Doom 3 in the fact that there are “safe” areas and the main world map has opened up a little bit giving you freedom and a break from shooting stuff with your shotgun, but at the heart of things it is still a FPS.

Pros:
Rage was created by id software meaning that the shooting is superb. Every weapon just feels good and sounds like it should.
Wingsticks: The wingstick is the best weapon in the game. It is essentially an offhand quick use weapon that is a sharp boomerang of decapitations.

Mega Textures: Id Tech 5 uses mega textures which make the game look gorgeous (when you are far away). Driving around in your armed buggy outside in the wasteland looks amazing and has a great feel to it.
Water: The water in RAGE looks really good. There is not a whole lot of it and there is no swimming, but it does look good.

Memorable Characters: The townsfolk that you run into are often a bit goofy like they stared at the sun too long, but they stick in your head.

Enemy Mobility: The enemies in RAGE are very agile (especially the mutants) and often climb on the walls or ceiling or are jumping over a rail or down a floor.

Other “Weapons”: There is more to RAGE than the shotgun (though the shotgun is always a good bet) there are items that you can “build” such as the sentry turret or bot and use them to help you out on your journey.

DLC: If you are liking RAGE get the DLC and play it after you finish the game, since it gives a better ending.


Cons:
Mega Textures: The down side of mega textures is when you are close up. If you go up to a soup can on the self it is all but a blur. There are some resources that can help to make this problem better, but it can only get so good due to the lack of higher quality texture file released by id.

Texture Popping: Basically you have a higher texture quality popping into place when you turn around in the game. This is a fairly common issue among lower end computers, and can be a primary reason to not play this game. There are some fixes for this but generally if you have a higher computer it won’t be an issue. Note: AMD cards have been known to have performance issues, but I haven’t experienced this.

Saves: The auto save feature in RAGE is all but broke. Don’t rely on it. Save your game whenever you want manually… Simple as that.

Story/Game World: The story of the game started out pretty good, but went downhill quite quickly. I felt like you are the only person in the game world that can do anything, and things like money are only there for you to use. The world is fairly static and default jump height doesn’t allow you to jump up on boxes or crates.

Ending: RAGE is essentially the first part in a two part story/game and the ending shows it. The ending makes since, but ultimately it is a letdown.


At the end of the day I really like RAGE and think that it is a great game, though it has been overlooked because of these issues. Hopefully id can fix this stuff and produce an amazing Doom 4, but we will have to wait and see. Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone that likes FPS games and to pick it up with the DLC when it is on sale.

reviewText: Loving this game. Much more into the Mad Max theme than Borderlands. It's like Mad Max meets Resistance. The car parts, missions and races is like your Mad Max. You even have theses guys that look like the Warboys. But than it also has Mutants which starts to feel like Resistance in the FPS parts. One mission even reminded me of Resident Evil, was a bit scary. Wish this game had more DLCs or even a more open world sequel. If your waiting for Mad Max and also played the hell out of Borderlands, try Rage. I think you'll like it.

reviewText:
Story: Now a massive asteroid hits earth in the year of 2029. There is several areas that have pockets of survivors that are forced to begin a new civilization. The world is populated by human survivors of the impact, who have come together to form settlements around oases and other practical or habitable locations, including racetracks. These fragile homes are diligently defended by the inhabitants against bandits and mutants, which are divided into various gangs and organizations of their own. Now you the ark survivor comes into the world in the year 2135. Now this game gave me the feel of Fallout which I liked very much. Now people may say fallout rip off. Which I admit ok. But really its not exactly the same. It might start nearly the same but its just a different game. Any way. You fight your way through three area's to help bring the world back from the brink of its near destruction from the Asteroid. I liked this. A nice fit for survival.

Game Play: The game primarily consists of FPS and driving area's, with the you using vehicle's to explore the world and travel between missions. Combat is in first person view. You are armed with a variety of firearms from pistols to a nice rocket launcher and my favorite weapon wing sticks (They are like boomerangs). You get different ammo for each weapon. Which you can change to your style. There is two types of enemies Shooting and melee, no need to explain what they do since its easy to figure out.

Now there is several vehicle events for you to participate in. Races and checkpoint rallies. Racing events may or may not have opponents, and some of them are armed races while others are not. You have the ability to augment you cars with various items and upgrades you can gain by completing events. Rage also some (RPG) elements, inventory system, looting system and Also able to build a wide assortment of items using collected recipes. There are also side missions and a number of other minor exploratory elements to the game.

Now this game is not fully open world like many out there. Yes you are restricted. But there is still a lot you can do. So do not let the closed world put you off. The game is fun and an interesting story to it to.

Controls: Easy and simple for anyone to use. Not much else to say on that. Controls can be customized to how you like it of course via keyboard and mouse.

The Graphics: The Graphics are really great. The characters and weapons had me drolling. Never seen such good graphics on my system like that and I am not usually some one for graphics.

Music: It was good for the game. But for this game I turned it off so I could pay more attention to the game, sometimes I find music distracting in games.

Bugs and Glitches: Right this was a big issue. Poor pc compatibility with this port. Rendering issues on the graphics and glitches in the sound along with (CTD's) But with user tweaks and fixes the game got better there was still issues but not as many for me it was just CTD's caused by my xfire. Technical issues with the PC version has led to articles explaining to users how to fix" Rage's problems. AMD had released drivers that attempt to fix some the issues. Then on October 10
date:
2011 patches for the Windows version were released which added various graphical options to the game and fixed a number of driver-related graphical issues.

Reply Value: Sadly I do not find any reply value in this game at all. Its a one time play in my books.

Overall: Now the story is good in my books. Game play is good to but there is room for improvements. Controls are easy as I have said. Graphics are amazing. Music is good. Graphics really great. There is bugs and glitches in the game and most are fixed via user help and drivers and a patch. Even for a poorly ported game. This was quiet fun and exciting for me. The ending was nice to shows for a possible squeal. But I am not going to tell you the ending. So my rating for this game will be 7 paws for this good game."

reviewText:
I would recommend it as a good play because it really is a good twist to an RPG. Hard to hit characters in first person and lots of vihicle explosions in third person.

The storyline is....cut short. Great beginning, exciting climax, and dissipointing finish.

In the end the game isn't GREAT because you have too much health, there's way too much ammo, the enemies are too stupid and there is basically no way to actually lose the game.

reviewText:
it doesnt really deserve a recomendation but it doesnt deserve to be condemed either, its more so-so.

RAGE doesnt live up to the hype that it is advertised as, it can be vissually spectacular but most of the time it isnt and looks like id has been lazy when making it. The only part i would say is not lazy is the scorchers DLC. it is a good DLC but doesnt off set the poor qualities of the game like the laziness of the construction, the lack of respawning enemies outside missions plus salvage doesnt respawn either (both of which leaves completed areas desolate after missions and can make it difficult for the more trigger happy players to keep ammo up to stock), the story line starts off good but gets weaker and weaker closer to the end and the ending makes the game feel cut short with no final boss, the racing elements of the game feel like they have been jammed in where they arent really needed and dialoge is not skipable which can get irrirating, weapon customisation is available but is very limited on only applies to a handful of weapons, gadgets are only usable in a handful of occasions (with the exception of grenades and sentury bots) and finally voice acting is mostly appauling. The mini games are decent, nothing overly special but decent to earn a little extra cash. The AI is a redeeming light of the game and does make the combat more interesting and the differnt ammo types can give additional punch when needed.

over all the game was okay to play and leaves me feeling that the game didnt live up to all i expected it to be and doesnt make use of all of its potential with the exception of the scorchers DLC which is good but ends up being fairly short and objectives can be a little vauge.

reviewText:
A fun and intense first person shooter set in the future of wasteland earth. So, it’s a little bit like Mad Max then? Well, it’s about 99% Mad Max-like. I mean you’re going to see insane weaponry, vehicular combat and bandit gangs, so it’s safe to say that this is a Mad Max themed shooter, but definitely not a movie clone.

Graphics: 10/10
For a game that is nearly 5 years old, it still impresses me on how good it looks. It’s not “perfect” by any means, but its good enough that you will think that this game is newer than it looks. Not to mention that you don’t need an overly powerful graphics card to run it; a GeForce 9800 GTX or an AMD equivalent is just enough to get playable framerates. This also goes for both the CPU and RAM. No need for a fancy £1000 rig to enjoy this game.

Storyline: 7/10
You are emerged into a wasteland earth full of bandits, gangs and mutants. You are seen as the ‘hero’ of the game and you learn more about the places and the people the more you play further into the story. It’s the generic story where you defeat all the mutants and gangs, whilst doing unrelated side-quests along the way and eventually “save” the world. It’s nothing new to the table in terms of storytelling and I wouldn’t personally call this one “story heavy”, the game is an experience and is for experience, not to be fully immersed in it. It certainly delivers that experience in a decent sense.

Sound: 10/10
The sounds of gunfire, the roaring engines and the clarity of the voice acting is at its best. Every bit of soundtrack has been fined tuned to sound how they were supposed to be heard. I am proud of what id Software did here. What an impressive achievement.

Gameplay: 9/10
It delivers very smooth and very polished gameplay that many is sure to enjoy for hours. The controls are responsive and the game difficulty is well balanced. The only downside is that you have to keep checking if you have enough ammo for a weapon as ammo in this game is very scarce, especially at the start of the game.

Price: 10/10
For the price of £12.99 and an additional £3.49 for a DLC, it is reasonably well priced and is definitely worth buying. Although, I suggest waiting until it goes on sale to get it.

reviewText:
Rage is a game from Id Software, one of the most iconic game developers of all time; Id is responsible for classics like Doom, Wolfenstein and Quake, and are a household name amongst the gaming community. Rage was pretty highly anticipated before its release, and the game itself created a pretty divisive fanbase.
Rage is set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland as a result of a meteorite collision with Earth. This makes for an environment made up of rocky canyons, dusty valleys and dark caves. This setting has been done quite a few times before, but the various gameplay mechanics and impressive use of visuals means that the world is rather nice to explore.
You navigate a moderately open world, similar to the first Borderlands. Using a wide array of guns with various ammo types, you'll collect quests from a hub, find the location in the world, complete the quest; rinse and repeat. The missions don't really have much variety as you'll often be completing the same tasks, consisting of killing mutants and bandits to get some item or pickup. Despite this however, the game will make up for it with some surprisingly solid shooting, and enjoyable racing mechanics.
The variety of guns definitely works in the game's favour. There are revolvers, assault rifles, shotguns, bazookas, plasma rifles, wingsticks, remote-control bomb cars, grenades, crossbows and sniper rifles. Not many games give you this many guns and I commend the game for doing so. The shooting itself is quite tight and responsive, with all of the weapons handling quite well. Enemy AI is also rather excellent; the enemies leap and sidestep around the levels to avoid your attacks, and it made the shooting really enjoyable and entertaining.
The game's best asset is probably the racing. With different tracks and game modes, Rage allows you to use modified racing cars to face off against other foes from around the wasteland. You can upgrade your cars with missles and machine guns, and this made for genuinely interesting moments of the game. The 'Mad Max' feel the game was obviously aiming for was really noticed her, and was one of the more addictive/memorable parts of the game.
Rage is a fun experience due to the sharp visuals, polished shooting and awesome racing. With little to no story and unmemorable characters, it is difficult to get invested in this game. If you enjoy mindless shooting and racing with visual flair, Rage will probably satisfy you. 7 / 10

reviewText:
If you are a looking for a postapolyptic fast 'n' solid id Software First Person Shooter combined with entertaining car combat races (like in Mad Max or Death Race) and a whiff of RPG-elements like crafting, RAGE could be worth a look.

Don't expect a Borderlands or even an open world Fallout 3 - There is a lot of wasted potential, the story is thin and the id Tech 5 Engine is not well optimized:
There are annoying texture popups and ugly environment textures (but awesome character textures...). You can find some .ini-tweaks online, which will improve the texture size, but it's sad enough you can't just adjust it in the graphic options.

reviewText:
The game is quite scenic and has a lot of character. The NPCs are interesting. Combat, economy, side quests, etc. all good. I made it as far as Wellspring, where I needed to get guns for my buggy to continue the storyline, and getting guns required me to win races with said buggy.

This is where I hit a wall, literally and figuratively.

The driving pretty much put an end to the game for me. At first with the keyboard, I did pretty well with the ATV, but the buggy was absolute crap. I tried my Logitech joystick, which has given me many hours of driving enjoyment... well, I had to use joy2key to make it work. And, again, driving the buggy was crap. I spent as much time in reverse to extricate myself from an obstacle as I did in forward. So I pulled out a controller. Again, driving the buggy was just not driving well (slightly better than the joystick). Additionally, the controller is just not comfortable because I haven't really used one much since the Atari 2600 days.
