reviewText:
age combines all the things we've come to expect from an id FPS with some Fallout stylings thrown in for good measure. The art direction is fantastic, and the intro cutscene was unexpectedly moving.

Multiplayer is presented through neat little flashback narratives, and I'm looking forward to playing through more of them. There's also a multiplayer racing mode that I haven't yet checked out.

The vehicle sections and minigames are good diversions, and it's nice to see some of the stock weapons enhanced through upgrades.

It's just a shame that the last third of the game feels comparatively unfinished and the finale seems to be missing. Don't expect any kind of story or gameplay conclusions.

That said, Rage is still a solid, enjoyable FPS with old school style gameplay, as well as decent arcade racing shooter.

First two thirds of the game: 10/10
Everything from about halfway through the Gaining Influence mission onwards: 4/10

The driving pretty much put an end to the game for me. At first with the keyboard, I did pretty well with the ATV, but the buggy was absolute crap. I tried my Logitech joystick, which has given me many hours of driving enjoyment... well, I had to use joy2key to make it work. And, again, driving the buggy was crap. I spent as much time in reverse to extricate myself from an obstacle as I did in forward. So I pulled out a controller. Again, driving the buggy was just not driving well (slightly better than the joystick). Additionally, the controller is just not comfortable because I haven't really used one much since the Atari 2600 days.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
age combines all the things we've come to expect from an id FPS with some Fallout stylings thrown in for good measure. The art direction is fantastic, and the intro cutscene was unexpectedly moving.

Multiplayer is presented through neat little flashback narratives, and I'm looking forward to playing through more of them. There's also a multiplayer racing mode that I haven't yet checked out.

The vehicle sections and minigames are good diversions, and it's nice to see some of the stock weapons enhanced through upgrades.

It's just a shame that the last third of the game feels comparatively unfinished and the finale seems to be missing. Don't expect any kind of story or gameplay conclusions.

That said, Rage is still a solid, enjoyable FPS with old school style gameplay, as well as decent arcade racing shooter.

First two thirds of the game: 10/10
Everything from about halfway through the Gaining Influence mission onwards: 4/10

reviewText:
Solid shooter, though you deal a lot with bullet-sponge enemies, or enemies of the same variant. Interface is very poorly designed for a mouse and keyboard. Very little difficulty curve, and the game more or less just dumps a ton of upgrades on you without even trying.

Driving is okay, but is limited mostly to races which get boring very quickly. All the upgrades aren't really necessary for survival.

Completed first playthrough focusing on side-quests and got 10 hours out of it. Bought it for $20, and would not recommend purchasing for anything more than that. Felt like iD was going for a very broad, Borderlands-esque shooter with about 30 hours of content, but ran out of time and shortened it considerably. The game ends when you feel like it just gets going.

reviewText:
Rage an example of an amazing corridor FPS(its an 'open world' filled with corridors and the 'open world is another huge corridor linking all the smaller corridors together), it offers a very different experience of corridor shooters, by giving me the choice to continue on with the story or to hang around doing side missions and races, many other linear games does not have this feature, they make you go on without giving you a break, thats why I didn't get bored playing this game.

This game is a shiny gem among other linear games, theres some great weapons to use, and I mean it, every single weapon is unique, and each has different ammo types to apply. The game even employs a decent crafting system, u can craft some items like meds to heal or bombs and stuff like that to kill your enemies with different styles. There are few types of enemy in this game, mainly u kill anything that moves, make use of your weapons, there is so many approach to killing besides shooting.

The graphics are beautiful from far, it's like a painting come alive, but up close its terrible, its so blurry that u can compare it to the graphics of the 1st Half-Life game. The driving is a bit off, it just doesnt seem real, banging a wall at full speed and u get a little knock back and thats it.

I must say the ending fight is kinda lame, I saved a lot of bullets for the boss fight I imagined would be tough, but instead its just dissapointingly easy, its the lamest ♥♥♥♥ I've ever seen, they decided to keep the story hanging there, so there will be a sequel to this. I just hope they improve everything, this game has lots of potential but not enough content.

Overall I think that it's definitely worth your time and your money, get it on a sale

reviewText:
Rage is an odd game.
Don't get me wrong, it's pretty darned fun, but it feels unfinished, which is uncharacteristic of id.
It looks gorgeous from a distance, but up close, the megatexture technology displays its weakness and ends up making every texture in the game look muddy.
There's still that odd moment when turning where the engine takes a microsecond longer to render textures in your peripheral vision.
For a world that invites exploration, it's remarkably linear, even down to your character not being able to jump over knee-high obstacles.
And the abrupt ending is one of the worst in gaming.

Still, the shooting and movement possess that unique id solidity, even down to strafe-jumping working like it does in Q3. And the character models and animation are sublime.

reviewText: I am really baffled by how much Id missed the mark on this. Aside from the blatant copying of Fallout and Borderlands, the game doesn't really do much to peak any interest in the post-apocalyptic-FPS-barren-wasteland-desert-survival games. Like, Doom and Quake, Rage just continues to throw enemies at you as you trek through the same areas over and over (and sometimes backwards). Yes other games make you return to the same areas (Borderlands) but Rage's linear single hallway design makes it tiresome. The racing feels so out of place and the in-game economy is very broken. Yes it's pretty when you're looking at stuff far away, but when you're close it's really gross.\n\nNo wonder Carmack left Id.

reviewText:
Rage is an interesting game considering its pedigree. It was a game that was released too late. Allow me to explain.
Rage had many features that were standard in the industry by the time it was released, which made the game feel like it was either behind the times or just not developed with enough substance. I felt it impossible to not compare it to other games that were released in the same time frame and felt that it brought little unqiue gameplay mechanics to the table. The tropes of older games are also present such as bountiful backtracking, red shirt enemies and linear layouts disguised as open world.

Had this game came out a few years earlier I think I would have received it better, but the entire time I was playing the game, it reminded me of something better I had already played. So take my Not recommended" with a gain of salt."

reviewText:
THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS THAT MIGHT MAKE YOU WANT TO SAVE YOUR MONEY.

This games starts very well, but it seems like they must have run over-budget as they were nearing the half-way point, and some pointy-haired, evil corporate-type with a Masters in Business Administration made the developers throw together an ending in a weekend. THERE ISN'T EVEN A FINAL BOSS!!!! Didn't even fire a single BFG round: I was saving them for some huge monster mutant, but the game just ends after you fight a bunch of small ones. Very unsatisfying.

This game is also buggy. One problem which is very annoying: the elevator to the secret lair of the resistance will often keep going down, right out of the game map, leaving you stranded in darkness.

reviewText:
This game was fun but highly overrated. For ID fans, this will be a romp down memory lane. Not much has changed since Doom and Quake except better graphics, a racing component and new gun modes. Gameplay was a lot like Doom where the only real problem was running out of ammo when too many enemies are thrown at you.  Calling this an RPG shooter, when one has played Fallout and Borderlands is a little laughable. The story is really, really unimaginative.

Still, the racing can be fun (albeit not tied well to the main game) and the Magic-esque mini-game was entertaining.

I think Metacritic was extremely charitable  to give it a 79/100. I would give it a 65/100 at best.

reviewText:
Sure it's buggy, but in retrospect, it isn't as buggy as when Dead Island came out. I've already played it for a few hours and have yet to experience a worthy game-killer bug.

Now that that's out of the way, RAGE is a really great game with great FPS and RPG elements. Seemingly numerous quests can keep you busy in a seemingly infinite, post apocalyptic wasteland. Until I get a new subscription for Fallen Earth, I'll be playing this for a while.

8.5/10

PROS
-Great visuals
-Great gameplay
-True to the FPS and RPG genre

CONS
-Stiff vehicle handling and animation
-Voice acting is iffy
-Almost as buggy as Dead Island and Fallout NV

reviewText:
graphics, sound and characters
when i fist started the game i was like WOW.
my rig could hardly run it, i could hear my old nvidia gts250 gpu fan making crazy noices while loading the hardly medium settings.
ok the grapgics are very nice, even with those settings i could see a great work done for environments, effects, mappings and textures.
awesome designs of characters and vehicles, it was like playing a realism mode of boardelands.
the animations are also very nice and the face designs were very well done although they had no expretions.
the sound effects were overwhelming, and the direction was so damn great it can make you staring around the enviroment while mouth droolling.

game play
the game length was very short actually...
yes there are quite a variety of things to do in there, but still the quests are few and your options are narrow.
plus you dont get to play free roaming around the wasteland after finishing the game.

HOWEVER.
the physics... god... the physics FAILed so badly. very very badly.
VERY narrow gaming, you can't even jump over a 30cm obstacle just because the designers don't want u to go that way even if its way too obvious that you could go there.
everything around you is just for looks, no interactions AT ALL. absolutelly non. all items are fixed inside teh environment graphics.
Rage is actually a quake game with an upgraded engine. That's exactly what it is.

the price for such a game is unacceptably high.
i mean comon, after playing scifi games like crysis, mass effect and fear, RAGE looks like an old retextured game.
they put too much efford for designs and environmental graphics, but they didnt work on the rest. it is... just weird...!
wait for a sales opportunity, the game is worth playing, but not for such a price..

reviewText: Rage had a lot of hype behind it and rightfully so. id Tech 5 introduced Mega textures" and bolstered some other neat features. So did the engine and the game deliver us the true "next gen" id experience? Yes and no.\n\nYou are an Arc survivor
date: one of the best [badass] and brightest of humanity before a major calamity befell earth. You wake up from your cryo-sleep ready to rebuilt society. Only to find the world has been reduced to a wasteland filled with bandits
recommended: mutants and is under control of the "authority". While getting on your feet
hoursPlayed: helping some of the more civilized natives you come across an overarching plot that ties everything together.\n\nThe wasteland that you find yourself in is a pseudo open-world. It has a clear structure of progression with separated locations on the two over-world maps to clear out. You'll take on quests from people you meet in the hub towns and you're free to tackle all your quests in any given order. You travel to each location with a selection of quads and cars
voteText: all upgradeable at your leisure. While traveling from location to location you'll notice that the big draw here is the variety the id Tech 5 engine provides. Repeated textures are few and far in between
helpfulPercent: creating some wonderfully diverse scenery of sprawling vistas. This however comes at a cost.\n\nRage uses immensely large singular texture maps ["Mega Textures"] for each location
votesHelpful: streaming in only that what's being looked at at that moment. The most noticeable problem is that if you spin around 180 degrees or round a corner you'll see the textures clearly stream in. Another problem this generates is that because each location essentially has one large texture file the resolution of individual objects might seem rather low at close proximity. Because of these issues and the lack of directly being able to resolve them in the video settings menu [without going into the developer console]
votesTotal: it is recommended that you use a GPU with 2GB of VRAM. I would also reckon that because of the sheer size of the textures a SSD drive would greatly speed up this streaming process as well.\n\nDo these glaring problems still make it worth exploring? Yes. Despite it's shortcomings Rage presents a wonderfully hand crafted world for you to explore. Each location you'll visit has a clear flavor
votesFunny: look and feels completely unique.The level design varies and changes per location
commentsCount: as do it's natives. Enemies come in a variety of flavors and the AI's tactics will be completely different from one faction to another. How each faction navigates their environment differently can make initial encounters jarring and tense. All that being said
column16: everything can be disposed of with a well placed buckshot or two. The gun-play feels like the signature id Software gameplay we all grew up on
column17: while also throwing in some new elements [vehicle combat] that can be hit or miss. All you need to know about the guns is that the signature id Shotgun and BFG are properly represented here.\n\nTo sum it all up
column18: Rage is an interesting
column19: gorgeous but sometimes frustrating ride that stumbles in it's execution. With John Carmack's departure from id Software it might be the last "true" id game we see. And that's exactly what it is
column20: it's an id game. Now suck it up
column21: strap in and blow some bandits away.\n\n- Full disclosure - I played and 100% completed the SP component of this game on Hard. I have as of writing this review not touched any of the DLC or MP components."

reviewText: Rage is something of a departure for Id in that there is more to Rage than simple FPS mechanics. Sure the shooting is there and what shooting there is is incredibly well done with locational damage and some decent weapons. As well as some amazing enemy animations as well as AI that is impressive in it's ability to take cover. Rage offers more than this though with it's light RPG elements such as crafting and quests" and the buggy driving mechanics which will come in to play while travelling to your quest locations. Here Id's abilty shines with car combat that wouldn't be out of place in a dedicated arcade racer.\nWhat really impresses though are the NPC animations
date: such as the blind Dr with the shoulder robot or the Mayor of Wellsprings who all show movie quality animations and facial tech. Just be wary if you're an ATI owner as there are some driver issues related to this game. 8/10."

reviewText:
Rage, if nothing else, is one of the most solid first person shooter experiences I've ever had. The graphics, despite the game taking place in a desert, is gorgeous. The gunplay is satisfying and responsive. The side quests, much like the NPCs who give them, are varied and colorful. So what went wrong?

Plot wise, Rage has terrible pacing. A majority of the game is spent building your reputation. Your only act of significance occurs in the final moments of the game. Unfortunately, even the endgame isn't rewarding.

Playing on the second most difficult setting, I died only twice. Rage is ridiculously easy. The AI is predictable and lacks intelligence. The guns are imbalanced. Challenge is something left to be desired.

With regards to the mechanics, Rage does gunplay exceptionally well. Even vehicular combat is smooth and rewarding. However, refining the bare minimum won't get you very far. Nothing about Rage makes it stand out. Yes, it is fun. But no, it isn't memorable.

Grade: B-

reviewText:
If you are coming here expecting something with plot as great as Modern Warfare or New Vegas, turn back now.  If you want an open world full of systems and dynamics on par with the GTA series or the Fallout Series, turn back now.

If you want a shoot mans game  that feels good and natural and intense as you approach a room full of hostiles, click buy.  I really wish the gunplay in this game was copied over into those other games I mentioned earlier.  The character models, the feel of the guns, the doubt as to whether you want to risk your high end ammo for a good kill or tough it out with smaller weapons to save the good bits for what is down the hall, that feels good.

The crafting system is surprisingly fun, especially with the ability to craft turrets, spider drones, RC car bombs, and some meds, this is crafting that's on par with what new vegas had, more accessable actually.

But all this comes at the cost of texture pop-in in the exterior, a shoddy story, pretty but lifeless towns, and an experience which is fun but kind of hollow.

Get it cheap but get it to understand good gunplay.

reviewText:
I bought this game the day it came out for xbox 360 (My PC was 100% linux at that point)
I played it all the way through and while it felt a bit short I loved every minute of it.

I've since upgraded my PC's GPU, dual booted windows, bought it on steam (with the DLC) and am playing through it again.
I'm finding it just as enjoyable as the first time I played it and I would like to see more games like it in the future.

In my opinion, too many games recently have tried to add far too much content and forgotten to add the fun.
These games start to feel like a chore to play and you end up never finishing them. Of course there are exceptions but I have far too many games I will probably never finish because they got boring.

Sure RAGE doesn't have the best graphics (although that painted sky is beautiful) nor does it have the greatest storyline, however, it's the kind of game that's genuinly fun to play.

The mechanics are fun (I especially like the wingsticks and deployable turrets) and who doesn't like blowing up a mutant with an explosive projectile fired from a massive shotgun? The missions are all slightly different and (at least for me) the game never feels stale or lacking in content.

Once you've finished the main storyline and the missions from the jobs board there are always the sewers to clear and now the scorchers DLC which, while quite short, I found to be increadibly entertaining.

I get bored very easily and so there are very few games I have played all the way through, let alone gone back to for a second play though. Rage however is one I just can't get enough of.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Awesome game! one of the best single player campaigns i have played in many years. the graphics are very intense and detailed.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I see other reviewers' complaints about the story line, characters, etc.  I find myself wondering whether they've played the same game as me?!

This game is head and shoulders above any other FPS game out there for its weapons, movement and AI mechanics. The graphics is far ahead of any other game of its time, with its texture streaming technology where they've achieved the most realistic environments I've seen to date. Also, you will not see any repeating textures that are so common in other game titles.

Game characters are exquisitely portrayed and memorable. Perhaps you won't find much back story for them, but this game is FPS with RPG elements, not the other way around. The game uses RPG elements to involve you into its story, it's a tool, not and end in itself.

The same applies to story line. Simple doesn't always mean bad. On contrary, simplicity is Zen, and that is hard to achieve, especially in FPS. Take Crysis 2 or 3 for example, where I've still no idea what's going on, despite replaying it few times. That's because story in Crysis seems like an addon, so I don't care for it. RAGE will make you care, for its story is essential to your gaming experience.

Vehicle fights are incredibly fun, but you need to take time to master it.

Weapons are punchy and satisfying, with adversaries' AI providing just enough challenge to enjoy the fights. Close proximity fights are so much fun that it took me back to Doom2 and 3 days!

The time invested in playing RAGE will reward you with hours of pure fun.

reviewText: Rage is an openworldish fps with some real high points but plagued by mediocrity. Everything in this game has been completely under-realized, from story, setting, exploration, character options, crafting system to the incredibly typical gun procession (pistol, shotgun, AR, crossbow, well timed rpg) . I had great satisfaction in using the different ammo types and buildable items such as the RC car bombs, wingsticks, mindcontrol bolts, and the combat mechanics are very solid. It has some very fun moments and slick level design at times, but playing the levels forwards and backwards was sorta cheesy. Story was stagnant and the ending was aweful. Overall it feels like its been stretched too thin but the combat makes the game totally playable. Maybe a Rage 2 will really pull some of the potential in the game design together and create and standout game but this title is just a fun  bargain shooter. 21 hours played between the tacked on multiplayer and the campaign however and most of the time was well enjoyed but i know ill never play it again Pick it up on sale, beat it once, uninstall, not worth the full price or the 21 gb but certainly worth a go.

reviewText:
I bought this game the day it came out for xbox 360 (My PC was 100% linux at that point)
I played it all the way through and while it felt a bit short I loved every minute of it.

I've since upgraded my PC's GPU, dual booted windows, bought it on steam (with the DLC) and am playing through it again.
I'm finding it just as enjoyable as the first time I played it and I would like to see more games like it in the future.

In my opinion, too many games recently have tried to add far too much content and forgotten to add the fun.
These games start to feel like a chore to play and you end up never finishing them. Of course there are exceptions but I have far too many games I will probably never finish because they got boring.

Sure RAGE doesn't have the best graphics (although that painted sky is beautiful) nor does it have the greatest storyline, however, it's the kind of game that's genuinly fun to play.

The mechanics are fun (I especially like the wingsticks and deployable turrets) and who doesn't like blowing up a mutant with an explosive projectile fired from a massive shotgun? The missions are all slightly different and (at least for me) the game never feels stale or lacking in content.

Once you've finished the main storyline and the missions from the jobs board there are always the sewers to clear and now the scorchers DLC which, while quite short, I found to be increadibly entertaining.

I get bored very easily and so there are very few games I have played all the way through, let alone gone back to for a second play though. Rage however is one I just can't get enough of.

reviewText: Rage. a mediocre game, nothing more, nothing less. The game itself is visually appealing and has good shooter mechanics, physics, driving combat mechanics and voiceacting. On the other hand, the story experience although being a fair length, is uninspiring, subpar in both content and execution and the gameplay feels like a series of fetchquests you would find in an MMO. The world is a postapocalyptic one, with mutants, human settlements/shacks, and bandits all fighting for control. There is limited freeroam, most of which is in your vehicle which is arguably the most polished part of the game. The driving combat is relatively well done, and overall is fun, and with towns offering race challenges you will honestly have a blast with this fair bit of content, so much so that you wonder why there is even a single player shooter game outside of this. Returning to the singleplayer story, it can be best summarized as Fallout 3 with better visuals, a very linear focus, bland execution and even vaguer cliche story. The game wobbles back and forth between relatively inspired story driven missions, and pure padding (fetch this, kill that), which although extends the duration you will spend on the game detracts from the overall experience (this is of course following main story arc, if you branch there is much more tedius missions). The game does feel like it is marginally unfinished or rushed in terms of the single player experience, and it answers few questions and returning to the previous points, some missions are well done, others not so much. The multiplayer experience is a nice touch, but has minimal longterm appeal, again the car racing is arguably the most enjoyable portion. Despite all this, the game is a worthwhile playthrough, although it is nowhere near the caliber of the obvious comparison of Fallout 3/New Vegas, it is however a mediocre first person shooter experience, worth a buy if you have the time and the patience.

reviewText:
So after finishing the game that I was really looking forward to, I have mixed feelings with RAGE.

PROS:
+Great action.
+Addictive driving and fun car combat. Fun races too!
+Great weapons with good sounds
+Impressive graphics once setup properly.

CONS:
-VERY linear
-LITTLE exploration. No free roaming à la Borderlands / Fallout 3.
-Few side quests / jobs to do.
-No deathmach mode for multiplayer (very unlike id Soft)
-Online racing can be tedious to find other players.
-No BOSS FIGHT in the last chapter (quite unlike id Soft)
-No proper closure of the campaign mode (still no DLC)
-ATI Drivers issues at game launch made the game unplayable till months later. (Waited 5 months till the game was playable!)

Saddening this game took MANY MANY YEARS in development and it ended up like this. Promising game with many letdowns.

OVERALL:
A disappointing game with fun shooter elements like id Soft are known for and that it could've been so much more.

RATING:
7.0 / 10

UPDATE:
If you loved playing RAGE, you may consider playing the single player DLC which is decent but don't expect more story into the game, unfortunately.

reviewText:
I see other reviewers' complaints about the story line, characters, etc.  I find myself wondering whether they've played the same game as me?!

This game is head and shoulders above any other FPS game out there for its weapons, movement and AI mechanics. The graphics is far ahead of any other game of its time, with its texture streaming technology where they've achieved the most realistic environments I've seen to date. Also, you will not see any repeating textures that are so common in other game titles.

Game characters are exquisitely portrayed and memorable. Perhaps you won't find much back story for them, but this game is FPS with RPG elements, not the other way around. The game uses RPG elements to involve you into its story, it's a tool, not and end in itself.

The same applies to story line. Simple doesn't always mean bad. On contrary, simplicity is Zen, and that is hard to achieve, especially in FPS. Take Crysis 2 or 3 for example, where I've still no idea what's going on, despite replaying it few times. That's because story in Crysis seems like an addon, so I don't care for it. RAGE will make you care, for its story is essential to your gaming experience.

Vehicle fights are incredibly fun, but you need to take time to master it.

Weapons are punchy and satisfying, with adversaries' AI providing just enough challenge to enjoy the fights. Close proximity fights are so much fun that it took me back to Doom2 and 3 days!

The time invested in playing RAGE will reward you with hours of pure fun.

reviewText:
Rage, if nothing else, is one of the most solid first person shooter experiences I've ever had. The graphics, despite the game taking place in a desert, is gorgeous. The gunplay is satisfying and responsive. The side quests, much like the NPCs who give them, are varied and colorful. So what went wrong?

Plot wise, Rage has terrible pacing. A majority of the game is spent building your reputation. Your only act of significance occurs in the final moments of the game. Unfortunately, even the endgame isn't rewarding.

Playing on the second most difficult setting, I died only twice. Rage is ridiculously easy. The AI is predictable and lacks intelligence. The guns are imbalanced. Challenge is something left to be desired.

With regards to the mechanics, Rage does gunplay exceptionally well. Even vehicular combat is smooth and rewarding. However, refining the bare minimum won't get you very far. Nothing about Rage makes it stand out. Yes, it is fun. But no, it isn't memorable.

Grade: B-

reviewText:
graphics, sound and characters
when i fist started the game i was like WOW.
my rig could hardly run it, i could hear my old nvidia gts250 gpu fan making crazy noices while loading the hardly medium settings.
ok the grapgics are very nice, even with those settings i could see a great work done for environments, effects, mappings and textures.
awesome designs of characters and vehicles, it was like playing a realism mode of boardelands.
the animations are also very nice and the face designs were very well done although they had no expretions.
the sound effects were overwhelming, and the direction was so damn great it can make you staring around the enviroment while mouth droolling.

game play
the game length was very short actually...
yes there are quite a variety of things to do in there, but still the quests are few and your options are narrow.
plus you dont get to play free roaming around the wasteland after finishing the game.

HOWEVER.
the physics... god... the physics FAILed so badly. very very badly.
VERY narrow gaming, you can't even jump over a 30cm obstacle just because the designers don't want u to go that way even if its way too obvious that you could go there.
everything around you is just for looks, no interactions AT ALL. absolutelly non. all items are fixed inside teh environment graphics.
Rage is actually a quake game with an upgraded engine. That's exactly what it is.

the price for such a game is unacceptably high.
i mean comon, after playing scifi games like crysis, mass effect and fear, RAGE looks like an old retextured game.
they put too much efford for designs and environmental graphics, but they didnt work on the rest. it is... just weird...!
wait for a sales opportunity, the game is worth playing, but not for such a price..

reviewText:
Rage is a classic first person shooter with a post-apocalyptic scenario.

Graphics:     7/10

The good news is that the game on the whole looks very good. When you play it for the first time you will have the wow-effect" as soon as your character leaves the survivor capsule. The particle effects are not exeggerated and suitable. When you get the first weapons you will agree that the developers put some work into them. They may not be everbody's taste but the visual quality is unquestionably good. You can say the same thing regarding the environment.
The bad news is that if you look a bit closer at the textures you will be very disappointed. Some are very blurred and directly next to them some are razor-sharp ones
date:
what underlines the blurring even more. It looks like someone mixed Crysis 3 textures with Minecraft textures.
Nevertheless the game has a good appearance concerning the graphics.

Sounds:     6/10

The weapon sounds are really powerful (especially the shotgun). Usually the rule is "the louder the gun the more damage you do". The cars have a nice engine noise. While most of the enemies say nothing or have nasty sounds you don't want to hear the villagers have pleasant voices. I appreciate that the developers tried to give everything a sound. That made the game lively and authentic. Due to the really bad enemy sounds I give 6/10. The developers could have made it better than that.

Gameplay/Handling/Equipment:     9/10

It's an ego-shooter
recommended: you will get what you expect. You will spend most of the time shooting mutants and bandits. To keep the player entertained the developers wisely added some side missions to break the monotony. Besides that you can gamble
hoursPlayed: enter an extensive racing competition to win car upgrades and new cars
voteText: play cards with a "trading card game" or risk some fingers in the knifegame. The handling is nearly perfect. You can quickly change weapons and ammo type
helpfulPercent:
draw your grenade or fix yourself up. Steering a car is really easy. The equipment is very nice. The different ammo types make the game interesting. If you are tired of normal shotgun ammo then craft explosive ones to transform your shotgun into a grenade launcher. Especially the crossbow has a lot of special bolts.

Level design:     8/10

The level design is pretty narrow with some exceptions. This makes the combat straightforward and the shotgun your best friend in close quarter combat. The exceptions are mostly the parts where you are driving the car. Sadly there are only two or three sniper side missions. The level routes are very interesting and sophisticated. You will have few monotonous areas in the game. The only really monotonous part is the open world which connects the mission locations.
I loved the level where I had to go to the destroyed city to get the defibrilator-upgrade. It gave me a real apocalyptic feeling.

Enemies/AI:     5/10

The AI is relatively poor. Except for some scripted events the enemies are just charging at you or are not using the covers properly. They don't have teamwork or act structured. Well at least some enemies use special abilities like the "octopus-like" enemy with the hook. The enemy variety is relatively low but it doesn't really matter.

Story:     3/10

The beginning and the basic idea was actually cool but it seems that the developers lost their creativity in the end. You are a survivor of a meteor impact and then... well and then you have to deal with the new world. There are some people who want to use the rescue-capsule for something and you want to free the civillians from the enemy influence and make sure that the capsules don't fall into enemies' hands. I don't really get it

reviewText:
I would reccomend rage on a sale or free. (That is how I got it).  It was very visually appealing, lots of rich terrain and infastructure. I felt like as soon and I got a feel for the game it was over. There are two main areas with what seemed like a dozen or so quests per area and then it is over. (I logged about 30 hrs, but really 20 of that was pushing the quests).

The weapons were pretty fun (like watching enemies dance when you hit them with a dynamite dart in the hand) but again I wanted more interaction with the Authority. I wanted more technology from them coming at me and more difficult bosses.  The weapon ranges were pretty cool and I wish there were some challenges in the game that demanded creativity in the choice of weaponry and bots.  You could basically go through the game and use only the shotgun pop rockets and the fat mamma's and be fine.

(another fun one is the flame thrower guys.. just shoot them with anything you have and they will sort-of turn away... when they turn away exposing their fuel tank shoot the valve and BOOM)

From 0 to 100 I would rate it in the low 70's.  I won't likely play it again.  Pretty fun though.

Seems like a book, or series of books about this subject would be better. I really wanted more detail about the post-apocolypse and how the authority came to power and what sort of technology they had. Didn't get much of that.

reviewText:
graphics, sound and characters
when i fist started the game i was like WOW.
my rig could hardly run it, i could hear my old nvidia gts250 gpu fan making crazy noices while loading the hardly medium settings.
ok the grapgics are very nice, even with those settings i could see a great work done for environments, effects, mappings and textures.
awesome designs of characters and vehicles, it was like playing a realism mode of boardelands.
the animations are also very nice and the face designs were very well done although they had no expretions.
the sound effects were overwhelming, and the direction was so damn great it can make you staring around the enviroment while mouth droolling.

game play
the game length was very short actually...
yes there are quite a variety of things to do in there, but still the quests are few and your options are narrow.
plus you dont get to play free roaming around the wasteland after finishing the game.

HOWEVER.
the physics... god... the physics FAILed so badly. very very badly.
VERY narrow gaming, you can't even jump over a 30cm obstacle just because the designers don't want u to go that way even if its way too obvious that you could go there.
everything around you is just for looks, no interactions AT ALL. absolutelly non. all items are fixed inside teh environment graphics.
Rage is actually a quake game with an upgraded engine. That's exactly what it is.

the price for such a game is unacceptably high.
i mean comon, after playing scifi games like crysis, mass effect and fear, RAGE looks like an old retextured game.
they put too much efford for designs and environmental graphics, but they didnt work on the rest. it is... just weird...!
wait for a sales opportunity, the game is worth playing, but not for such a price..

reviewText:
If you are coming here expecting something with plot as great as Modern Warfare or New Vegas, turn back now.  If you want an open world full of systems and dynamics on par with the GTA series or the Fallout Series, turn back now.

If you want a shoot mans game  that feels good and natural and intense as you approach a room full of hostiles, click buy.  I really wish the gunplay in this game was copied over into those other games I mentioned earlier.  The character models, the feel of the guns, the doubt as to whether you want to risk your high end ammo for a good kill or tough it out with smaller weapons to save the good bits for what is down the hall, that feels good.

The crafting system is surprisingly fun, especially with the ability to craft turrets, spider drones, RC car bombs, and some meds, this is crafting that's on par with what new vegas had, more accessable actually.

But all this comes at the cost of texture pop-in in the exterior, a shoddy story, pretty but lifeless towns, and an experience which is fun but kind of hollow.

Get it cheap but get it to understand good gunplay.

reviewText:
Good game. Good fun. Unfortunately I felt a bit like I just wanted to play Borderlands during the gameplay. However there are many fun 'mini-games' and car races/events. Enough to satisfy a change of scenery from shooting bandits.

The missions felt a bit too 'samey', going into a hideout or area and shooting bandits to bits, you pass an area you can't get into as you go in and you start to realise you're just going to poke out of their in about 10 minutes time. But, the story within the hideouts change which makes it enjoyable nonetheless. The addition of screaching and random moments of being trapped in with muties bouncing around made me jump quite a few times as well which is always a bonus.

The ending [no-spoilers, don't worry] was a bit of a let down for me. I thought the story was going to be dragged on a bit more but it seemed to end quite suddenly and was easy to get to in the last area. Was expecting some kind of huge boss (like Borderlands) but only got waves of armored-muties.

Recommended weapon:
The wingstick. Mandatory in this game. Never known a game where a modified boomerang destroys all.
Haha.

In all, 7/10, would recommend if you havn't tried Borderlands or have finished both and want more.

reviewText:
RAGE is another single word title game from id Software, creators of DooM and Quake. This game was the showcase for id’s Tech 5 Engine and as well as the first new IP from the company since Quake. As one would expect, RAGE is a First Person Shooter, but only part of the time. It is also a racing game at times as well as a vehicular combat game.

RAGE takes place more than 100 years after an asteroid has devastated the planet in an atmosphere that is similar to the Fallout series in some ways. You play as an Arc Survivor, a person that was placed in cryogenic suspension to be woken up after the disaster to rebuild civilization. The player isn’t the average joe by any means. He has been infused with nanotech that enables him to heal amazingly fast and even come back from the dead. First the player battles the many bandits that inhabit the Wasteland, hideous mutants and then moves on to the tyrannical high tech Authority which aims to dominate the world.

Combat in RAGE is solid and was certainly the most enjoyable part the game for me. The weapons “feel” solid and are varied. Along with different weapons are different ammunition types. Some types of ammunition increase affectedness against certain types of enemies and a few make radical changes in how the weapon will act. In addition to using weapons the player is able to construct RC Bomb Carts, Sentry Turrets and even lethal Sentry Bots to help the player out in a fight. No small amount of combat that occurs in RAGE takes place on the roads of the wastelands as you drive about. This combat can get a bit tedious at times as there is little variation in the enemies and they attack in a fairly predictable manner.

That was the good, now for the bad and that is the writing. I am not saying the writing is terrible, it gets the minimum job done. But it *only* gets the minimum job done. Most of the characters you see in the game come off as flat caricatures whose only reason to exist is to drive the story along, act as an info dump or give you a mission to accomplish. You really don’t care anything about these people. Even the ones you should care about such as Dan Hagar, the first person you meet on the game and he even saves your life. If the characters you meet in the game have any real life to them it is because the voice actor gives it to them. If Steve (Spike Spiegel) Blum can’t bring a lot of life to a character, something isn’t right.
Sometimes there are things that show up that make no real sense and can break your suspension of belief. Bandits with British or Russian accents? What? WHY? Heck, I remember one bandit complaining about how he missed Mother Russia. This is supposed to be a post-apocalyptic world. You just don’t pick up and move hundreds of people halfway across the planet without even a hint an explanation or reason.

Something that irritated me was all the references to other id games that can be found in RAGE. Now I am not totally against the practice of referencing, but there is a point where it breaks immersion. Unfortunately in RAGE they go to the point of shattering immersion into a thousand little pieces for no good reason I can see. From hidden rooms dedicated to earlier games (done in the same graphical style as the original game) to advertisements for DooM 3 or RAGE 2, to “Pinkies” a combined take off on Twinkies and the Pink Demons from DooM. You can even find the “numbers” from LOST in there as well as a “Pick up the can” scene from Half Life 2.

Probably the best illustration of the problems I see with RAGE can be found in “The Scorchers” DLC. In this we are introduced to Sarah, a member of the Hagar Clan. It seems to me that she was supposed to be a character similar Alyx Vance from Half Life 2. But if that was what id was going for, they failed and failed badly. She starts off as a very good fighter, then turns into a damsel in distress at the drop of a hat for no other reason to give the player a reason to follow the bad guys. Sarah shows more skin than just about any other female character and struts and poses like a model all the time. Worse after going through a fairly traumatic experience she shows absolutely no reaction to it other than a “Thank You”. Wut?

The main enemy of the DLC (a bandit clan called the Scorchers) has a base in some strange ruins that look like they were built by aliens. In fact I actually thought that it did take place on another planet for a while since it didn’t resemble the environment seen in all the rest of the game. The end of the DLC leaves Sarah in the Trophy Room (Yes, that is the Official Name) and never leaving. If you talk to her she will snark a little at the player though.

I guess the biggest problem I have with RAGE is that I can clearly see is that id seems to have been shooting for the next Half Life or HALO IP and they screwed it up. They had all the pieces to make a compelling universe that people would want to visit again and again, but they failed to bring those pieces together and relied on writing that is often flat and riddled with clichés. I guess the part about RAGE I dislike the most is the fact I can see the great game it could have been and is not.

Despite my complaints RAGE is a good shooter and if you are looking some good FPS combat RAGE certainly delivers. Just don’t expect much more than that. sm

reviewText:
Rage, developed by Id Software & Released on Oct 4, 2011. According to Metacritic (http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/rage), it's rank 55th best critic review pc game & 9th most discussed pc game in 2011, respectively.  Does it hold any meaningful  value or worth purchasing in 2015? It depends.

The Controls are easy to grasp. Visually, it still looks good to date. Game mechanics is good, fun. Aside from the FPS, you'll have racing and some other mini games to play. The combat system is responsive@really satisfying feel. The AI are fairly smart. You'll get to experience it when you put up a fight against groups of mutants and the humans factions.

Rage is set in an post-apocalyptic time. It feels like a combination of mad max & borderland. I'll give you the bad news first. You'll be spending most of your time driving. The good news?  No nonsense farming for random glowing loot & you'll get to blow up lots of enemies/vehicles/mutants while exploring the land -or-trying to get from point A to point B.

Unlike borderlands, you'll only have a limited choice of weapons & customization to choose from. Some are pretty nasty & interesting (for instance the Nail Gun or the remote control car with bomb) BUT you'll need to replenish the ammo constantly throughout your travels. You either buy them or craft them from your salvages.

The road to richness is a long one, you'll get to play some mini games to to earn cash, a tv arena to earn more cash and a few racing arena where you'll have to invest your time to get the vehicles upgrade parts for your sweet ride.

The story is linear but definitely an interesting one. Not as funny/whacky than borderlands but is still refreshing to do them after X amount hours on the road (smashing/blowing up everything that moves).
There's Multiplayer option as well however I have yet to try it out myself.

My Summary:
It was refreshing and fun at first but after a XX amount of hours into the game, it gets pretty boring@repetitive but what kept me going was the story. The interesting fights/scenario you're put into. Late into the game however, there's a sudden spike of difficulty. That's a no-no for me. I wasn't pleased at all with ending. (There wasn't even an epic boss fight!) Despite the awesome guns/combat mechanic - there is no replay value for Rage. It was a sweet, one time experience for me. On the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for Rage is a 6/10.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game for about 100 minutes as of writing this, and I have to say: very little of that time was spent actually SHOOTING anything.

This game really is just another racing game, and a poorly made one at that.  It may be better with a controller, but I used a mouse + keyboard, and it just felt awkward.  There's supposed to be a semi-deep system with different ammunitions for each gun, but I have to say they all felt really pointless.  Fatboy bullets and regular pistol ammo seemed to do about the same damage.

There's also a sharp lack of customization.  The biggest issue of which is there's no console, unlike every other id game, and you can't change things such as toggle ironsights" or "hold crouch
date:
the two biggest problems with the game for me.

The controls feel very awkward, with the in-game cursor being affected by the aim sensitivity.  At defaults, it feels fine, but above that it crosses the screen in less than a centimeter of movement, and unless you raise it, it takes a significant amount of time just to turn around in-game.

4/10, really wish I hadn't bought this.

reviewText:
Synopsis: A post apocalyptic FPS, where you try to save the world from the evil government and wasteland bandits.
Genre: FPS

Yea!: A large amount of unique weapons(as well as ammo types for each one) that each feel different, gunplay is a blast! Distance graphics are just beautiful.

Meh!: Story is your run of the mill cookie cutter Post-apoc save the world story, length for a fps is just right. Texture quality is too wide in quality with either being awesome or just down right pathetic.

Bleh! Game is full of technical issues, especially in the menu system with mouse sensitivity, unresolved AMD GPU crashes and the unability to skip cutscenes and character conversations is quite annoying.

Lowdown: A good FPS when caught on sale cheap enough, but it shows its console development lead with some of the textures and objects in game. The menu sysstem can be fixed by putting mouse sensitivity in game to at least 50% but makes aiming to fast for me in game.

3/5

reviewText:
Do you wish your Fallout post-apocolyptic game was more like a linear corridor shooter?

Linear as they are, the levels are rich in visual flair.  The gunplay isn't overly technical and is polished as any other Quake or Doom game.  The gadgets are a nice way to make the combat alittle more different than the usual pop and shoot.  The weapons sound nice and beefy.  The cars handle well with a k/m.

This game isn't bad at all.  Might be repetitive for some, might be engaging for others.  I enjoy it simply for the visuals.

reviewText: Oh Rage, how you made me rage on release day. I remember it so well. First of all I have to say I was really  excited about this game when it was announced and after watching early build footage and trailers. I pictured Fallout with vehicles. I immediatly pre-ordered the game and waited for release day.\nMy first attempt at playing Rage was marred by graphical annoyances as turning in the game would cause me to see textures low rez for a second before the high rez textures would load. This was immensly annoying as the game didn't even look that great to begin with.  After pouring through forums and tech support there didn't seem to be a fix that would cure this bug so I continued playing until I got my first vehicle. This is when I stopped playing. The vehicles have very limited physics and the landscape are very limited in scale that there didn't seem to be any fun to be had at driving. I stopped playing shortly after that and considered this game a loss.\nFast forward years later and I decided to play it again, knowing what I did about the games limitations and hoping the texture bug would atleast be fixed. Now that is when the fun began. The vehicle part of the game is more like Borderlands  than some surreal open world driving simulator that I had hoped.  Vehicles have very limited physics and the areas you drive through are just large hallways that you go through to get from point A to point B with a few enemies thrown inbetween. But what makes Rage shine is the combat. Its what ID software  does best, the feel and sound of the weapons and the enemies reaction to getting shot.  After getting over my initial expectations I was able to enjoy the game for what it is, A really fun shooter. If your looking that and nothing more you will be pleased.

reviewText:
Review, not recommendation.

The game is rather fun to play and is a straight forward shooter.  If you enjoy FPS's you'll enjoy RAGE.

The setting feels appropriate, and the people populated into the world by the writers and actors fit the situation perfectly.  It was refreshing to have the characters populating the world feel like real people rather than plain cardboard cutouts.

Like most sci-fi shooters in post apocalyptica, the weapons vary from a very basic pistol to a rocket launcher or a energy mini-gun.  As per normal, the only weapon in the game that can one shot anyone is a 'hi-tech' crossbow, and it can only do it if the enemy doesn't know you are there.

There is a MadMax car component to the game that isn't bad, but I don't really view it as a core component to the game.  The car is mostly for getting you from point A to point B.  The car racing/demo derbies are fun distractors from going off and playing the other parts of the game.

Overall, I'd say the greatest reason to play RAGE is the atmosphere and the well portrayed NPCs.  Most everything else is pretty generic.

The story is pretty good, but the ending felt like a let-down to me personally.  Especially considering some of the things you do in game prior to its conclusion.

Overall rating: 6/10 (Get it if you like shooters, you'll probably enjoy yourself)

reviewText:
What is rage, you may ask?  Let me answer that question of yours.
The game is set in a post-apocalyptic future, where the civilization as we know it, has been destroyed by the asteroid 99942 Apophis in 2029. Survivors have created settlements and other habitable locations and have been divided into various clans and organizations of their own. Bandits and mutants constantly roam the world and try to salvage and destroy the settlements.

The story is your basic, “save the world story”. I could not get into the story of this game, it did not draw me in with anything special. I found no connections to the players actions except saving the world, but you are not greeted with an explanation to why the protagonist do the things he does. The protagonist is a mystery, who just happens to emerge and wants to save the world. I guess that you do not need more information to why you save the world, but it is a detail I would like to see, as to why the protagonist to the choices he does.

The protagonist, is an “Ark Survivor”. You emerge to the surface as the sole survivor from your Ark in 2135, and you are immediately thrown into the harsh world that is left. You are greeted by some bandits trying to salvage the wreckage of your ark, you are in an bad position as you lack weapons and equipment, but fear not because you are saved by a wasteland settler, who will teach you how the new world works. From here on it follows a linear story, where you do quest after quest which takes you further up in the world, and soon people will start to hear rumors of the “Ark Survivor”, and form here on the journey only gets harder as you try to save the world from its misery.

It is not that I disliked the story itself, I just could not find myself caught in it. I just followed the quest, did what I was told, and not long into the game I started to forget the story itself. But fear not, the story may have been weak for me but there were many other things that weighted in for it.

The gameplay itself is what lured me into this game, this is what kept me coming back to the game. It is very action based, with a lot of gun-play, and a few stealth mechanisms if you manage to pull them off.
This action is where all the fun resides. You can find yourself stuck waist-down in a firefight, with grenades flying from both sides, until you emerge victorious or die trying. But you do not actually die, since the Ark suit that you wear through the game has a built in defibrillator, so when you are about to die you enter a second chance mode, where you can revive yourself with a percentage of health and take out the enemies around you.

I found that the AI was very good, and they have some of the more interesting mechanics, comparing with other games. Bandits dodge your shoots by doing acrobats, tactically advance and fall back depending on their amount, their health and how much health I seem to have. Mutants however swarm the area around you and charge head in, towards you, and jumps around to confuse you.
There are not so many different enemies. There are three main categories, Bandits, Mutants and Authority. Each of the three has a number of different subcategories, where you find a handful of changes like, different weapons and different armor, changes in movement and size. Sure there are only three main enemies, but with the subcategories and all the changes in between the enemies, you get a very dynamic feel towards what you are fighting. There are some bosses in the game, which are a nice asset. One is the huge of a ten story apartment and takes some time taking down until you learn the tricks, and another might just be a bandit in some bulky armor shooting rockets at you. I found the bosses to be a nice change from the regular creeps that are sent at you, and they offered a nice amount of challenge, to keep it hard and interesting.

The enemies had some changes with weapons, but what do you get?  You get an arsenal of ten weapons if I am correct. At first I thought that this was not enough, that it became to repetitive running about with the weapons you had, but all of that changes soon enough, when I was introduced to different kinds of ammo and equipment. Some weapons got explosive ammo, some got electric, some even got mind-control ammo. There was so many joyful ways to take down your enemies that I had a hard time choosing which was my favorite. The game rewarded you with different types of equipment, your primary were regular grenades, but you also had EMP-grenades, wingsticks (A triple-bladed boomerang), RC cars and some other things that I did not pay so much attention to.

There was a nice amount of side quests that you could do, from eliminate, protect, save, gather, races and delivery missions. They offered a nice variation to the linear and dull story, but there was one thing that blew away all of the side missions and that was BashTV, and arena where you could fight through some of the weirdest, immerse, amusing and engaging rooms filled with mutants of all sorts. I spent a lot of time in this arena, rampaging about with my weapons as I had to dodge enemies, spinning blades from the roof, spikes from the floor, you name it.

A game cannot be perfect, while there was a lot of things that stimulated, but there were also some things were dull and for me destroyed the feeling of immersion. The first thing I have already mentioned, and that is the story. Then we have the world. From time to time the world appealed me, with how everything seemed to have adopted to the apocalyptic world, how the some areas felt unique. I found it to be way to empty from time to time, and I saw repeating patterns in how the enemy areas were made. There were no weather changes, which withdrew some of my immersion.
I also felt like the textures on the environment were to low res from time to time, and badly made, compared to the weapons, characters and vehicles. I had some trouble with the rendering from time to time as well, seemed like the textures were not loading as they should. Other than the problem I had with the look of the textures and their rendering from time to time, the game looked good. It fitted the scene of an apocalyptic world as it was supposed to, sure there was the feeling of it being to empty at certain points, but what else is there to be expected from a game like this.

The controls were completely fine, everything did as I wanted it to, when I wanted it. The only thing I disliked about controls was that the camera was locked when you were in a vehicle, I would have liked it to be move able so you could watch around more. but I managed to look past it and enjoy the game for what it was.
The voices were well made, sometimes you got the feeling that some of the voices did not fit in at all, but it was quickly overlooked. The game had a nice soundtrack that kept the immersion in place, and made you feel like you were in the heat of the moment. Then we have the weapon sounds, I loved the sound of the weapons in this for some reason. To me they were very realistic, and the sound of someone blowing up or being electrocuted was amusing in so many ways, that it was close to disturbing.

Conclusion:The game Rage, is a very fun game to play, if you are able to overlook the issues that I found. I enjoyed it once I overlooked the issues, and I played through the story in about 8-9 hours. For me this time was well spent, by blowing stuff to pieces, blasting them in the face with a shotgun or trying the stealthy approach with a crossbow.
If you are a person that likes the action based games where it is a lot of shooting involved, and do not mind if the story is the weak part, f

reviewText:
Good visuals, though mostly brown. Gunplay is good and most guns feel like they have a nice kick to them. The accessories(Wingstick, spider robot thing etc)  are pretty useful and the materials are easy to come by, so they aren't something you'll be saving in your inventory for specific situations and gets rid of the I don't want to use this yet" feeling which I find annoying in most games with inventory management and "gadgets".

The story has a lot of potential but it doesn't do anything interesting and you can easily lose focus of it from lack of being a good story. The ending in particular is very bad and one of the most anti-climax endings I've seen.

The AI is pretty good though and even though there will be some "poke and duck behind cover" fighting most enemies will change position to get a good shot at you. The melee enemies are especially fun to play against as they interact with the environment to move around
date: making them feel more alive than the usual enemies who just ran straight for you

You wake up 40,000 years later to find that the world fell apart because the UAC decided to use the Moxim bolts, instead of the higher quality Mixom.  You drive around in a mad max esque waste land, throwing propellers at guys, even though there are no boats. reviewText: Bad PC performance, boring, repetitive, I even heard someone mention that the sound was bad. If this game had been released today in 2015 all patched up from an indie developer - it would probably receive high praise. This thing is $20 now and you probably spent about as much to go and watch Mad Max: Fury Road... if you did I suggest you pick this game up. The graphics are fantastic (some low res here or there), the sound design is impeccable (ambient, soundtrack, environmental and combat sounds layered nicely at all times), fantastic level design - the game oozes fun. The AI, though certainly not great, is at least very interesting, the weapons are huge, feel great and look great. The buggy sounds great and feels great, the character design is great. Everything is streamlined and simplified, almost like they took an arcade racing game, Borderlands environment inspiration, added some Doom 3 elements and tried to guess what Blizzard would try and do with merging the gameplay & streamlining to make it fun, polished, intense and somewhat goofy. This game doesn't dissapoint; however, the gaming public's past attitude towards this game certainly was.

reviewText:
RAGE is another single word title game from id Software, creators of DooM and Quake. This game was the showcase for id’s Tech 5 Engine and as well as the first new IP from the company since Quake. As one would expect, RAGE is a First Person Shooter, but only part of the time. It is also a racing game at times as well as a vehicular combat game.

RAGE takes place more than 100 years after an asteroid has devastated the planet in an atmosphere that is similar to the Fallout series in some ways. You play as an Arc Survivor, a person that was placed in cryogenic suspension to be woken up after the disaster to rebuild civilization. The player isn’t the average joe by any means. He has been infused with nanotech that enables him to heal amazingly fast and even come back from the dead. First the player battles the many bandits that inhabit the Wasteland, hideous mutants and then moves on to the tyrannical high tech Authority which aims to dominate the world.

Combat in RAGE is solid and was certainly the most enjoyable part the game for me. The weapons “feel” solid and are varied. Along with different weapons are different ammunition types. Some types of ammunition increase affectedness against certain types of enemies and a few make radical changes in how the weapon will act. In addition to using weapons the player is able to construct RC Bomb Carts, Sentry Turrets and even lethal Sentry Bots to help the player out in a fight. No small amount of combat that occurs in RAGE takes place on the roads of the wastelands as you drive about. This combat can get a bit tedious at times as there is little variation in the enemies and they attack in a fairly predictable manner.

That was the good, now for the bad and that is the writing. I am not saying the writing is terrible, it gets the minimum job done. But it *only* gets the minimum job done. Most of the characters you see in the game come off as flat caricatures whose only reason to exist is to drive the story along, act as an info dump or give you a mission to accomplish. You really don’t care anything about these people. Even the ones you should care about such as Dan Hagar, the first person you meet on the game and he even saves your life. If the characters you meet in the game have any real life to them it is because the voice actor gives it to them. If Steve (Spike Spiegel) Blum can’t bring a lot of life to a character, something isn’t right.
Sometimes there are things that show up that make no real sense and can break your suspension of belief. Bandits with British or Russian accents? What? WHY? Heck, I remember one bandit complaining about how he missed Mother Russia. This is supposed to be a post-apocalyptic world. You just don’t pick up and move hundreds of people halfway across the planet without even a hint an explanation or reason.

Something that irritated me was all the references to other id games that can be found in RAGE. Now I am not totally against the practice of referencing, but there is a point where it breaks immersion. Unfortunately in RAGE they go to the point of shattering immersion into a thousand little pieces for no good reason I can see. From hidden rooms dedicated to earlier games (done in the same graphical style as the original game) to advertisements for DooM 3 or RAGE 2, to “Pinkies” a combined take off on Twinkies and the Pink Demons from DooM. You can even find the “numbers” from LOST in there as well as a “Pick up the can” scene from Half Life 2.

Probably the best illustration of the problems I see with RAGE can be found in “The Scorchers” DLC. In this we are introduced to Sarah, a member of the Hagar Clan. It seems to me that she was supposed to be a character similar Alyx Vance from Half Life 2. But if that was what id was going for, they failed and failed badly. She starts off as a very good fighter, then turns into a damsel in distress at the drop of a hat for no other reason to give the player a reason to follow the bad guys. Sarah shows more skin than just about any other female character and struts and poses like a model all the time. Worse after going through a fairly traumatic experience she shows absolutely no reaction to it other than a “Thank You”. Wut?

The main enemy of the DLC (a bandit clan called the Scorchers) has a base in some strange ruins that look like they were built by aliens. In fact I actually thought that it did take place on another planet for a while since it didn’t resemble the environment seen in all the rest of the game. The end of the DLC leaves Sarah in the Trophy Room (Yes, that is the Official Name) and never leaving. If you talk to her she will snark a little at the player though.

I guess the biggest problem I have with RAGE is that I can clearly see is that id seems to have been shooting for the next Half Life or HALO IP and they screwed it up. They had all the pieces to make a compelling universe that people would want to visit again and again, but they failed to bring those pieces together and relied on writing that is often flat and riddled with clichés. I guess the part about RAGE I dislike the most is the fact I can see the great game it could have been and is not.

Despite my complaints RAGE is a good shooter and if you are looking some good FPS combat RAGE certainly delivers. Just don’t expect much more than that. sm

reviewText:
Underrated, and disappointing at the same time. This game had a wonderful wasteland, extremely good shooting mechanics, great weapons, a fun card game, great bosses, great AI, and a lot of potential.

Sadly the game also had terrible texture issues, including poor quality and texture pop. Along with a terrible short story, no SLI support, complicated mod tools that launched late, no mod support from the community, terrible multiplayer modes, and a ton of other short comings. Had this game just been a high quality PC title with a longer campaign I would have loved it. This is not to be compared to Fallout 3, I suppose that is what I was hoping for, and one of the reasons it seemed so disappointing.

With the lack of SLI support, and terrible graphics (mainly textures), I cannot recommend this game unless it's $5~.

reviewText:
What is rage, you may ask?  Let me answer that question of yours.
The game is set in a post-apocalyptic future, where the civilization as we know it, has been destroyed by the asteroid 99942 Apophis in 2029. Survivors have created settlements and other habitable locations and have been divided into various clans and organizations of their own. Bandits and mutants constantly roam the world and try to salvage and destroy the settlements.

The story is your basic, “save the world story”. I could not get into the story of this game, it did not draw me in with anything special. I found no connections to the players actions except saving the world, but you are not greeted with an explanation to why the protagonist do the things he does. The protagonist is a mystery, who just happens to emerge and wants to save the world. I guess that you do not need more information to why you save the world, but it is a detail I would like to see, as to why the protagonist to the choices he does.

The protagonist, is an “Ark Survivor”. You emerge to the surface as the sole survivor from your Ark in 2135, and you are immediately thrown into the harsh world that is left. You are greeted by some bandits trying to salvage the wreckage of your ark, you are in an bad position as you lack weapons and equipment, but fear not because you are saved by a wasteland settler, who will teach you how the new world works. From here on it follows a linear story, where you do quest after quest which takes you further up in the world, and soon people will start to hear rumors of the “Ark Survivor”, and form here on the journey only gets harder as you try to save the world from its misery.

It is not that I disliked the story itself, I just could not find myself caught in it. I just followed the quest, did what I was told, and not long into the game I started to forget the story itself. But fear not, the story may have been weak for me but there were many other things that weighted in for it.

The gameplay itself is what lured me into this game, this is what kept me coming back to the game. It is very action based, with a lot of gun-play, and a few stealth mechanisms if you manage to pull them off.
This action is where all the fun resides. You can find yourself stuck waist-down in a firefight, with grenades flying from both sides, until you emerge victorious or die trying. But you do not actually die, since the Ark suit that you wear through the game has a built in defibrillator, so when you are about to die you enter a second chance mode, where you can revive yourself with a percentage of health and take out the enemies around you.

I found that the AI was very good, and they have some of the more interesting mechanics, comparing with other games. Bandits dodge your shoots by doing acrobats, tactically advance and fall back depending on their amount, their health and how much health I seem to have. Mutants however swarm the area around you and charge head in, towards you, and jumps around to confuse you.
There are not so many different enemies. There are three main categories, Bandits, Mutants and Authority. Each of the three has a number of different subcategories, where you find a handful of changes like, different weapons and different armor, changes in movement and size. Sure there are only three main enemies, but with the subcategories and all the changes in between the enemies, you get a very dynamic feel towards what you are fighting. There are some bosses in the game, which are a nice asset. One is the huge of a ten story apartment and takes some time taking down until you learn the tricks, and another might just be a bandit in some bulky armor shooting rockets at you. I found the bosses to be a nice change from the regular creeps that are sent at you, and they offered a nice amount of challenge, to keep it hard and interesting.

The enemies had some changes with weapons, but what do you get?  You get an arsenal of ten weapons if I am correct. At first I thought that this was not enough, that it became to repetitive running about with the weapons you had, but all of that changes soon enough, when I was introduced to different kinds of ammo and equipment. Some weapons got explosive ammo, some got electric, some even got mind-control ammo. There was so many joyful ways to take down your enemies that I had a hard time choosing which was my favorite. The game rewarded you with different types of equipment, your primary were regular grenades, but you also had EMP-grenades, wingsticks (A triple-bladed boomerang), RC cars and some other things that I did not pay so much attention to.

There was a nice amount of side quests that you could do, from eliminate, protect, save, gather, races and delivery missions. They offered a nice variation to the linear and dull story, but there was one thing that blew away all of the side missions and that was BashTV, and arena where you could fight through some of the weirdest, immerse, amusing and engaging rooms filled with mutants of all sorts. I spent a lot of time in this arena, rampaging about with my weapons as I had to dodge enemies, spinning blades from the roof, spikes from the floor, you name it.

A game cannot be perfect, while there was a lot of things that stimulated, but there were also some things were dull and for me destroyed the feeling of immersion. The first thing I have already mentioned, and that is the story. Then we have the world. From time to time the world appealed me, with how everything seemed to have adopted to the apocalyptic world, how the some areas felt unique. I found it to be way to empty from time to time, and I saw repeating patterns in how the enemy areas were made. There were no weather changes, which withdrew some of my immersion.
I also felt like the textures on the environment were to low res from time to time, and badly made, compared to the weapons, characters and vehicles. I had some trouble with the rendering from time to time as well, seemed like the textures were not loading as they should. Other than the problem I had with the look of the textures and their rendering from time to time, the game looked good. It fitted the scene of an apocalyptic world as it was supposed to, sure there was the feeling of it being to empty at certain points, but what else is there to be expected from a game like this.

The controls were completely fine, everything did as I wanted it to, when I wanted it. The only thing I disliked about controls was that the camera was locked when you were in a vehicle, I would have liked it to be move able so you could watch around more. but I managed to look past it and enjoy the game for what it was.
The voices were well made, sometimes you got the feeling that some of the voices did not fit in at all, but it was quickly overlooked. The game had a nice soundtrack that kept the immersion in place, and made you feel like you were in the heat of the moment. Then we have the weapon sounds, I loved the sound of the weapons in this for some reason. To me they were very realistic, and the sound of someone blowing up or being electrocuted was amusing in so many ways, that it was close to disturbing.

Conclusion:The game Rage, is a very fun game to play, if you are able to overlook the issues that I found. I enjoyed it once I overlooked the issues, and I played through the story in about 8-9 hours. For me this time was well spent, by blowing stuff to pieces, blasting them in the face with a shotgun or trying the stealthy approach with a crossbow.
If you are a person that likes the action based games where it is a lot of shooting involved, and do not mind if the story is the weak part, f

reviewText: Rage is a decent game, but I felt a bit disappointed with my overall experience. It has great action, nice visuals, and a decent AI; However, the game felt like it didn't live up to what I was hoping it to be. Instead of a more sandbox style game, it becomes a rather repetitive experience. Rather than seeing the fruits of you labors, the game has you go through a number of quests in a barely existant plotline that isn't rewarding on its own. I felt so disappointed with the game that I stopped playing it before I finished... something I normally never do, regardless of how bothered I was with the game

★★★★★
Love this game, second time I'm playing it 5/5 , if u love a atmospheric game that absorbs u into the action this game is definitely for u, if u like boring games where u just do the same thing over and over again go find a different game, this game has a very original feel (fallout) along with driving and a lot of fun mini-games, hell you can even play magic the gathering (a card game similar to it) really good game, the way the guns work and the AI makes this a very fun game, never knowing which way you'l get attacked from and having to attack out of instinct instead of planning how to go forwards.
