reviewText: Must admit, I enjoyed this game much more than I thought I would.  I was stunned by the quality of the graphics and character modeling (every NPC is 100% unique).  Think Fallout as a first-person shooter/racing game.  The story line is pretty generic, and there's far less content that I hoped, but what is there is great fun, especially for something that started life as a mere tech demo.  I can't stop playing Tombstones, one of the many gambling side-games available.  I sincerely hope they revisit this world and give us more to explore in the future.  I'll be waiting in line, eager for more insane dune-buggy combat!

reviewText:
What is rage, you may ask?  Let me answer that question of yours.
The game is set in a post-apocalyptic future, where the civilization as we know it, has been destroyed by the asteroid 99942 Apophis in 2029. Survivors have created settlements and other habitable locations and have been divided into various clans and organizations of their own. Bandits and mutants constantly roam the world and try to salvage and destroy the settlements.

The story is your basic, “save the world story”. I could not get into the story of this game, it did not draw me in with anything special. I found no connections to the players actions except saving the world, but you are not greeted with an explanation to why the protagonist do the things he does. The protagonist is a mystery, who just happens to emerge and wants to save the world. I guess that you do not need more information to why you save the world, but it is a detail I would like to see, as to why the protagonist to the choices he does.

The protagonist, is an “Ark Survivor”. You emerge to the surface as the sole survivor from your Ark in 2135, and you are immediately thrown into the harsh world that is left. You are greeted by some bandits trying to salvage the wreckage of your ark, you are in an bad position as you lack weapons and equipment, but fear not because you are saved by a wasteland settler, who will teach you how the new world works. From here on it follows a linear story, where you do quest after quest which takes you further up in the world, and soon people will start to hear rumors of the “Ark Survivor”, and form here on the journey only gets harder as you try to save the world from its misery.

It is not that I disliked the story itself, I just could not find myself caught in it. I just followed the quest, did what I was told, and not long into the game I started to forget the story itself. But fear not, the story may have been weak for me but there were many other things that weighted in for it.

The gameplay itself is what lured me into this game, this is what kept me coming back to the game. It is very action based, with a lot of gun-play, and a few stealth mechanisms if you manage to pull them off.
This action is where all the fun resides. You can find yourself stuck waist-down in a firefight, with grenades flying from both sides, until you emerge victorious or die trying. But you do not actually die, since the Ark suit that you wear through the game has a built in defibrillator, so when you are about to die you enter a second chance mode, where you can revive yourself with a percentage of health and take out the enemies around you.

I found that the AI was very good, and they have some of the more interesting mechanics, comparing with other games. Bandits dodge your shoots by doing acrobats, tactically advance and fall back depending on their amount, their health and how much health I seem to have. Mutants however swarm the area around you and charge head in, towards you, and jumps around to confuse you.
There are not so many different enemies. There are three main categories, Bandits, Mutants and Authority. Each of the three has a number of different subcategories, where you find a handful of changes like, different weapons and different armor, changes in movement and size. Sure there are only three main enemies, but with the subcategories and all the changes in between the enemies, you get a very dynamic feel towards what you are fighting. There are some bosses in the game, which are a nice asset. One is the huge of a ten story apartment and takes some time taking down until you learn the tricks, and another might just be a bandit in some bulky armor shooting rockets at you. I found the bosses to be a nice change from the regular creeps that are sent at you, and they offered a nice amount of challenge, to keep it hard and interesting.

The enemies had some changes with weapons, but what do you get?  You get an arsenal of ten weapons if I am correct. At first I thought that this was not enough, that it became to repetitive running about with the weapons you had, but all of that changes soon enough, when I was introduced to different kinds of ammo and equipment. Some weapons got explosive ammo, some got electric, some even got mind-control ammo. There was so many joyful ways to take down your enemies that I had a hard time choosing which was my favorite. The game rewarded you with different types of equipment, your primary were regular grenades, but you also had EMP-grenades, wingsticks (A triple-bladed boomerang), RC cars and some other things that I did not pay so much attention to.

There was a nice amount of side quests that you could do, from eliminate, protect, save, gather, races and delivery missions. They offered a nice variation to the linear and dull story, but there was one thing that blew away all of the side missions and that was BashTV, and arena where you could fight through some of the weirdest, immerse, amusing and engaging rooms filled with mutants of all sorts. I spent a lot of time in this arena, rampaging about with my weapons as I had to dodge enemies, spinning blades from the roof, spikes from the floor, you name it.

A game cannot be perfect, while there was a lot of things that stimulated, but there were also some things were dull and for me destroyed the feeling of immersion. The first thing I have already mentioned, and that is the story. Then we have the world. From time to time the world appealed me, with how everything seemed to have adopted to the apocalyptic world, how the some areas felt unique. I found it to be way to empty from time to time, and I saw repeating patterns in how the enemy areas were made. There were no weather changes, which withdrew some of my immersion.
I also felt like the textures on the environment were to low res from time to time, and badly made, compared to the weapons, characters and vehicles. I had some trouble with the rendering from time to time as well, seemed like the textures were not loading as they should. Other than the problem I had with the look of the textures and their rendering from time to time, the game looked good. It fitted the scene of an apocalyptic world as it was supposed to, sure there was the feeling of it being to empty at certain points, but what else is there to be expected from a game like this.

The controls were completely fine, everything did as I wanted it to, when I wanted it. The only thing I disliked about controls was that the camera was locked when you were in a vehicle, I would have liked it to be move able so you could watch around more. but I managed to look past it and enjoy the game for what it was.
The voices were well made, sometimes you got the feeling that some of the voices did not fit in at all, but it was quickly overlooked. The game had a nice soundtrack that kept the immersion in place, and made you feel like you were in the heat of the moment. Then we have the weapon sounds, I loved the sound of the weapons in this for some reason. To me they were very realistic, and the sound of someone blowing up or being electrocuted was amusing in so many ways, that it was close to disturbing.

Conclusion:The game Rage, is a very fun game to play, if you are able to overlook the issues that I found. I enjoyed it once I overlooked the issues, and I played through the story in about 8-9 hours. For me this time was well spent, by blowing stuff to pieces, blasting them in the face with a shotgun or trying the stealthy approach with a crossbow.
If you are a person that likes the action based games where it is a lot of shooting involved, and do not mind if the story is the weak part, f

reviewText:
Almost four years on and I finally gave this game a fair run through. It took me 18 hours of in-game time to complete including the Scorchers DLC with all side quests done and the pre-order Sewers DLC. Before this I could only play the first two hours before losing interest and moving on or the horrible texture pop-ins becoming a serious issue. The last time I played previous to this attempt was in 2012.

It's a shame. On release RAGE was an absolute mess especially on PC. The way id handled it was poor at best and really got under the skin of PC gamers. Both nVidia and AMD cards struggled trying to run the game in a presentable state and had severe texture pop-in issues which made the game unplayable on most machines. id's response to this was to point fingers and blame GPU drivers despite the fact that the game was basically built for GPU Transcoding which is primary to nVidia cards and was essential at the time for reducing texture pop-in. Despite this fact there was still an issue with nVidia cards which supported the feature. As for AMD users they were left in the dark even with high end GPUs. Simply put the game was in a sorry state on release and made worse by id's unappologethic attitude while also giving the middle finger to the PC platform at the same time in saying PC wasn't considered a Prime platform." This coupled with the non-existent graphics options in the game was an utter slap to the face for many gamers.

To understand just how bad this game was on release and the lack of simple graphical options this video sums up perfectly what many of us had to deal with on release.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mLuOtGwLnzQ

These issues are still there to this day on even high end GPUs although they are nowhere near as bad as shown in the video above and there are some graphics options that have been patched in.

Having just beaten the game i'm really disappointed that RAGE didn't pick up. It's obvious it was overshadowed by the technical problems it faced on release and the rather boring and uninspired combat presented to you in the beginning. For the first two hours the game is lackluster and completely boring
date: not because the world isn't interesting or there's nothing to really do but because the gunplay is so ineffective making you really dread playing the game. Fortunately -- or rather unfortunately -- the gunplay picks up considerably and becomes much more rewarding and fun to play when you get a few different weapons you can use but this comes a couple of hours into the campaign. For the base weapon you're given early in the game and how limited you are on cash and ammo starting out this game really isn't enjoyable for the first few hours. This is because all enemies no matter the difficulty are basically bullet sponges no matter where you hit them. Headshots won't one shot
recommended: they'll deal a lot of damage but they won't straight out kill an enemy but knock them back and require a second headshot to finish them with the pistol. It's extremely frustrating to have to sink about twenty bullets into an enemy to take them down.\n\nWhen the game opens up and you have access to RPGs

those first two hours of gameplay aren't great. id really dropped the ball here). The mission and level design are top notch later on in the game. There's opportunity for stealth kills in most levels and not much repetition in enemies. It's not simply wave after wave in each area but more of a scripted experience which is fine for a game like this. The repeats of levels are different and not lazily slapped together of "Go in and do this again but find item X or kill person Y." Once you beat an area it'll change according to the story so you'll see different enemy types and different spawns entirely with most levels being done in reverse so as not to feel like a flat out repeated process of the first time you completed the level.

The story is solid but there are pacing issues most likely due to the cut content because of the XBox 360 restrictions(The game was supposed to cover 4 Wastelands but had to be cut down to 2). For one you don't really learn much of anything about the current situation instead you're just helping the local people deal with their problems which sends you to bandit camps and mutant lairs to retrieve specific story related items or to investigate strange goings on. This gives you a good feel for the politics of the wasteland and how harsh and inhospitable the wasteland is which is a good thing.

Your own story isn't really integrated into the main story which is a problem. In-game you never really find out who you are but in terms of lore and background

reviewText:
I was actually in rage when this game came out. It was full of glitches and id software released a game with barely any graphics options to choose from in the main menu. Websites popped-up around the net to provide advice as to how to change the graphics settings by modifying the game's cfg file. I hated this - this was not user friendly and also even to check small changes you needed to quit and relaunch the game again and again.

After a while some patches were released and corrected these issues of the game. RAGE, by the way, has a very mediocre story and in my opinion Bethesda being the publisher here did not help the case. You are a survivor after an asteroid almost completely annihilates mankind. Just before the catastrophe a handful of people - scientists, soldiers and other high rank personnel - were frozen and put in a so-called ark that was taken below ground levels. Many years after the event you wake up as your ark automatically hits the surface. You realise everybody else from your team perished and you are the sole survivor. You are immediately attacked by mutants and then saved by a stranger. He takes you to his settlement and the game practically starts.

There are several small towns where you can interact with a lot of people. There are dozens of side missions to complete and a couple of minigames, as well. So, as opposed to what we got used to in previous id software games RAGE now follows a non-linear path. Completing sidemissions earns you money which you can use to purchase new weapons or upgrades to your equipment. In addition to this there are races you can participate in. You have your own vehicle and beside the races you can use this to go from one town to the next. I liked how smoothly the developers completed this - transitioning from the FPS perspective to the camera-behind-the-car view happens smoothly. There are really no loading times; getting in and out of your vehicle happens fast.

There are two things where RAGE shines, in my opinion:

1) Art design: Some of the places you venture through look amazing. An example: You need to go to Dead City to acquire an object. You climb narrow steps in-between huge, collapsed multistorey buildings. You truly get the feeling of a post-apocalyptic setting here. You race in vast wastelands, go down to the sewers to eradicate mutants, participate in a mutant reality show, go through deadly caves in the Scorchers DLC etc. Textures could have been more of high quality nature, still, the game's art design compensates for this.

2) Combat: I loved Doom and Quake for their weapons. And how good it was to eliminate waves of enemies. RAGE delivers the very same experience. Enemies hide behind cover and they react realistically: headshots do count and in case you shoot them in the leg they stumble and fall. Some run at you with clubs only and you think it is easy to get rid of them but you realise that you cannot hit them: they do somersault and jump on and off walls and drive you mad. Also, all weapons are valuable. Remember how quickly we stopped using a pistol in Doom? As the minigun used the same ammunition. Or simply because weapons obtained later on were more efficient. In RAGE each weapon has different ammunition types and some upgrades, as well. Believe it or not - the pistol is one of the strongest weapons in the hands of a good shooter. You can craft a very strong bullet that can easily eliminate bigger foes with some good aimed headshots.

RAGE can remind gamers of old-school shooters. If you look at it like that you can enjoy this game from start to finish. I am not saying my expectations weren't higher for an id game but following my initial disappointment I gradually came to like this game. Although the story is mediocre and the game has a disappointing end and a short DLC, it is a highly recommended FPS game.

reviewText:
For years many First-Person shooter RPG Hybrids taken place in some wasteland has been for many of us just a regular tradition each year. With the release of Fallout and even earlier games have made it fun; Rage took up the reins of 2011 for the wasteland First-Person shooter game. Does it stack up as good as the others such as Fallout? Or would it be lost forever, post-apocalyptic style?

Story/Design: The story goes that in 2029 the real life meteorite Apophis is on a direct collision mark with Earth and nearly causes mass extinction; however with the world taking precautions they start to send out volunteers in Arks with cryo-genetic hibernation. It didn't go so well, and you are the only survivor of your own particular Ark. After 106 years off that, you step out in the world for the first type, post-apocalypse...Sound familiar? Anyway, the game starts out with a great starting cinematic, yet the story is only decent, if not weak. It takes time that you can try and change the story in general and find out what exactly happened to all the other Arks. The starting point is extremely slow and it took me real motivation to try and push through it in the first hours and not completely stop the game. . Furthermore, just before the game starts to heat up and get you interested it abruptly ends. The ending is certainly jarring (and extremely disappointing) it could serve as a quality story based DLC. The game is quite beautiful though, it honestly depends on your PC though, just like any other game. With the new id tech 5 engine they say it doesn't use any of the same textures twice which is nice; however, this means that your graphics will change once you rotate the camera and will load in accordingly. This can mean textures take in at least a full second or two to load in and can make some gamers lag. It's beautiful, but as a closer look in towns you realize how fuzzy and low-style they are. Overall, I'd like to get this through to everyone, if you're buying Rage then you should NOT be buying it for the story, it's slow and disappointing and forgettable. The textures are nice while driving around, yet in towns it can a whole second or two to load in at least a simple one.

Gameplay/Mechanics: This is obviously a First-Person shooter. And I'd like to say that this is a game based off its shooting mechanics and it does a fantastic job of it. It feels smooth enough and has multiple guns to choose from. The game is also a RPG mixed game, obviously trying to take from other wasteland style of games, but is nowhere near as complex as say Fallout, or even a few mechanics of Borderlands. It results in using different type of ammo, selling and trading items, building things with objects for opening doors and other objects. It's simple yet does well. It also has quests and side quests to do multiple things along with just running around, killing, or just collecting. Racing and vehicle combat is also a big part of the game, races are critical to upgrading your vehicle. The driving controls are odd though, realistic they are not and you must keep using it to feel comfortable behind the wheel. The FPS feel is great and well done, the RPG elements are simple yet for some groups can be just what they want, with more experienced RPG players it will seems a bit too simplistic for them. The vehicle combat is actually fun and is a key thing from the game. It's a fun game to play but as I said, just to play, not to hear about the story.

Rage is a game not based on story; it tries and fails with disappointment. The combat and gameplay is fun and engaging. The wasteland is beautiful yet with the hiccups it might seem like an aesthetic blemish to some, yet game breaking for others. It's an above-average FPS shooter, but it's just that. Slightly above average, the same bland story as some, and not memorable as I had to force and push myself to get through it. If you want a good FPS, without good story then you can try to get this on sale. If you want story...you're going to need to find something else.

6.8/10

reviewText:
First of all, i dont wana teach people how to write reviews or match rating with the written review.. but i must say that imo 2 points out of 10 are a question of personal taste. Not only that, but i must also say that you can review black without knowing white, same goes for saying x is great if y doesnt exist... this means that rating is possible and legit when you compare to other games in its category or atleast with similarities... With this said... i give this game a 10 and i am surprised with the low rating and reviews...

Where can i start? well with the fact that, this is a bethesda game... so to those complaining about graphics.. they are perfect to me.. if you want a game to escape your CoD or Battlefield addiction dont low rate a good quality game just because graphics arent similar... On the same road, i must say that i am surprised that this marvelous fps game is from bethesda, since they are renowned for their rpgs. So it was indeed a great positive surprise for me...

The shooting is great, the combat smooth, the whole idea of wasteland violence and surprise attacks is just... 10... right of the bat i got spooked out with a bandit jumping on me. The fact that ammo keeps running low is also good imo, since it adds to the difficulty (which may i say, scales awesomely well... hard to see a fps with such a great difficulty scaling(usually its either dumb dummies or headshot bots))
The vehicle combat is really fun and interesting. Side quests (even though it is not an rpg) exist and are great.helpful and fun...

Now... to all negative reviews.. i just gota say that, ofcourse you cant compare this game to cod or battlefield.. this game has a great story, and alot more than mere shooting, its bethesda... Comparing it to fallout is also silly, even though both are bethesda and involves wastelands, 1 is a rpg and the other fps with little rpg elements. I must say that this is also a great point for this game, the rpg elements are genious... they are just enough to maintain fps status but still give some extra stuff to do and work on.

This game cannot be compared to Stalker also... Stalker is also fps true, but has way more elements of rpg.. Its a great game also, BUT simply cannot be compared to RAGE. Whole different ideas, 1 has intense combat which is cohesive to the fact that you are being hunted down, the other is honest and loyal to the idea that you are a stalker... and therefore is just existing like other stalkers (scavenging)

Compare this game to metro last light... which as i reviewed... is really really unfinished. Compare both games... both fps, both of them are post apocalyptical games and both pursue the idea of intense combat. However... metro has no side quests, no minimum rpg elements... many strings that you pull only to realise there is nothing on the other end...

Rage does have a story and its pretty linear... you cant simply cant get lost... if you get lost playing rage.. you should stick to basic left to right games.. STILL it manages to give you room to work on smaller stuff.. Yes the story aint deep... but tell me 5 fps games that get you immersed in its story....

I sincerly find it pretty sad, to see critics unable to match their writing to their number rating. Even more to see players and pro critics alike comparing this game to cod when it comes to shooting and graphics and story to other bethesda rpg games... seriously... giving metro last joke a 8 and this game a 4.8 user rating is just ridiculous.... If you played stalker or metro the joke and like post apocalyptical fps games... Rage is an awesome surprise... dont trust ratings from people who compare it wrongly... just give it a chance... its bethesda ffs.... ID made great game aswell... why on earth wouldnt you try it?

Oh and to all bug this.. crash that... graphic that seriously... people dont downvote jokes like darksouls for its pathetic almost unplayable pc version but will downvote this because it has better graphics on console?!? ilogical imo... The game runs fine... if by any chance you think its lagish due to low fps
recommended: go to options and there you shall find video options that you can change... judging by what i see on many reviews

reviewText:
RAGE was delivered as a fresh new franchise (on release) which is developed and published from id software, and as a huge long-time id fan there was no question of me getting this title. It's set in a post-apocolyptic world (somewhat of a cliche' these days), and you're one of the last people from before this time preserved with microscopic nanites flowing through your blood. There's a high price to the Authority and the Rebels for you and/or your head.

Although the high res graphics are locked out (which you can change through internet research), and it was off to a sketchy release loaded with issues - but then why should you trust any developer on release or close to on PC titles?

The game looks nice, performs well and introduces some nice mechanics. It presents a challenge and has a nice story which you can believe and immerse yourself in. For me personally, I loved the Rebar gun which was a part of the DLC package on Steam. The rebar gun launches a solid stick of ~400mm rebar or rio as we call it in Australia, and it can pin opponents to nearly any object, it can take heads off, it can take out multiple enemies with a really well placed shot, and it will terminate larger opponents with a couple of well placed shots - it does however take only one piece of rebar and reload speeds are slow. You are able to recover the rebar once launched, and it is the star of the game, so much fun.

It is however very linear in the campaign, but once you're off campaign there's much more freedom. There are a lot of annoying invisible walls, and the trading/shop seems a little tedious if you want to be well stocked at all times, but you can compete in an array of races to gain some currency.

Overall it is a fantastic game, but for the average user I wouldn't rush about to complete it. If you're into FPS games and/or into id software's style I would say it's a must own. When you get a chance, make sure you enjoy this title - there'll be another one on the way once DOOM is released next year!

reviewText:
For me the only frustrations that arose with RAGE surrounded the fact that it comes so close to greatness.

A troubled PC launch seemed to kill the multiplayer community and the DLC adds little to the experience.  Yet even the limp ending and slim illusion of player freedom cannot hide the fact that ID know all about shooting things in the face.  That is where the fun is to be had in this game; shoot all of the things, then throw spiderbots, turrets and boomerangs into the mix.

The world and character design are enjoyable, although you never really interact with them in a meaningful way.  Whilst the racing and mini games are briefly entertaining, they prove to be little more than resource grinding.  RAGE also harbours RPG and crafting pretensions that do not get in the way, but feel strangely unimportant as a result.  If any one of these elements worked as well as the shooting, ID would have been on to a real winner here.  Just imagine what this could have been like if they had nailed them all......

As it stands, RAGE has a solid core hidden amongst elements that either time, money or skill (all three?) prevented from truly coming together as a whole.  Seven out of ten seems fair, perhaps the ambition sends it a point either side of that mark, depending on how you take to the games weaker elements.

Should ID have focused their effort a little better?  Perhaps; the game shines when played with a controller and employing a gung ho approach to ammo and resource expenditure, as the title would seem to suggest.  It's just a shame that other aspects of the game never hit those heights.

reviewText: The two best genres of any game come together in this post apocalyptic video game.  The racing is first rate and the survivor horror first person shooter elements make this one of the most unique games I've played.  Learning how potentially reacts to the aftermath of a giant meteor impact on the earth is intriguing.  I love the upgrade system that they included for your vehicles.  I also love seeing how people react to an opressive government.  Going through each mission with caution never knowing what lies behind the next cornter makes it all the more excitng.  This game is a must for all of you science fiction fans out there.

reviewText:
First of all, i dont wana teach people how to write reviews or match rating with the written review.. but i must say that imo 2 points out of 10 are a question of personal taste. Not only that, but i must also say that you can review black without knowing white, same goes for saying x is great if y doesnt exist... this means that rating is possible and legit when you compare to other games in its category or atleast with similarities... With this said... i give this game a 10 and i am surprised with the low rating and reviews...

Where can i start? well with the fact that, this is a bethesda game... so to those complaining about graphics.. they are perfect to me.. if you want a game to escape your CoD or Battlefield addiction dont low rate a good quality game just because graphics arent similar... On the same road, i must say that i am surprised that this marvelous fps game is from bethesda, since they are renowned for their rpgs. So it was indeed a great positive surprise for me...

The shooting is great, the combat smooth, the whole idea of wasteland violence and surprise attacks is just... 10... right of the bat i got spooked out with a bandit jumping on me. The fact that ammo keeps running low is also good imo, since it adds to the difficulty (which may i say, scales awesomely well... hard to see a fps with such a great difficulty scaling(usually its either dumb dummies or headshot bots))
The vehicle combat is really fun and interesting. Side quests (even though it is not an rpg) exist and are great.helpful and fun...

Now... to all negative reviews.. i just gota say that, ofcourse you cant compare this game to cod or battlefield.. this game has a great story, and alot more than mere shooting, its bethesda... Comparing it to fallout is also silly, even though both are bethesda and involves wastelands, 1 is a rpg and the other fps with little rpg elements. I must say that this is also a great point for this game, the rpg elements are genious... they are just enough to maintain fps status but still give some extra stuff to do and work on.

This game cannot be compared to Stalker also... Stalker is also fps true, but has way more elements of rpg.. Its a great game also, BUT simply cannot be compared to RAGE. Whole different ideas, 1 has intense combat which is cohesive to the fact that you are being hunted down, the other is honest and loyal to the idea that you are a stalker... and therefore is just existing like other stalkers (scavenging)

Compare this game to metro last light... which as i reviewed... is really really unfinished. Compare both games... both fps, both of them are post apocalyptical games and both pursue the idea of intense combat. However... metro has no side quests, no minimum rpg elements... many strings that you pull only to realise there is nothing on the other end...

Rage does have a story and its pretty linear... you cant simply cant get lost... if you get lost playing rage.. you should stick to basic left to right games.. STILL it manages to give you room to work on smaller stuff.. Yes the story aint deep... but tell me 5 fps games that get you immersed in its story....

I sincerly find it pretty sad, to see critics unable to match their writing to their number rating. Even more to see players and pro critics alike comparing this game to cod when it comes to shooting and graphics and story to other bethesda rpg games... seriously... giving metro last joke a 8 and this game a 4.8 user rating is just ridiculous.... If you played stalker or metro the joke and like post apocalyptical fps games... Rage is an awesome surprise... dont trust ratings from people who compare it wrongly... just give it a chance... its bethesda ffs.... ID made great game aswell... why on earth wouldnt you try it?

Oh and to all bug this.. crash that... graphic that seriously... people dont downvote jokes like darksouls for its pathetic almost unplayable pc version but will downvote this because it has better graphics on console?!? ilogical imo... The game runs fine... if by any chance you think its lagish due to low fps
recommended: go to options and there you shall find video options that you can change... judging by what i see on many reviews
hoursPlayed: this is apparently really hard to do..."

reviewText:
Nice game concept and post-apocalyptic game-world but the eye straining style just tickles my brain, in a bad way. After about a hour of playing i had to take a break because i felt nauseous and my eye's felt dry. It's the same strain level as Jazz Jackrabbit... The controls are a bit dodgy, the feeling of a bad PC port is big in this game. By tapping the strafe button you take a big step to the side instead of a normal step in all of the other FPS's so the controls can be called quite bulky, invisible walls are used almost as much as in the old-school Medal of honor titles which means that you will encounter allot of these, and the inventory system is just bad, you can clearly see that it was designed for a controller. The texture loads a bit slow, so be prepared for allot of texture loads while you play.

Overall the weapons and character models look nice, the intro sucked me right into the game and atmosphere but as soon as the game really began it lost all of its charm. It's worth the 5 euro's i spend on it but if it is above this price i would spend the money on a game like Fallout 3 since this is a better alternative.

After playing for 90 minutes i rate it a 6,5/10, mainly due to the dodgy controls and eye straining style. This also gets my Bad port" stamp of disapproval."

reviewText:
One of the most beautiful & horrible looking game I've ever seen. Looks great until it comes under scrutiny. I bought this on sale for very cheap since I ignored it on release because of it's early issues. I found it to be a solid FPS with some great driving mechanics (although driving didn't really rock my boat). Not a bad story and a couple of wow moments. The ending, although poor, looks to feed into part 2 so I would've forgiven it.. I can't see Rage 2 coming, so unforgiven :)

Buy Rage when it's 3 or 4 quid and it's bob on.

I did speed to the end as I had something else on the go, still took me 16 hours to push the main story. I would have gone back to finish the side quests if I'd got the option but the game denies you access once the credits roll, DLC fixes this I am told and even more DLC gives you a better and more fitting endgame.

All in all; fair to good, 7 lollipops out of 10.

reviewText:
Rage is lacking. I did enjoy some of its parts, but mostly it was just that feeling of unused potential.

Pros:
-	I liked the fighting system, weapons felt okay
-	Locations were well-made
-	Plot was a bit blunt but turned out okay
-	Ability to drive vehicles – I enjoyed that part of the game the most (I always missed that in Fallouts)
-	Games world’s atmosphere similar to Fallout’s (but definitely inferior in all the aspects)
-	Cities were alright
-       I like the graphics

Cons –
-	Boring races… Seriously that could have been done much, much better…
-	Bandits on the roads – annoying
-	Not opened world (something that only pretended to be opened, but was really few closed locations connected by closed roads)
-	World was boring and too small
-	TOO SHORT! Game ended so suddenly…
-	Compatibility problems – some of the add ons made my game to crush in my native language (was okay when I changed to English)
-	Dreary NPC
-	Gameplay “on rails” – no choice where to go or what to do… Just go forward with what game had for you.
-	Side quest were… boring…

Conclusion,
Well, I expected something better…. But maybe my expectations were just a bit too high after playing in masterpieces like Fallout 3 or New Vegas.

RATING 3.50/10

reviewText:
Let's start immediately with the only thing I didn't like: weak finale. Really? Come on Id, you've a long list of weak finales (quake, quake2,doom3 was better though) but this is probably the weakest.

Ok. Cons list done. Apart from that, Rage is probably a MASTERPIECE. You start being an old-era apocalypse survivor and, before you have enough time to understand what's happening you're diving in a BEAUTIFUL post-apocalyptic HUGE scenario. A world, so various that goes from broken highways to dead cities, filthy sewers and many many more.

Graphics, The detail is UNBELIEVABLE, every single aspect of every map is placed carefully and planned deeply. You can almost smell the garbage in wasted garage or gasoline in Shrouded Bunker. It's awesome how level designers pay attention to every single insignificant detail. Beautiful. I didn't see any popping artifacts, I must say, Probably because my video card is very old engine just decides to use low texture by default (most of all in Dead City level apparently), which it's ok for me.

Gameplay, It's id, come on, Obviously the best in town. Every shot you fire it seems that really hurts enemies, and their bodies react with damage + previous movement so it really seems that a running mutant, coming after you, after been shot to death, has still some inertia to die in front of you making two more steps. This is art, imo.
I noticed they add a little RPG" addition

reviewText: One of my favorite games thus far. Yes, it's old(ish). Yes, it's linear. Yes, it's hella fun. Whether I was blasting mutants with a shotgun or tearing it up in a rocket ralley, this game never failed to keep me entertained. I'd give it a 9/10 for the wingsticks alone. It's a great game with a great story that I haven't forgotten since I beat it two years ago. id postboned Rage 2 for DOOM, so hopefully we will see a Rage 2 at an E3 down the road. Great game, I highly recomend it.

reviewText:
Seriously... BORING UNEVENTFUL STORY.

I actively wished the entire game to have a CHOICE in ANYTHING, especially being able to side with the so-called 'authority' because they got cool armor and seemed to have some sembelance of an idea what the hell they were doing.

I do not recommend this game for someone who wants:
1) A good storyline with a thorough ending.
2) Interesting characters you can interact with
3) An open world

Additionally, if you DO NOT want the following; beware:
1) Racing is REQUIRED in the main storyline. (I do okay in racing games and was able to complete them, but I do not like them)
2) a couple mini bosses but no real skill requirement to fight anything
3) Endless random vendor trash to sell for no apparent reason.
4) Endless ammo if you so choose.
5) Enemies which while having some intelligence, still seem to put their back to you when you throw a grenade at them. (seriously, just watched 2 people run around cover and turn to face the grenade with me looking at them... smart.)
6) A lack of 'fun guns' to play with. Ultimately, I ended up using the shotgun almost the entire game because using 'Pop Rockets' (grenade ammo) is simply the only weapon I found enjoyable, side for shooting mutants with an assault rifle and then slamming them in the face with melee. (other than this, wingsticks were my only other weapon choice)

-Some BACKGROUND:
I played RAGE originally back in 2012 and after getting bored with it, I stopped playing. This was after about 2 hours of the game and I had not completed the game.

Then, again in 2014 I picked up the game again (figuratively) and played past the part I stopped at previously. Again, I became bored out of my mind and uninstalled it.
Finally, in 2016 I finished it.

Yes, I was bored with an id game. Three times now. I only beat the game to prove I could and... dear god it was still a waste of my time. (Surprisingly, yes I always enjoyed Doom 1,2 and 3, also played the original wolfenstein games and commander keen. So, I love id and I think they have a great staff.)

Sadly, this game has dissappointed me greatly. When I first picked it up, read the cover and thought back to the trailers; I said My
date: this would rock if it's anything like what is described." That is simply not the case.\n\nI was hopeful of a Fallout3/NewVegas with a doom atmosphere
recommended: because out of everything I want a survival horror wasteland game if I can get one. (Even if doom is a bit shooty ;-)\n\nRegardless

reviewText:
I'm a decent way in to the game now - got all the gear, fairly certain where the end game is headed. I definitely have a good feel for the features and style of the game, and while I've selected yes - I do recommend the game - that comes with several important caveats.

iD have created a shooter with some really interesting ideas in RAGE. Unfortunately, it suffers from a stunning lack of ideas in many important respects, also - most of which have to do with the actual playing of the game. It's very old fashioned, in many ways, which you may view as a good thing if you're nostalgic for FPS games of old. Weapons assigned to number buttons, 1-10? Check. Unlock them in sequence, just as they're needed? Check. Tight corridors and fast enemies for shotgun splooshing? Check. Open spaces and cover loving baddies for sniper or machine gun play? Check. Oh, and here's a crossbow. Because crossbow.

The enemies, while spouting some interesting dialogue, are of very limited variety, models reused with alarming frequency. Likewise, their move sets are limited. The challenge arises here in presenting you with more enemies, or sometimes enemies with higher hit points, than in providing smarter baddies. I can't think of a single interesting villian - or hero, for that matter - in the game so far. The characters are massively cliché. Attempts at making the world intimidating, or even horrifying in terms of things you see in bandit camps, are immediately undone by slapstick bad guys with cartoonish animation. Also, it's always jarring to be lectured endlessly about the dangers of this horrifying world, how every step outside the secure towns is taking your life in your hands as hordes of unspeakable monstrosities await the frothy goodness of your very blood...and then to saunter from place to place on a quad bike or stupidly heavily armed buggy without so much as an insult shouted from a nearby hillock. RAGE is not a dangerous world. Glasgow pubs are, literally and figuratively, more dangerous than RAGE.

This is a game with too many ideas, some of which conflict stylistically with each other. And despite, or perhaps because of, the implementation of these ideas, other things are just left to the side. The world is very small, with some areas getting reused numerous times, just filled with different baddies. There's no true free roaming, in that you follow a limited set of canyons to a few major hubs. Occasionally you blow up a dam, or other obstruction, to unlock new canyons and a new hub. Quests are just places to go and collect things, with set pieces all along the way. A little bit on rails for a modern shooter.

RAGE also features an incredibly annoying set of outdated features which aren't directly related to the gameplay. ALL the button prompts are for xBox controllers, even if one isn't hooked up. I know it's a console port, but that's just lazy and off-putting, and the mapping for controls is far from explicit about what the assigned key will do. The game actually prompts you to save on some occasions (only seen this in DLC missions so far, to be fair), stating that The action is about to HOT up

reviewText:
So I'm gonna try to keep this short and sweet.

I really liked this game it was a great FPS with more ways to kill than just unloading into a guy the weapon selection and execution was one of the best I have ever seen and the way your enemies react to them is perfection.
The story is linear but it's done the right way and keeps you pretty well immersed in the game the side missions are fun but do get a bit repetitive.
The graphics are decent, My PC is no where near that great so it was a little rough for me but not game breaking and the controls are great I played mostly with a gamepad but did use the mouse and keyboard some as well.
The mani complaint I have about the game is the ending, the final battle wast really anything special I expected something pretty big after talking to NPC's and given the gun I was given was ridiculously huge but it was quite a let down when the fight was over and the cutscene started. As for the ending cutscene it was good and I did like it but I wish they would have shown more and explained it better and also acknowledged the fact that you had beaten The Authority after it goes back to the game to let you finish anything you wanted to do.

All in all the game was great and I really liked it despite the ending seeming like they just wanted to be done with it.
I do reccomend it to anyone that likes the FPS and post apocalptic style games as his was a different spin on a great genre.

8/10

reviewText:
In this game you can carry 10 weapons (and probably unlimited ammo)  and shoot mutants along with  high-tech supersoldiers in a postapocalyptic world. You can also be a race driver with your very own cars.

Pro:
The combat system is excellent (these guys made the Doom series..), and I must mention, that the enemy death and combat  animations are exemplary. If I shoot somebody in the stomach, he falls to the ground, then drags himself to the nearest cover, and prepares to die. But he's still alive, so until then, shoots some bullet at you. If I hit somebody's feet, it limps, like in reality. You can be an engineer and construct items such as sentry bots and turrets. These bots are overpowered in my opinion, you can spawn 2 at the same time, and they clear the area for you. The races are exciting, but won the first place always at the first try. The minigames are also cool. Never facede any bugs (fell off the map once, but it was my fault).

Contra:
However, you can't really jump. Apart from the race fields, the whole game is very linear. You go into a building through the front door,  kick some ♥♥♥ inside, then return to that door again. And almost every single mission is like this.  The characters are boring, but their mimics and gestures are detailed. The textures sometimes look correct, but when they don't, they're ugly and low detailed. You have to save manually, because the game saves only at the beginning and the end of the mission. Forgot that when I started, and had to start again a mission.

This game offers much more then 25 hours of content, in overall, it's a great FPS. If it has 75% off, or more, don't hesitate, buy it!

reviewText:
I have read pretty much everything and its opposite about that game. So I wanted to write a review, to try to give a comprehensive list of the pros/cons of that game.

First of all, this game is NOT a Role Playing Game. Of course, like every single game, it can fit into its definition, since you play the role of a character in an imaginary world. Now, it is not what is conventionally accepted as a RPG. This game has no character levels, it has no skills, it has no skill-tree either of course, and so on.

This game is a shooter. By the people who invented the genre, id Software. Now, if it is from the people who invented the genre, how can it only have a User Score of 49" (at the time of writing) on metacritic? The reason is simple: this game is really different from what id Software usually does (or did. I did not play
recommended: all the id Software shooters; but I played Doom and Quake).\n\nSo

what are the pros and the cons?

reviewText:
This game shows off what id does best: technology and shooting.  As an FPS, it's top notch.  The guns feel great and the enemy AI is fantastic.  Each type of enemy behaves differently and gives you nice variety throughout the game.  When you go out into the open world, the vehicles feel great and combat is solid.  id also did a great job modestly expanding their usual game archetype with driving, missions, and crafting.  And most surprising, the voice acting, sound, and music are top notch.

On the technology side, it is nothing short of groundbreaking.  It had a rough launch mostly due to driver issues which have since been resolved;  Now everybody can enjoy the entirely hand-painted world (check out my screenshots).  Of course the downside is, since every texture is unique, things don't look so great close-up.  But I choose to enjoy the game rather than look for faults and it's just amazing my computer can crank out 60 fps when it looks so good.

Just don't expect a fantastic story.

I'd also like to add how impressed I am with the DLC.  It costs $5 and has more content than most $10 DLCs while maintaining the same high quality as the rest of the game.  id managed to integrate the DLC seamlessly with the rest of the story so you never feel like you're actually playing a DLC.  The only real change is that the DLC content is significantly harder than most of the rest of the game.  I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoyed RAGE.

reviewText:
Where to begin… So as stated on the box art: RAGE, from the creators of doom and quake. This would seem promising considering this game comes from the creators of two of the best series of all time, but does it really? The answer is no… RAGE falls way short of even being somewhat decent. Here are the reasons I found RAGE to be a complete disappointment and the only rage that came from this experience is the rage that I now have towards id software. Shame because id software was my favorite developer.

And just a fyi, my pc is perfectly compatible to play anything you throw at it, Tomb Raider, Bioshock Infinite, Dishonored, Shadow Warrior (2013) and Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army 2 all work on the highest settings without a problem.

First of all, the graphics… I’m sure we all have heard the nightmare about the graphics being terrible, but let me be more specific. Long story short, the game wasn’t programmed correctly. For example, when I look at something, it will take a few seconds before the textures load in, then I’ll look somewhere else and those textures do the same thing, then I look back at the first place and those textures have to load BACK in. Please explain the logic in this game, the textures are not supposed to vanish when you look away, they’re supposed to stay there until you are far away or have loaded another map. Aside from this, the textures are a very low quality/low resolution. So even after the textures are loaded 5 seconds after you look at them, they still look ugly anyway. I have seen various solutions to fix all of this, and none of them have worked; although the game should be programmed correctly so you don’t even have to waste your time on this. Is it really too much to ask for? All we want is a game that we can load up and be ready to play, we don’t want to spent 2 hours trying various solutions just to get the stupid game to work. Then to top all this off, considering there so many problems with textures popping in, we are also given the worst problem of all… lag. As I said before, my pc has more than enough power to run this game. I can play Bioshock Infinite and Tomb Raider on the highest settings with no problem, but I can’t play RAGE (a game that’s 2 years older) on even the lowest settings. So good job id software, I’m sure you’re very proud of yourselves; you successfully created a game that is nearly unplayable.

So aside from the game looking like something you found in the back of the refrigerator from 3 months ago, and the game running like a truck with cement tires…. that are shaped like squares, maybe the actually game play will be fun?…… Who am I kidding, they can’t even get the game to run properly, why on earth would the actual game be fun? I will admit, the first 2 hours were certainly fun, brought back memories of the classic id software games, just with horrible graphics. But then after the 2 hours of the fun shooting/exploring/collecting, it decides to take a rather stupid turn in events. First of all, the entire aspect of driving just literally killed the game. I didn’t come here to drive a buggy that explodes every 5 min and am forced to upgrade and waste all the money I just spent 4 hours collecting. If id software wanted to make a driving game, then they should of made a driving game. There is a reason we have different genre’s of games, not so that we can take each genre and awkwardly merge them together that does nothing but fills you with rage *cough cough* So aside from the stupid driving/vehicle upgrade monstrosity, ok lets go shoot things! “NO TO HELL WITH THAT” says id software, “HOW ABOUT YOU GO DELIVER MAIL INSDEAD!” yes this is correct, after 3 hours, the shooting completely stops and you find yourself delivering mail and doing other completely stupid/boring/uneventful tasks. After many hours I had absolutely no use for my weapons and the game didn’t even let me carry them (I guess they disappeared to Narnia) Long story short; the game play sucks, it’s probably better to just replay the first 2 hours a few times then go buy another game.

So what’s left? Oh, yes, the story….. *falls on the ground laughing* yea there’s absolutely no reason to even talk about that.

So taking everything into consideration, we have a game that wasn’t programmed correctly, stupid graphics, stupid game play, horrible merging of two completely different genre’s and little to no story. 1/10

reviewText: At every possible moment this game threatens to become a good shooter.  There's really no reason it shouldn't be.  It's got a gorgeous graphics engine, entertaining guns... what else do you need?  Oh right.  What we don't have here is pacing, good level design or interesting enemies.  On top of that the game just decides to end at one arbitrary point.  On my first playthrough I got through the whole game without ever firing the game's 'super weapon'.  I was saving it for a climactic boss fight or final level that never actually came.\n\nToo easy, as well.  I played through on nightmare and felt no sense of accomplishment having beaten it whatsoever.

reviewText: I would definitely recommend buying this game. It has a very Mad Max vibe and provided hours of entertainment. There is a standard FPS weapon spread (pistol, shotgun, SMG, AR, etc) and a fair variety of enemies to shoot at. I found the story to be standard post apocalypse fair but this games take on it is good. There is a decent amount of sidequests and even some races both with and without weapons to provide some more thrills. Vehicles and weapons can be customized as the story progresses. There is also decent multiplayer based off events that take place during campaign to keep you going after the campaign is finished.

reviewText: Ever wondered what it would be like if Fallout and Doom had a baby?  RAGE is that game.  It's an action game with some very mild RPG elements.  Really the only thing RPG about it is the fact that you have a pretty open sandbox world with lots of quests.  Other than that, there's no skills to upgrade, no armor to buy (although you get upgrades for your armor at pre-determined points in the game), and your weaponry is mostly given to you as quest rewards (or during your exploits).\n\nI can't say that I personally like it all that much, but to those who enjoy a good shoot-'em-up with that Fallout-vibe of a post-apocalyptic world, this could be a great way to pass the time.

reviewText:
To put it bluntly Rage is dumb.

I sorta got behind the idea of Rage, being a post apocalyptic Mad-Max style game. The only problem is that Borderlands and Fallout 3 did it first. Indeed while playing Rage it feels just like playing Borderlands without cel shaded graphics and the humor.

The lack of humor is what startled me with Rage. All the character are stock action movie grizzled veterans, the plot is extremely generic, almost everything about it is treated like the characters are incapable of laughing at their ridiculous situation.

There are good things about it, I mean the gunplay is alright and the maps are spectacularly detailed. But all the maps are tediously linear and while there are reasons to backtrack through them, you wouldn't want to. That's not even mentioning the technical problems with the game's engine, many of which still exist and have yet to be patched out

I question why this game was made and why Id would stoop so low to just make a more generic Borderlands with Call of Duty elements. One that feels like nobody put any time or attention into detail and just surgically inserted elements because they thought it would sell better.

reviewText:
I only selected no just cause of how it the ending happened. Literally it felt like funding for its story budget dried midway through so they had the CEO make an idea and used that. The writer for this story is also the guy who wrote Childs Play 2 & 3" so he is probably used to cheesy nonsenical horror endings...

Unfortunately those actually have a decent ending compared to this. Through the first half of the game it seems really great and you wonder where it can go from here. Then it gets cliche'y where you "join the resistance to fight the man blah blah blah and how you are a special person that the Authority wants for some reason."

The last mission was as anti climactic as dinner with my parents.

A nice pro though is that the gunplay is pretty fun for a while but it does start to get a litle repetitive. Gameplay on youtube looks like its a little bit more fun sometimes."

reviewText: Heyyo, it's a fun game with beautiful graphics, really interesting AI and pretty good singleplayer campaign... just avoid multiplayer, it sucks. It's buggy as hell, and very limited, especially the co-op... I'm shocked that ID Software can't make netcode work since they refined and had very solid Multiplayer on Quake 1 to 3... yet in Doom 3, Quake 4 and RAGE? Multiplayer is so laggy and buggy that the netcode lets those games down. The only games on ID Tech 5 that worked good for multiplayer? Both by Splash Damage Studios... Enemy Territory: Quake Wars which is an amazing game... and Brink... which sucked. :P

reviewText: A disappointing clone of Borderlands, Rage really has nothing to recommend it at all. It smacks terribly of a brilliantly designed engine in desperate need of a game to make the most of it. It completely lacks artistic flair, unlike Borderlands, which has oodles. The game just doesn't have any character at all. Did you ever watch the series Tru Calling? Well the game-play strongly reminds me of that series. You would have to watch the series to know why. And if I sound harsh, well, yes I am, but I expected much better from the company that pretty much invented the FPS game genre.\nRecommended? No, I am afraid not. I guess when it's in the sales, then OK, but in the mean time buy Borderlands instead.

reviewText:
The Short: An unsuccessful blend of genres

The Long:
With a setting very much like Fallout 3, RAGE instead focuses on being a straight 3D Shooter (not surprisingly given that it’s an id-game) and throws in some fancy driving/racing for good measure. But all these elements never quite gel. The driving feels very much like an afterthought to amp up the game (or an attempt to channel Mad Max 2) but not only does this feel like a separate game within the game (which the racing basically is) but it very much sabotages any kind of open world feeling games like Fallout 3 offer, since you don’t explore the world, you simply drive through it … fast!

Also the pacing of the campaign is terrible. It’s basically the concept of a linear shooter disguised as a RPG quest system. The player is rushed from one mission to the next. There are few side quests, mostly lazily designed by revisiting a previous location playing it backwards from end to start the second time. RPG elements are rudimentary and never quite pay off.
Characters are superficial and you never get emotionally invested in their stories or fates. But at least the voice acting is fairly good.

The storyline is badly constructed. Starting from the initial point from the player being rescued by Hagar just to be send out again to do missions, over establishing the faceless Authority (which way too  much looked like Half-Life 2’s Combine troops) as villains before even properly explaining what makes them villainous, to shoving the player towards joining a Resistance he knows little about. As in fact the whole background of this world is never properly established.

On the bright side the game looks very good and plays quite well as a shooter. The locations are well designed, with a decent amount of attention to detail.

In my opinion the game would have been better had it focused on being a 3D Shooter. Driving could still have been part of the game, but in a way harmonious to the gameplay (e.g. like Far Cry 2 - as mediocre as that game was).

The way it is RAGE pretends to be more than it is and fails on living up to that pretense. It’s not a bad game, but playing it leaves one disappointed because it promised more than it delivered. The ending is also fairly unsatisfactory, but I assume the developers pretty much envisioned it with some RAGE 2" in mind. In a better game it would have disappointed me. Here I really didn't care."

reviewText:
I've been playing it for a fair amount since yesterday and have just done the first Wellspring mission. While there is a reasonable FPS under there (Note: Reasonable, not original, mould-breaking or particularly enthralling in any way), it's seriously hampered by the writing and pacing out of combat, as well as just how small the world feels.

Examples:

.1 I literally laughed out loud at the start where the guy who saves you is talking about bandits basically running the area and that you both better get to the safety of his home and is like 'oh here we are' 10 seconds later at his house.

2. The NPCs take so damn long to say anything, and are happy to talk ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for five minutes before allowing you to 'use' them, and then we you finally do get the prompt, they introduce themselves to you!

3. That first Wellspring mission is seriously a pisstake: Talk to the Mayor, the mayor sends you to talk to the Sheriff, the Sheriff won't work with you until you talk to the Auto-weapons guy, who in turn, won't give you anything until you've done a race because apparently money is no good to him just 'race points' , so he sends you to the race manager, who doesn't actually DO anything except direct you to the guy behind him who sorts out the races. Bare in mind, up until the race there is literally no player agency here. It's just listening to NPCs go through their scripts and walking from one end of the town to the other. It's appalling.


The shame here, is that the concept is interesting, but it's like a themepark, not a post-apocalyptic world. The combat, while feeling 'right' with the weapon play, is just corridor shooter stuff. Worse, it's often very small corridor stuff. It makes Doom 3 feel like a sandbox when you're in the bandit/gang camps. The vehicle stuff handles well, although being in third person makes it feel overly arcady but I guess with the whole racing stuff, that's what they were going for (compare it to Half-Life 2's excellent buggy/car play, or Halo's vehicles and it comes up short).

As for the tech, I'm not really seeing what id tech 5 is bringing to the table. It doesn't look a whole lot better than id tech 4, certainly not much better than Quake 4 - and that had better feeling guns (thanks Raven software, I guess), and the texture popping I'm getting looks atrocious, and the artwork has that same 'chunky' unreal look that previous id games have (your preference may vary, but for me I don't want to see it in every game they do..get some new artists, fellas).

I really want to like this game, but a few hours in and it's getting harder to keep up hope.

reviewText:
RAGE is a shooter set in a post-apocalyptic future. RAGE is strictly a shooter (with no RPG mechanics like you'd find in the newer Fallouts), and its world is far less believable - more Mad Max than plausible future prediction. I must say that the story is linear and boring, but in the light of the previous sentence, criticising it would just seem petty.

Let's get the good over with first. RAGE looks fantastic: the graphics and the overall design are very good indeed. Character models are great and the gestures natural-looking, although most of the characters have little to say. The shooting is better than I am used to as well, with dead enemies tumbling over obstacles and maintaining momentum instead of just slumping over or ragdollizing ridiculously. Most factions have some lore tacked onto them, and the enemies fight accordingly: some gangs prefer to take cover behind each other, others like to use explosives, while others might prefer to close in without too much organizing.

That's about it for the good stuff, unfortunately. So here comes the flak:

1) The weapons are poorly balanced. The assault rifle and machine gun are particularly useless against regular enemies, and I noticed almost exclusively favouring the shotgun and wingstick (bladed boomerang). Most weapons have different ammunition to choose from; this can transform the regular pistol into a powerful magnum, the shotgun into a grenade launcher, the crossbow into a kind of long-distance taser. While this makes otherwise poor weapons at least feasible, it also moves the good ones further ahead of the game.

2) The world is tiny. It attempts to give an impression of a biggish sandbox, but there are only two hub towns and there's fairly little to do outside of missions (which are few as well). Exploration is basically useless. If you're here for a Fallout 3/New Vegas experience, forget it.

3) Remember those great graphics I mentioned? Well guess what, there is a problem: texture pop-in is a major issue without unofficial fixes (which are easy to find on the Internet, thank Christ). Even with powerful hardware, you can turn 180 degrees and have to wait a second or two to wait for the textures to load, then turn back and have to wait for the game to load the same textures you were looking at not five seconds earlier.

4) There are maybe two boss fights, both of them boring, and neither of them at the end of the game, so the rocket launcher and BFG are pretty much useless unless you go for some über-difficult playthrough. Makes me wonder why they bothered with said weapons in the first place.

5) You may have guessed this already, but the ending is crap. You just throw wingsticks for fifteen minutes and get confetti dropped on you with a you win" cutscene on the background (metaphorically
date: of course). There is no build-up to a grand end
recommended: the game just sort of stops short and goes "fine
hoursPlayed: you've won."\n\nProbably the most mediocre game that I have ever played
voteText: if that makes any sense."

reviewText:
I don't know, Rage isn't all that bad. The game does look great, but there are so many technical issues that prevented me from truly enjoying it. The fact that V-sync, at first, wasn't implemented was a bad choice. The texture pop-in was awful as well. Combine this with the freezing problem (every few minutes the game freezes for at least 1-2 seconds) and I'm sure you'll understand what I mean.
The gameplay itself is like any other shooter. With some added RPG elements. You'll  collect a lot of worthless junk (which is a shame) and complete simple, sometimes fun, quests. But since there is no real reward for the sidequests there isn't much incentive to do them at all. You'll gain money and some licenses for your vehicle, but no weapons, schematics or anything else. Not even XP. So in the end there's no feeling you're getting any stronger. A missed opportunity.
The driving segments are actually ok, but quite easy.
Anyway, I did have fun with it, but I expected more to be honest.

[Rating: 81/100]

reviewText:
I really wanted to hate RAGE, but I couldn't help having a fun time anyway. From the feeling that its a tech demo first and a half hearted entry into a new franchise second, this game is one of missed opportunities and shows how far behind the competition id Software has gotten when it comes to designing memorable experiences. Blurry textures and pop in are a small price to pay when you realize how beautiful and revolutionary MegaTexture streaming actually is from a technical standpoint. On the artistic front there's some truly standout character design and setpieces, but again, they're used only as excuses for shooting galleries.

I suspect the lukewarm reception to RAGE stems from people expecting something along the lines of an open-world RPG with idTech behind it: an amazing proposition indeed, but not what this game actually is. It's a punchy shooter with amazing animation (seriously, shoot a bandit and watch him dance) with the smallest concessions to RPG design, paired with a surprisingly robust vehicular combat component. The plot is shockingly thin, unresolved and downright lazy towards the final act. The game does more of its world building through visual shorthand rather than exposition, and its cliched post-apocalypse is better at conveying pixels and polygons than real heart and soul.

You'd never mistake this for Borderlands or Fallout, and while it lacks the variety and breadth of its distant cousins, it's still very much its own experience, and one that's worth playing through at least once (and probably only once).

reviewText:
So i finished RAGE for a third time, finally on steam as perfect game. Great idea of story, only shame they nailed end like that. Storyline has medium lenght (approx. 25hr), couple of sidequests, not very exciting, basically, just repeating already completed location reversed etc. I really want to appeal on main story quests environment and sceneries and hardest game difffficulty, its quite hard from beginning (like death on 2-3 hits, need to be very carefull), but right after purchasing first, second armor upgrade its basic game difficulty.
Next BIG plus is ARENA, RACING and MINIGAMES, especially minigames are very funny and challenging.

Graphic is a bit less anime than Borderlands, so haters of BL dont be scared of it. More music would be appreciated.

Multiplayer -
Racing and derby would be fun, but no one plays it.
CO-OP missions are very funny, BIG plus for the maps of coop missions (Wellspring street fights, or reversed demolished arena etc.).

DLCs -
Scorchers dlc is very worthy, contains big storyline, new, freaking OP weapon (Ultra nightmare difficulty is a bit easier from the beggining with that gun), and hard enemies. Also very hot lead character Sarah <3 xD

Achievements -
Perfect game could be done in one run (only Jetpack achievement requires lower difficulty). I dont like MP racing achievements (2) where u need to be in four players (coop achievements /4/ requires only 1 aditional player), and since nobody plays it, theres just chance u will find someone on steam game discussions.

Few PROS
- no inventory limit
- plenty of zombies (especially sewers missions)
- not pointlessly giant map

I've owned the game for years but other than a couple of half hearted starts where I barely put half an hour into it each time I've never played it, Until last week that is.

I've just finished my first playthrough which was on Nightmare difficulty, It took over 30 hours to complete and I managed to get 60% of the achievements (which is good for me).

I really enjoyed the game, I had no crashes, no bugs and great performance (60 fps at all times) with everything maxed on a 60hz 1080p monitor with vsr pushing it at 1440p. Visually it looks great too

From what I remember this game was never one that got rave reviews and I just don't know why.

It's a good looking, enjoyable game and the most important thing is that it is what a game should be. FUN.

It's quite an old game now meaning you can often pick it up dirt cheap but even at the current price without a sale deal it is well worth getting. If you haven't ever played Rage and it looks like your thing don't wait no longer. Treat yourself as I'm sure you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
The Short: An unsuccessful blend of genres

The Long:
With a setting very much like Fallout 3, RAGE instead focuses on being a straight 3D Shooter (not surprisingly given that it’s an id-game) and throws in some fancy driving/racing for good measure. But all these elements never quite gel. The driving feels very much like an afterthought to amp up the game (or an attempt to channel Mad Max 2) but not only does this feel like a separate game within the game (which the racing basically is) but it very much sabotages any kind of open world feeling games like Fallout 3 offer, since you don’t explore the world, you simply drive through it … fast!

Also the pacing of the campaign is terrible. It’s basically the concept of a linear shooter disguised as a RPG quest system. The player is rushed from one mission to the next. There are few side quests, mostly lazily designed by revisiting a previous location playing it backwards from end to start the second time. RPG elements are rudimentary and never quite pay off.
Characters are superficial and you never get emotionally invested in their stories or fates. But at least the voice acting is fairly good.

The storyline is badly constructed. Starting from the initial point from the player being rescued by Hagar just to be send out again to do missions, over establishing the faceless Authority (which way too  much looked like Half-Life 2’s Combine troops) as villains before even properly explaining what makes them villainous, to shoving the player towards joining a Resistance he knows little about. As in fact the whole background of this world is never properly established.

On the bright side the game looks very good and plays quite well as a shooter. The locations are well designed, with a decent amount of attention to detail.

In my opinion the game would have been better had it focused on being a 3D Shooter. Driving could still have been part of the game, but in a way harmonious to the gameplay (e.g. like Far Cry 2 - as mediocre as that game was).

The way it is RAGE pretends to be more than it is and fails on living up to that pretense. It’s not a bad game, but playing it leaves one disappointed because it promised more than it delivered. The ending is also fairly unsatisfactory, but I assume the developers pretty much envisioned it with some RAGE 2" in mind. In a better game it would have disappointed me. Here I really didn't care."

reviewText:
I've been playing it for a fair amount since yesterday and have just done the first Wellspring mission. While there is a reasonable FPS under there (Note: Reasonable, not original, mould-breaking or particularly enthralling in any way), it's seriously hampered by the writing and pacing out of combat, as well as just how small the world feels.

Examples:

.1 I literally laughed out loud at the start where the guy who saves you is talking about bandits basically running the area and that you both better get to the safety of his home and is like 'oh here we are' 10 seconds later at his house.

2. The NPCs take so damn long to say anything, and are happy to talk ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for five minutes before allowing you to 'use' them, and then we you finally do get the prompt, they introduce themselves to you!

3. That first Wellspring mission is seriously a pisstake: Talk to the Mayor, the mayor sends you to talk to the Sheriff, the Sheriff won't work with you until you talk to the Auto-weapons guy, who in turn, won't give you anything until you've done a race because apparently money is no good to him just 'race points' , so he sends you to the race manager, who doesn't actually DO anything except direct you to the guy behind him who sorts out the races. Bare in mind, up until the race there is literally no player agency here. It's just listening to NPCs go through their scripts and walking from one end of the town to the other. It's appalling.


The shame here, is that the concept is interesting, but it's like a themepark, not a post-apocalyptic world. The combat, while feeling 'right' with the weapon play, is just corridor shooter stuff. Worse, it's often very small corridor stuff. It makes Doom 3 feel like a sandbox when you're in the bandit/gang camps. The vehicle stuff handles well, although being in third person makes it feel overly arcady but I guess with the whole racing stuff, that's what they were going for (compare it to Half-Life 2's excellent buggy/car play, or Halo's vehicles and it comes up short).

As for the tech, I'm not really seeing what id tech 5 is bringing to the table. It doesn't look a whole lot better than id tech 4, certainly not much better than Quake 4 - and that had better feeling guns (thanks Raven software, I guess), and the texture popping I'm getting looks atrocious, and the artwork has that same 'chunky' unreal look that previous id games have (your preference may vary, but for me I don't want to see it in every game they do..get some new artists, fellas).

I really want to like this game, but a few hours in and it's getting harder to keep up hope.

reviewText: I'm tossed on this game. Everything about me wants to love this new shooter from the gods that damn near invented the fps genre. However, it appears IDs design team thought it would be best to stick with game play from the 1990's. Rage looks great, no doubt. The enviroments look amazing for a post apocalyptic game. Combat is fierce and all the weapons sound and feel great. So whats wrong you ask? Everything else! ID isnt know for storytelling, but after 10+ years of creating games, you would think their narrative abilities would have improved over the years. It feels like they just made a moderate sized world full of things to gib and tacked on some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t story a 5th grader wrote. Vehicles feel more like a afterthought. The fact that its you main mode of transportation really hurts too. In a nutshell, if you like mindless, boring shooting elements with a halfed ♥♥♥ crafting system and a lame ♥♥♥ travel system. Then you will like this over priced, over rated, over hyped release.
