reviewText:
RAGE is a shooter set in a post-apocalyptic future. RAGE is strictly a shooter (with no RPG mechanics like you'd find in the newer Fallouts), and its world is far less believable - more Mad Max than plausible future prediction. I must say that the story is linear and boring, but in the light of the previous sentence, criticising it would just seem petty.

Let's get the good over with first. RAGE looks fantastic: the graphics and the overall design are very good indeed. Character models are great and the gestures natural-looking, although most of the characters have little to say. The shooting is better than I am used to as well, with dead enemies tumbling over obstacles and maintaining momentum instead of just slumping over or ragdollizing ridiculously. Most factions have some lore tacked onto them, and the enemies fight accordingly: some gangs prefer to take cover behind each other, others like to use explosives, while others might prefer to close in without too much organizing.

That's about it for the good stuff, unfortunately. So here comes the flak:

1) The weapons are poorly balanced. The assault rifle and machine gun are particularly useless against regular enemies, and I noticed almost exclusively favouring the shotgun and wingstick (bladed boomerang). Most weapons have different ammunition to choose from; this can transform the regular pistol into a powerful magnum, the shotgun into a grenade launcher, the crossbow into a kind of long-distance taser. While this makes otherwise poor weapons at least feasible, it also moves the good ones further ahead of the game.

2) The world is tiny. It attempts to give an impression of a biggish sandbox, but there are only two hub towns and there's fairly little to do outside of missions (which are few as well). Exploration is basically useless. If you're here for a Fallout 3/New Vegas experience, forget it.

3) Remember those great graphics I mentioned? Well guess what, there is a problem: texture pop-in is a major issue without unofficial fixes (which are easy to find on the Internet, thank Christ). Even with powerful hardware, you can turn 180 degrees and have to wait a second or two to wait for the textures to load, then turn back and have to wait for the game to load the same textures you were looking at not five seconds earlier.

4) There are maybe two boss fights, both of them boring, and neither of them at the end of the game, so the rocket launcher and BFG are pretty much useless unless you go for some über-difficult playthrough. Makes me wonder why they bothered with said weapons in the first place.

5) You may have guessed this already, but the ending is crap. You just throw wingsticks for fifteen minutes and get confetti dropped on you with a you win" cutscene on the background (metaphorically
date: of course). There is no build-up to a grand end
recommended: the game just sort of stops short and goes "fine
hoursPlayed: you've won."\n\nProbably the most mediocre game that I have ever played
voteText: if that makes any sense."

reviewText:
The game had the potential to be alot more than what it delivers to the player. The wasteland looks beautiful & very highly detailed. However, up close the textures look hideous, probably a compromise they had to make to accomodate the limited memory available on the consoles. Despite its many shortcomings, the game had potential, its too bad they didn't expand it much further with variable side quests (most of them are merely repeats of the same map in reverse).

Its sad to see ID failing to deliver what they did so marvelously on their past releases. Quake, Doom & Wolfenstein were some of the finest shooters of their time.

reviewText: The best way I can sum up Rage is... if you are interested in playing Rage, you've already played this game. It is the next generic post-apocolypse shooter. It's like the sampler appetizer that has just a little bit of pieces of other games. However, this is the best looking of these games. Some of the textures look like total crap, but some areas and vistas look very nice. The game does take a lot of hard drive space for a fairly short game. Overall, it wasn't bad. It took around 13 hours to finish. The story is generic. Most of the combat is done in linear corriders. I didn't care for the hit detection when shooting enemies. Shoot them once and you gotta wait to shoot them again or the hit won't register. A lot of bullets and time were wasted having to wait through the AI recovery  god frame animations so the next bullet will register. Most of the exploration is done with vehicles that let you travel the map. I'd recommend getting Rage if it's on sale and you want some mindless fun. It is unremarkable in every way, but I still managed to have some fun with it.

reviewText:
The game has a very shallow story. The gameplay is okay. The levels are very much on rails, the fights predictable, and the methods to win are very clearly spelled out to you. I felt like the game never stopped holding my hand, and that got really boring.

I think this was made really to be more of an engine showcase. Games built using this engine are finally about to be released. Wolfenstein: The New Order, The Evil Within, and Doom 4 are all being built on the id Tech 5 engine.

Worth $5? Sure. Why not. Don't go in with high expectations, though. Just enjoy blowing stuff up.

reviewText:
I've owned the game for years but other than a couple of half hearted starts where I barely put half an hour into it each time I've never played it, Until last week that is.

I've just finished my first playthrough which was on Nightmare difficulty, It took over 30 hours to complete and I managed to get 60% of the achievements (which is good for me).

I really enjoyed the game, I had no crashes, no bugs and great performance (60 fps at all times) with everything maxed on a 60hz 1080p monitor with vsr pushing it at 1440p. Visually it looks great too

From what I remember this game was never one that got rave reviews and I just don't know why.

It's a good looking, enjoyable game and the most important thing is that it is what a game should be. FUN.

It's quite an old game now meaning you can often pick it up dirt cheap but even at the current price without a sale deal it is well worth getting. If you haven't ever played Rage and it looks like your thing don't wait no longer. Treat yourself as I'm sure you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
If you are considering whether to buy this game during the sale, then i suggest that you give these modern single player shooters a shot before Rage:
-S.T.A.L.K.E.R. (any of 3)

-Metro 2033/Last Light
-Far Cry 3
The games i have listed above are better than Rage in terms of story,environment,characters, enemies, arsenal and gameplay.
What you get with Rage is essentially Mad Max- inspired pseudo-open-world (empty Wasteland with access hubs).
Even if the game was made by well established FPS developer like Id Software, it doesnt have the appeal of their other game franchises like Doom,Quake and Wolfenstein.

reviewText:
Rage is a very nice First-Person-Shooter. Although I usually don't play FPS very often I realy enjoyed this one.
The story is good, but the ending is a little unsatisfactory. The mixture between a normal FPS and a racing game is awesome. On normal difficulty the enemies are not that tough and the story can easily be explored. If you like a challange then you have to play ultra nightmare difficulty. The enemies will always hit you, if you don't hide, and sneak around. I recommend playing in this difficulty setting when you are playing it the second time.
There are several weapons that you can use. Most of them will be given to you by playing through the story. You can buy upgrades to improve the handling.
Muliplayer is nice. There are some coop missions and racing maps. I recommend playing with friends or you have to wait long between matches, because there are not many people playing the MP.

8/10

reviewText:
A truly underrated gem.

RAGE is a visceral first-person shooter with vehicular combat.

Many mistake the game for an open world-type; RPG. It does implement RPG elements in the vehicle and gun categories - allowing you to upgrade and customize your guns and vehicle the way you want to play. Each unique gun has multiple types of ammunition to kill mutants with, and the vehicle comes with many different options such as turrets, mines and rocket launchers. The game is somewhat open world"

such as:

RESISTANCE - A group of people who seek to destroy the Authority's power over the Wasteland.

AUTHORITY- A highly organized and weaponized military force that controls and shapes the Wasteland how they see fit. Unlike the mutants and bandits that wander the Wasteland
voteText: the Authority knows what it's doing. They use personal energy shields

and utilize cover and tactics.

BANDITS

reviewText:
I've owned the game for years but other than a couple of half hearted starts where I barely put half an hour into it each time I've never played it, Until last week that is.

I've just finished my first playthrough which was on Nightmare difficulty, It took over 30 hours to complete and I managed to get 60% of the achievements (which is good for me).

I really enjoyed the game, I had no crashes, no bugs and great performance (60 fps at all times) with everything maxed on a 60hz 1080p monitor with vsr pushing it at 1440p. Visually it looks great too

From what I remember this game was never one that got rave reviews and I just don't know why.

It's a good looking, enjoyable game and the most important thing is that it is what a game should be. FUN.

It's quite an old game now meaning you can often pick it up dirt cheap but even at the current price without a sale deal it is well worth getting. If you haven't ever played Rage and it looks like your thing don't wait no longer. Treat yourself as I'm sure you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
I absolutely loved playing this game.  The combination of viseral combat, super AI use of cover, flanking and working in teams makes this one of the most exhilirating FPS experiences out there. This game is action-packed with superb graphics and the voice-acting is bang on the button.

A perfect synergy between Fallout3 & Metro2033 provides the most wonderful atmospheric setting. An excellent backdrop to a dramatic story tied together through a series of impressive locations. A great arsenal of weapons and many different types of non-weapon equipment allows for different combat strategies to kill bad-guys.

The many different sub-games such as racing, mini-gambling of skill and chance are a perfect compliment to the combat. On top of this the multiplayer racing and combat oriented challenges, extend the life of what would be a rather short game.
Despite this and the SP not-really being replayable the game is one you should get, play and enjoy... until you run out of things to do. Just dont mention the ending... the real fun is playing the game, not reaching the end!

Car combat is poorly designed, the Car AI stinks and the mounted minigun is worthless due to the superiority of the other mounted weapons.  Textures are trash and id should be embarassed. reviewText:
I like this game. It is a few years old now but the graphics are still fairly good overall. Overall it is a first-person shooter style game, but they added in a driving/racing aspect that not only seems to work fairly well, but to me adds a degree of realism to a post-apocolyptic world that so many other games seem to lack. And unlike some other games, while you can just walk around out on the main map; taking the buggy or the monarch to drive around definitely gets you there both faster and safer. There is a good amount to do in this game aside from the main quest line in the form of side quests and challenges, as well as several easter eggs from the older id software games that are just kinda cool to collect.

Now for the bad. Thw game is fairly linear overall. You can miss out on things by progressing the main storyline too far too fast, and I'm not a big fan of that in open-world games. It's not too bad as long as you do optional side quests first then the main 1 but on initial playthrough it might not be obvious. Also, might just be because I'm late to the party, as in I did not buy this game when it was brand new, but there is never anybody on the multiplayer side of this so I can't unlock the rest of my acheivements. not a huge deal, but a little disappointing.

Overall, like I said, I really do enjoy the game. I would rate the overall experience as about a 7 out of 10. Definitely worth trying.

reviewText:
You're awaken in a lifepod after a big piece of rock hits Earth and made it a wasteland with people of different nationalities. There's basically 2 cities and a garage in the wastes. Some bandits are Brits while others speak with Russian accent etc.

You fight all enemies in dungeons (old city, factories, sewers) connected by open-world corridor defended by bandit cars that you can either kill for cash or avoid or get killed by. You can visit a total of 5 or so dungeons and then do them again in sidequests. You'll probably forget them anyway. One dungeon is special though as you can revisit it backwards. That one you will remember for life!

In the free cities you can join offroad races in different modes, most of them spiced by miniguns and rockets. Races earn you points you can spend on vehicle upgrades like thicker armour and wheel spikes.

I don't think multiplayer (racing only) was ever alive in this game on PC and I only tried co-op back at release and it was too laggy.

Pros: I really enjoyed shooting. There's only so many weapons but all of them have several different ammo types making shooting even more fun and interesting. It really makes up for other stuff. Voice acting is also decent.

6.5/10 get it on sale

I finally got to finish this thing, and after how many years. The release for this game was bad. It was a disaster plagued by bugs, performance issues and straightup incompatibility with some hardware. It took me a long time to get over the disgust from pre-ordering it.

reviewText:
I like to think of RAGE as a mod for Borderlands. You have a wasteland, vehicles, weapons, bald dudes running after you screaming weird stuff, quests, side quests and a main story line. However, the game does have its downpoints. First, the graphics engine, rather than preloading all textures for each map, to keep a persisten wasteland map, it streams the textures on-the-fly. In other words, if you are looking at somewhere and quickly turn around, and your streaming velocity isn't fast enough, you'll be able to see the low-res replacement textures as the hi-res ones replace them.

Be ware: It is as repetitive as Borderlands...
My suggestion: If it goes on sale, get it. Otherwise, you can pass this one.

reviewText:
It seems that success was never in Rage's destiny. id Software (known for their genre-defining shooters, Wolfenstein 3D and Doom) released their 2011 open-world shooter in a post-Fallout 3 gaming landscape, choosing to leave their world fairly empty and uneventful aside from car combat encounters. It's testament to id Software's brilliance at making a polished combat system that the many flaws Rage has don't massively detract from the fun you'll have playing through it.

It's glaringly apparent throughout Rage that much work has gone into the combat. Guns feel great to fire, with multiple modes of fire and different kinds of ammo to suit the varied situations and enemies you'll be encountering. There's a decent selection of them too, with the Combat Shotgun being a particular favourite, as you blast shells into mutants and bandits alike. There's also an Engineering (aka crafting) element, where you combine components to build certain tools. It's quite fun to build Sentry Turrets and deploy them, as well as RC Car Bombs that you can drive into a group of enemies and detonate. You'll quickly find yourself creating bandages to heal up more quickly, and making a ton of Pop Rockets for your shotgun for that extra explosive bang. Simply put, id knows how to do guns and do them right.

As mentioned before, there's a fair bit of car combat in the game. We've since had games like Mad Max that do this quite a bit better, but here it's not too bad. You get a selection of cars throughout the game, and you can arm those with machine guns and rockets. Most of your encounters will be as you drive from one objective to another, and you can earn money from destroying bandit vehicles and returning to Wellspring or Subway Town for rewards. There's a decent amount of things to do in the game, with races and mini-games, plus the two main towns with their Job Boards that offer side quests.

The biggest issues with Rage all concern its story and quests. You're mostly looking at a run of fetch quests throughout the game, and everything feels a bit samey. There's a general feeling of meh" throughout the experience
date: as you venture into locations (sometimes more than once if you have to go back for a side quest) and dispatch of enemies
recommended: then either pick something up to bring back to town or plant something there. This is mostly a game that concerns itself with the fun feeling of shooting things

reviewText:
I bought this game thinking it would be good. It certainly didn't look bad on screens and reviews weren't that bad either.
What a mistake this was.

There's some kind of story that isn't that easy to follow as you are too busy being a good dog and fetching stuff for incompetent people who can't drive 500 meters to do it themselves.

The graphics is okay, but definitely not good. While models look quite pretty and detailed, textures of the environment are blurry and very low-res. There's an option to turn details for textures on, but if you do, FPS goes WAY down and the change isn't even that remarkable.

The sounds are standard. There's not much to say about them. There's also music that fits the atmosphere, but sadly isn't very memorable.

When it comes to gameplay, the game takes some time to get used to. Enemies run around doing parkour stunts, so it's sometimes quite difficult to hit them (in the head). You can also drive vehicles and install weapons on them to be able to defend yourself from bandits who also own vehicles. Driving feels okay as long as you don't race. It's not like the racing is so bad, but AI drivers are masters of rally and you might have a hard time winning the first place. Races in the second part of the game are extremely frustrating.
What kills this game are the minigames. They are mostly based on luck and even if they aren't, the game is ready to ♥♥♥♥ in your mouth anyway. It doesn't help that the game has achievements, which means more frustration for achievement hunters like myself as you MUST win all those unfair minigames. Did the lousy developers really think this was fun?

To sum it up, this game is pretty much average. It's fine for people who don't go for 100% and avoid all the frustrating stuff the game has to offer. I personally was in rage several times, so at least the bloody title is fitting.

EDIT: Finally did it. What were you thinking, idiots? Why so frustrating?

reviewText:
First things first.  If you do not like arcade style play do NOT buy this game!  There are certain sections early on that require arcade play and a must win (Dusty 8 Race) before you can progress any further.  If you can't hammer away at these sections you're done playing the game (which is where I am now).

The FPS portion of the game is great.  Fun weapons and very challenging.  It is unfortunate that many encounters are proximity triggered so there's not as much sneaking up on the enemy as I personally prefer.  Great for those 'run in and kill' player style folks though.

The monetary system is a bit of a challenge early on, but as with most games it gets easier.  Some of the side betting games in Wellsprings help.  On the downside, I think there are too many games within the game.  They're nice distractions I guess, but they don't lend to the storyline (as far as I got that is).

The explorable world is really not all that big.  This is not some large open map, but rather a nicely textured backdrop in which missions are narrowly bracketed into the surrounding landscape.  It takes little to no time to find the outer boundaries of the map in each mission.  No climbing over the boulders, sneaking around, and getting the lay of the land before you proceed around that blind curve... you're just gonna have to proceed.

In as much as the previous mission areas remain open, creating an ever expanding environment... vast" hardly describes your gameplay area.

The flexibility in assigning key controls is good.  I prefer to keep as much as possible on the keypad and the number of commands allows things to fit nicely.  The graphics are beautiful.  The responsiveness in game (on my machine anyway) is great!

I can't recommend the game though.  The game description does not accurately reflect the limitations in play and as I noted previously
date:
there's no clear mention of game stops at arcade style missions much less mention of arcade play at all.  Had I known they existed I would never have purchased the game.

After a mixed bag of high enjoyment in FPS and extreme disappointment and frustration in arcade play the game will be unloaded and placed in the virtual trashcan.

There are those that will greatly enjoy the mix of play.  To you I tip my hat!"

reviewText:
The only problems with the game is that it is too short, it lacks content and is limited on explorable land/areas.

- AMAZING story
- AMAZING gameplay
- Very unique in almost ALL of its aspects
- Beautiful graphics
- Cool npcs...
- The list goes on and on.

Its unfortunate however that the game had SO much more potential and I WISH they included more and perhaps even a more open world as I loved the story and path of the protagonist (even though the protagonist himself lacked importance - perhaps because he had no voice) and simply would have given this a 10/10 if there were more towns/interesting places to visit.

Therefore im forced to give the game an 8 out of 10 :P Still amazing. Praying that they release RAGE 2 with a more open world/longer story line to follow.

reviewText:
Hmm what to say...Well at first I saw this game as a Fallout 3/Boardlands rip off. Because of the fact we're in a distopian future, there are vaults and people want to get to the vaults. Game also seems kinda sexist as every woman (apart from elderly woman) I dressed with no tops besides a thin bikini or one-trap bra ann the either wear shorts or jeans in the rare cases.

So...good things about the game:

*Your weapons have a varied types of ammo such as armour peircing rounds or explosive on some weapons.
*The opening of the story is very engaging and interesting, thought your character being a silent protagonist doesn't add to it.
*You end up straight into the action, but not in too much of a jarring way.
*There are many side-missions and minigames to earn cash such as bulletin board, gambling and others.
*You have a crafting system
*it's a lot of fun.
*You are not stuck to one vehicle and get to change to more advanced ones as you go.

However there are many bad parts.

*The characters are all quite forgettable
*There aren't nearly enough side-missions as Boardlands, which does in a way make it more enjoyable.
*The rendering is HIDIOUS. I bought this game late in the date. It's been out for 2 years and they havn't fixed the horrible rendering? If you move around a corner too fast all the textures become blobs and enemies, in a few cases, dissappear until the texture loads up.
*There is a lag at times, which means you can miss a good shot or, most frustraitingly, you can mess up at five-fingered fillet.
*The story, whilst started strong, has a very lack-luster ending.
*Numerous bugs, including a loss of sound leading to watching the end movie on youtube because it cut out and was silent.
*Despite your character never been seen in 3rd dimensions apart from end of mutant bash, you cannot customise your character nor does he appear to have a name.
*SOME weapons are upgradable, but not many.

Over-all it's a fun game and I found myself addicted to playing it, having fun decapitating people with the wingsticks and so on. Despite it's many errors, I would recommend it, if you were just after a fun fps to burn off steam. However if you're looking for something better in storyline then I suggest something more along the lines of Half-life or Portal or even System Shock. It's sad to see Id Software ♥♥♥♥ this out with Bethesda. At times there seemed to be good ideas, but at other times they either aren't expanded upon enough or fall flat. Almost like Id Software had a suggestion, Bethesda tried it, then failed misirbly and didn't even put any effort into it.

One final thing, this game was obviously made for a controller. You cannot scroll through all your weapons, only 4 pre-sets which, based on the shape, probably are accessable with the D-pad. If anything get this game on a sale and only if you have no other FPSs to play. However there are many funny Id software easter eggs in there :)

reviewText:
TL;DR:
In all honesty, the game is perfectly competent in what it does. In terms of presentation, it was consistently at 60 frames a second with only a few performance issues. It’s just a game that comes across as boring and heartless. It felt like there were a series of extra check boxes that were added to their list of necessities in development to try and appease various niches when they should have focused on making a good/creative shooter without all these flat bells and whistles that take away from the core experience. As a result, instead of standing out from the crowd Rage manages to look more bland than its competitors.

For the full review, go here: http://dagondogs.com/2015/02/17/rage-review/

reviewText:
tldr; first, then further reading below:

Pros:
- Beautiful game. From the graphics to the color choices to the excellent level aesthetics, RAGE has an immersive world to explore.
- Plenty of tense, enjoyable moments blasting everything from raging mutants to the coordinated assaults of the authority
- Enemy animations are a joy to watch. Enemies jump, duck, roll, climb from the ceiling and react to hits from your weapons in a way no other game does
- Mixes up the standard shooter genre with driving sections, a light crafting system and different ammo types for most guns offering various ways to use weaponry in interesting ways

Cons:
- The ending is cut short with a fairly anticlimactic assault sequence
- Driving mechanics and AI are not as well fleshed out as could be, almost an afterthought for the way some of it works
- Multiplayer feels tacked on with the co-op missions being rehashed levels of the campaign and racing that feels dry and boring
- Fairly easy game, even on the ultra nightmare difficulty added by the DLC

Rating: 4/5

RAGE... It's a game that a lot of people like to hate on. Looking at it from a perspective purely focused on game design and implementation, yes RAGE is lacking. There's one thing that most people don't take into account when enjoying games however and that is the perspective from games as art. From that standpoint, ID nails it with RAGE. It's a simply beautiful game that stands the test of time even now and because of that:

I LOVE RAGE

By far some of the most fun I've had with the game has been bullet spraying, sniping, shotgunning, wingsticking or otherwise pulverizing enemies and seeing their death and reaction animations. Having enemies duck and dodge at the last second, swing across the ceiling and stumble and roll as they're shot in the shoulder is extremely satisfying to watch. It makes the game much more immersive than most shooters where enemies stand there and then die like robots repeating the same motions over and over.

The graphics help with this and to this day RAGE has some of the best looking graphics there is. The textures may not hold up to modern ones but the overall aesthetic and graphical fidelity certainly does. RAGE looks gorgeous, check out some of the screenshots I or others have taken and see for yourself the colorful environments that are pleasantly in line with the setting of the game. Ruined cruise ships sitting on top of cities made from industrial steel sheets, a town converted from an old subway station, a maniacal TV host with a carnival themed arena of death, RAGE continues to amaze with each chapter of the game fitting a well crafted post apocalyptic theme.

Also of note is the attempt by ID to try new things with the standard shooter genre. Weapons have alternate ammunition types which alter the way they're used, some to a greater degree than others. There's also a light crafting system in the game that lets you construct items from health bandages to stationary turrets and even robotic spider turrets. While the game doesn't ever require you to need these items as even on the hardest difficulty the game can be completed without any of them, it's a nice addition that does allow for some different approaches to combat if desired.

---

RAGE does have it's negative sides however and it's unfortunate that this is all some people see in the game. It's been heavily criticized for it's ending sequence and yes, it does leave something to be desired. The last half of the game in general does seem rushed and not as creative as the first half although again the aesthetic and attention to detail is still there. Even right to the end the game each sequence is fantastic to behold with the level, enemy and weapon design being the saving grace for me.

With the mechanics ID added to mix up the genre they came close to creating something magical but ended up stumbling a bit in the implementation. The driving mechanics first of all could have been done better. While it's fun to turbo boost yourself around the wasteland firing machine guns and rockets at other cars in a Twisted Metal fashion, the vehicle controls and enemy AI do feel lackluster compared the rest of the game mechanics. An afterthought kind of feeling can't help but be conveyed especially after your tenth or so race with the enemy cars driving ever so cautiously behind you as not to be too hard on you but not too easy on you either and then immediately dumping their ammo supply upon pickup in a very predictable way.

While appreciated, the crafting and ammo system is also somewhat lackluster in it's implementation because while everything in the game is indeed fun to use on it's own, the game is not balanced well enough nor ever requires you to use any of what's given to complete the game. In fact if you play on normal difficulty you can very easily use nothing but the shotgun and the occasional showing of a rifle for the entire game. The disconnect between the ideas in the game and the implementation in conjunction with the enemy AI shows although. Again however, the fun in using the available mechanics is there should you choose to enjoy the game in it's fullest.

One more thing to note and is as much of an afterthought as the mode itself is the multiplayer element. While nice to have, multiplayer does indeed feel tacked on offering two modes that are entirely forgettable. First there is a co-op mission mode but the missions are just rehashed levels from the campaign. You and your partner compete for points by killing enemies the fastest and most efficient. The other mode is up to four player races and destruction derbys that are more fun than the co-op mode but the race mechanics are dry enough that it doesn't redeem it as something that will last you more than a few plays.

---

Overall I certainly enjoyed my time with RAGE, enough to buy the DLC and complete the achievements. It's going up as one of my favorite shooters despite it's flaws and it's a game I wholeheartedly recommend everyone try.
